info.content:
Mummy, Katie, Ben and Catherine went to London to visit the London Dungeons. It was really good with actors, acting out famous murders and generally trying to spook you out in the dark.

Ben was shocked at how poorly organised Mummy was. She didn't even have a timetable or know what platform the trains went from! Eh Ben?

By the London Eye

Katie went in the rain to Thorpe Park with some of her school friends. She had a good time.

Katie and friends

In the morning daddy put up the new blinds in the conservatory. It was harder than it looks and daddy was getting stressed at it. Anyway they are all up now and we like it. We just need some sun now to test whether the blinds help stop making it oven like in the conservatory.

In the afternoon we went off to Jakes Recreation ground in Binfield to meet up with the Barnett crew. Todd and Ollie had come over from Canada with their newly adopted son, Nicholas. He is 2 years old and originally from South Korea.

It was nice to see everyone there. Daddy came a little later as he rode in.

Jessa

Benna

Katiea

title.value: Katie Tutoring, Todd and Ollie Family Gathering

info.content:
In the morning we all went over to Dorking to see Daddy and Duncan run a hilly parkrun in the Denbies Wine Estate. Duncan is in training for the London Marathon, so they said they'd take it easy. Don't know about Duncan but Daddy wouldn't have been able to go much faster. We all love Duncan. Very friendly.

Daddy and Dunc do Mole Valley parkrun

Route

Walk 108 saw us go down the road to Ockley for a longer walk than usual. A 4.5 miler, which turned into 5 miles after some navigational issues. Erm Mummy? It was a nice walk. We were approached by some geese. You'd have thought they were lions to way some reacted! We made it back to the car after a couple of hours. On the way home we stopped off at the very busy Christmas Bakery. Somewhere Katie has wanted to stop off at for a long while!

Ockley Walk

Route

In the afternoon, Katie popped into Camberley to stalk Catherine on her date. She then joined Daddy and Ben who were at Camberley Town FC watching Chertsey win 3-0, and go top of the table.

Ma Ma was away, so we invited Pop Pop over for dinner and to play board games. We played Rummikub and Ticket To Ride Europe.

title.value: Denbies parkrun, Walk 108 - Ockley, CTFC, Pop Pop over

info.content:
It was an early start for some, even earlier as the clocks went back an hour. Daddy started making and baking bread for Farmor's breakfast. Jessica got up and help make pancakes for mummy's breakfast in bed.

After Mummy and Jessica went to church, the lot of us went to Portsmouth, to the Historic Dockyard. We embarrassingly mistook HMS victory for the Mary Rose. Once we found the Mary Rose, partially built, we wandered around the museum. Us children weren't particularly interested. Mummy was well in to it all. Anyway we spent over 3 hours marveling at the exhibition.

Henry VIII and friends

The Mary Rose

We had booked a table at the Dice Cafe and spent another 3 hours playing board games. We played Picture Codenames, Pandemic (a collaborative strategy game), Ticket To Ride Europe, Mobile Phone Game and some really rubbish board game (can't remember the name). We had a good time, and deffo want to come back again. We bought Ticket To Ride Europe.

Dice Cafe

title.value: Mother's Day, Mary Rose, Dice Cafe

info.content:
In the morning Daddy had parkrun at Frimley Lodge. Jessica was also in the running mood, sprinting up and down Elmcroft Close.... however, didn't feel brave enough to take on a parkrun.

The Falcon's were at Heatherside for an 11am kick off against Cove, who were in a division above. We had almost a full squad. Unfortunately the goalkeeper had a nightmare, dropped catches, ball through the legs, etc. We lost 5-3.

Mummy and Jessica departed for Bournemouth with Ma Ma and Pop Pop. They met with their aunties and cousins to play crazy golf and have dinner at a burger restaurant.

Daddy, Ben and Katie went to Chertsey's biggest game ever, the FA Vase Semi Final second leg against Northwich Victoria. First leg ended 1-1. Daddy helped on the turnstile and saw in over 400 spectators, taking Â£2500! There were a lot of notes floating around. Katie was helping Farmor in the tea bar serving drinks and taking money. Another Â£20 earnt.

Alwyns Lane full

The terraces were packed. Similar to the Aldershot game some 16 years previous. Farfar reckoned there were more in attendance today. The game ended 0-0 after extra time. Penalties! It was tense, but Chertsey scored all 5 of their pens. Northwich missed one. We were through. There was a pitch invasion. Everyone was so happy. Mission accomplished. Getting to Wembley is the main achievement, the result in the final is almost incidental. We cannot wait till the 18th May now.

title.value: parkrun, Falcons lose, Chertsey Town v Northwich Victoria FA Vase Semi Final 2nd Leg, Bournemouth with Westons

info.content:
Chertsey travelled up to Northwich Victoria for the FA Vase Semi Final 1st leg. Daddy and Ben joined Farfar and trained in up to Warrington. They had some time whilst waiting for their train from Euston, so Ben weaved his persuasive magic and conned Daddy into walking to Warren Street, McDonalds whilst having a hypo! After getting jammy with the order, they had to rush back to an anxious Farfar. Of course they took a wrong turning up a no-through road just to make it a bit more interesting!

On the way up Ben and Daddy played Ticket To Ride. A taxi journey to the ground, actually owned by Witton Albion, and they all got boardroom passes.

Windy Northwich

The game itself was spoilt by the windy conditions. Chertsey took the lead, but were pegged back in the second half. An even game.

They caught the team coach back to Warrington, then the train back to Euston and home. A good day out.

title.value: Northwich Victoria v Chertsey Town. FA Vase Semi Final 1st Leg

info.content:
In the morning Daddy went to Upton Court parkrun, near Slough. He started 8 minutes late! Another tourist run chalked up.

Unusually the Falcons had an afternoon match against Joey's lot. Without playing great we won 4-1 in Alton.

Ben and Joey had to leave the game early as they had a Sky Dive experience booked in Basingstoke in an indoor centre. They had a briefing then 2 x 1 minute sessions in the wind tunnel. On the second go, they were taken to the top of a dome and then down again. Ben said it was the best experience he's had! He loved it.

Daddy motorbiked home from Ben's Sky Diving experience along the M3. A week previous Daddy managed to sustain a puncture and got it plugged. Daddy raced home at 80mph along the motorway. He felt the handling a little strange, but put it down to having a hypo. By the time he got to Hook he lost confidence a bit and slowed down. It felt like the handlebars and the rest of the bike were attached via string or Sellotape. Steering seemed weird. Just as he was coming off at junction 4, he noticed a group of lads staring at the bike. Suspicious he stopped on the hard shoulder, felt the back tyre. Completely flat and scorching hot. No wonder people were looking. How did he manage to go at 60mph on a flat down the motorway? He managed to nurse the bike back home at 15mph. The sidewall had been damaged. After taking the bike in for a new tyre, Barry said the original puncture had re-appeared as well as a new one. Lucky to stay upright!

Tyre off the rim

title.value: parkrun, Alton v Falcons, Ben Sky Dive, Puncture on motorbike at 80mph

info.content:
Mummy was suffering from anxiety this week, so Daddy decided to treat Mummy by taking the day off work and taking her to the Ideal Home Exhibition. However, Mummy didn't want to go with the crowds, so declined the ticket! They did however go over to the Kingfisher for a nice lunch.

Daddy spent the morning mostly painting over the two colours Mummy had used in the hall way.

Daddy went with the Fars to Kensington Olympia. It was OK. Daddy was tempted at the Robot Lawnmower. He got some tool sharpeners, a basket for fire logs and some pillows for us!

The sweet stall

Daddy had a check-up recently and results have returned. Daddy was astounded at his weight gain. 84kg! So he has put himself on a diet, aiming now for 77kg.

More importantly the HbA1c result. It came out at 61mmol/mol. This was better than last year, but not that close to the recommended 49mmol/mol.

History of Hb1Ac results over the years.

  • 2013: 55
  • 2013: 76
  • 2014: 76
  • 2014: 94
  • 2015: 71
  • 2016: 70
  • 2017: 56
  • 2018: 69
  • 2019: 61

Speaking with Keith, there is a chance of getting the Libre for free after April. Daddy has also pushed for a pump with the aim to get a closed-loop system. Next step is an appointment at the hospital for this. There was some disagreement on the recommended HbA1c value. Keith reckoned it to be 59mmol/mol, not 49!

Daddy and Ben continued in their quest to visit all the football league grounds inside the M25. They drove to Crystal Palace and embarked on their 25 mile journey in winding and fresh conditions.

It was a nice ride and by the time they got to Catford, Ben had convinced Daddy into a McDonalds! Next stop was Pop Pops old house, 95 Pitfold Road. Along the way, Ben rode over a broken bottle and somehow managed to avoid a puncture! The house in Lee was in good condition which was comforting to see.

At Pop Pop Pop's old house

A short distance away was Charlton Athletic. The boys both needed the toilet desperately so water the plants there!

Through Greenwich and onto Millwall who had a quatre final FA Cup game today against Brighton. As such, the ground was open and we sneaked in and even got one of the staff to take a picture of us both there, before they shut the gates firmly!

A long trek back through a quaint Dulwich and a tough Sydenham Hill. They rode past the infamous radio masts.

Route

Three more football grounds ticked off

title.value: Crystal Palace, Charlton, Millwall bike ride

info.content:
In the morning Daddy went off to parkrun. After he managed a 3-2 victory against bottom of the table Beacon Hill Sparks. Ben wasn't 100% and didn't play too well.

Katie went off to Maths class at school. She is really getting into boys now and is proving a distraction to her exams in a couple of months time. Daddy is trying to get her back on track again with her revision. Over the past week or so not a lot has been done!

Summer came and stayed last night and tonight. Katie gets on very well with her, although a lot of time is spent them texting on their phones.... not to each other. In the evening they were dropped off in Camberley and went to Creams.

Jessica went shopping with the girls in the early afternoon and bought an outfit including a fetching hat. She loves fashion.

In the morning Mummy went to church. Daddy embarked on a very gusty bike ride with Bob over to the croquet club area to watch the Surrey Half Marathon.

Bike Route

Katie had her tutoring this morning and went over some Physics. She found today's session useful.

After a Sunday roast, we headed to the other side of Surrey for one of the final walks in the Surrey book. Today, Woldingham on the North Downs. We headed around the 3.5 mile circuit. Near the end we came across this old man struggling up the hill with a trolley. He did like to talk, especially from the past. It was sweet, although he did go on a bit. Daddy in the end felt sorry for the chap and wheel his trolley through the mud to the top of the hill. He even offered to give him a lift home.

Strike the pose

Ben missed the walk as he had a bad throat, although he didn't escape church club with Katie.

Later we played another game of Ticket To Ride.

Walk 107 Route

In the morning Ben played in Falcons 4-2 win in a friendly game played at Heatherside. The Fars came along to watch. Ben played OK, but is still getting his re-occurring knee issues.

Meanwhile Katie went to school of her own volition, just because she enjoys spending time with her friends. Not because of the extra maths that was put on in the morning!

At the beginning of the afternoon we all went to Basingstoke, mainly because Ben and Mummy wanted to see the new Marvel film in the cinema with recliner seats. We first went to pizza hut to eat lunch before moving on to the Vue cinema. Daddy thought this to be a good opportunity to have a nice sleep in the recliner, leather seats whilst watching (cough, cough) the Lego Movie 2 with the girls!

comfy seats at the cinema

Mummy and Ben enjoyed the Marvel film a bit more than the others who watch the Lego film. We all loved the seating, despite it costing over Â£50.

Later in the evening Daddy went off to Reading to meet up with Steve, Nick and Phil. He had a good time.

Daddy out with Steve, Phil and Nick

title.value: Falcons win, Katie Extra Maths, Pizza Hut and Cinema, Boys night out

info.content:
Daddy went over to James's for a Frimley Flyers card night. Daddy did well to only lose Â£6 on the night.

James' Card Night

In the morning the Falcons played football over at the Police College in Bramshill. It was a friendly against a team in a division higher. Not for a few goalkeeping clangers, the Falcons would have won the game. However, we lost 4-2.

The gilrs had planned a trip to London to visit Madam Tussauds and later the Old Operating Theatre Museum at St Thomas' hospital. They enjoyed both places.

Some pop stars

Someone from a different planet. ET.

Hunger Games

Walking like a cat

Popping in for tea

Freddie!

Elvis!

Spiddy

Harrison and his no.1 fan

Princess or Sloth

May the force be with you

In the evening they played Ticket To Ride.

title.value: Falcons Lose, Madam Tussauds, Old Operating Theatre

info.content:
Ben and Daddy woke and met up with the Fars in their room as they had ordered drinks and a newspaper for room service! Shortly after the boys went off to the Durham parkrun. It was a 2km jog to the start which was at the university sports ground. Ben was getting all the excuses ready, from knee hurting to haven't run for ages. It was a pleasant run, especially in the last half up the River Wier with Durham Cathedral in the background.

Route

Post Parkrun Framed Photo

We walked back to the hotel with the Fars who came to watch them finish. After a nice breakfast where we stuffed our faces we went to the hotel pool. Farmor joined Ben and Daddy in the swimming pool. We snuck Ben into the sauna and steam room. After each the boys had challenged each other to the plunge pool. Both passed! Whilst in the Jacuzzi Ben was told he was too young. Luck had run out.

We said goodbye to Farmor who continued to look around Durham. Daddy and Ben sneaked in to peek at some lecture theaters in Durham University The three boys then caught a bus to West Auckland to watch Chertsey Town play in the quatre finals of the FA Vase. They went into the local pub in West Auckland only to find a load of other Chertsey Town supporters! The ground was neat and tidy and had some interesting undulations. Chertsey brought a 100 or so supporters. They were by far the noisiest out of the 734 in attendance. Chertsey started strong and went 2-0 up in the first half and hour. They then pretty much sat on the lead and defended resolutely to run out victors. Great celebrations afterwards, especially on the team coach back to Darlington. A full on karaoke session started up. It was a fantastic atmosphere. A short pub stay before we took the long train back to Kings Cross and then home. We hit our bed at midnight.

West Auckland FC

Meanwhile the girls met up with the Teales at Crystal Palace park.

Crystal Palace with the Teales

In the evening Katie went off to a party.

title.value: Durham parkrun, Chertsey Town FA Vase Quatres, Crystal Palace park

info.content:
Daddy went to work, but then rushed home to pick Ben up and caught the train to Durham, where the Fars met them. They stayed at the 4* Marriott Hotel. Ben said it was the poshest hotel he's stayed at.

Platform 9 3/4s at Kings Cross

Again we went down to Morrisons for breakfast. we saw again this crazy family who we reckoned to be Mormons. They had 6 children all under the age of 5! The parents look knackered. Anyway they had the same idea as us as patrons of the hotel and eating at the supermarket.

After a walk around the seafront we headed home with a few stop off points.

New Brighton

Perch Rock Lighthouse

First Daddy wanted to visit Prenton Park and Tranmere Rovers. They boys got out and couldn't really see inside the ground. They went into the club shop and asked if they could peer in. Luckily they offered for someone to show us around for 10 minutes. So they went into the home team dressing rooms, down the tunnel and onto the pitch. A great little experience.

Prenton Park, Tranmere Rovers

Next stop was Velocity, a inflatable park. A bit like a trampoline park, but with a massive inflatable instead! The three of us loved it. A got hot a sweaty. There was a big wall to climb and a rotating arm to duck and jump over. A great hour spent.

We got home for about 6pm! A nice mini break.

We descended from our Travelodge hotel to the Morrisons around the corner and ate a nice cooked breakfast. The weather wasn't great and we just missed the Ferry from Seacombe so had to wait around for an hour till the next one.

We eventually got on the very rocky Ferry and toured down the Mersey eventually ending up at Pier Head, Liverpool. There we split into two, the girls shopping and the boys shopping.

We all met up again and took the bus tour around the city. It was interesting to hear the commentary.

The Fab4 with the infamous 5

Ben and the Cavern Club

City Bus Tour

We returned on the Ferry back to Wallasey and the hotel. To chill and some ran!

Route

Ferry Across The Mersey

In the evening we ate at the local Weatherspoons. Ben embarrassed us all when he did a massive burp in front of the table next to us. We all had to apologies! After we went down the arcades in New Brighton. Lots of 2 pennies were lost to the sliding machines (not sure on their name).

Weatherspoons

New Brighton Arcades

title.value: Liverpool Day 2 - Ferry Across The Mersey, Sightseeing tour, New Brighton

info.content:
We booked up a mini break to Liverpool. We drove the 4 hour journey in the morning, stopping off at Sandbach town on the way.

We headed straight to the Williamsons Tunnels and get there just in time for a tour. We found it quite strange as we came away not really understanding why the tunnels were built. It was to flatten the land above so the rich could have flat gardens on the side of a hill. I think maybe it was to create jobs. Anyway it was a little different and kept us amused for an hour.

We headed into town and after faffing around parking the car we embarked on a walk about, first heading into the Chinese street and then into the main shopping area. The girls eyes lit up, especially finding a massive Forever 21 store.

Williamson Tunnels

Spot the piggy

Someone's on drugs

We had booked a Beatles themed, Yellow Sub Escape Rooms. Things didn't go well early doors as we couldn't even work out how to get into the place! Anyway the host was jovial enough and we were sent into the sub for 50 minutes to stop the bomb. We weren't great at it. We had a number of clues and still failed! We had fun.

Yellow Sub Escape Rooms

Route

We got some fish and chips and headed under the tunnel to the Wirral and checked in to our hotel on the front in New Brighton. The girls did some shopping, the boys headed straight back out to Anfield where Liverpool were playing Bayern Munich. They found a sneaky parking spot and walked to the ground with the fans. They circled the stadium on the slender off chance of getting in..... however, that was never going to happen. The boys settled into a pub, The Twelfth Man. We sat close to a homeless person who absolutely stank. However, we felt sorry for the man. A little less compassion was given by the locals. The game itself was pretty drab. 0-0.

Liverpool v Bayern Munich, outside the Kop

title.value: Liverpool Day 1 - Williamson Tunnels, Yellow Sub Escape Rooms, Anfield

info.content:
We went over to Gillingham today and met up with just the Burrows clan. Unfortunately Helen and Guy couldn't come because last night they were in hospital. Poor Guy has just been diagnosed with diabetes!

We had a couple of goes on the toboggan run.

Katie and Natasha tobogganing

We left late morning to go down to Portsmouth. First up was some retail therapy at Gunwarf Quays.

After we headed to Southsea and Clarence Pier to watch the hovercraft come in. We also played in the arcades.

Hovercraft landing at Clarence Pier

We met with the Elders and tried to go in and play at the Dice, the board games cafe. However, it was fully booked. This was disappointing. Instead we went to Scoops the local ice cream parlour and got ourselves some treats before returning home again.

Scoops Ice Cream parlour

In the morning Daddy and Auntie Ellie ran the Frimley Lodge parkrun. Ellie got a 5km PB! Straight after it was another Falcons v Alton Huskies, which meant another Ben v Joey match up. Falcons won 4-0, with Ben getting 2 assists.

Route

Falcons v Huskies

In the afternoon Katie and Daddy went off to Chertsey to see them play top place. They hid from Farfar and surprised him!

In Chertsey stands

Alwyns Lane

In the evening Ma Ma had organised a classical concert for Christian Aid. It was pretty boring to be honest. Daddy, Mummy, Katie and Jessica endured the 2.5 hour concert.

title.value: parkrun, Falcons v Alton, Chertsey Town, Classical concert

info.content:
Jessica was very excited to have a couple of her friends from school. She wrote them letters of what they can expect from the evening. Very sweet.

Summer, Emma and Jessica

Daddy had planned a long run to fill in the map to Loxhill. There were diggers helping de-foresting the woods. They left massive tyre marks which turned into sinking mud.

Route

Up to the calves in mud

It was pretty wet and the Falcons game consequently got called off. This allowed Daddy to go off to do parkrun. He did expectantly well running in under 25 minutes.

In the afternoon we all headed off to the Legoland Hotel in Windsor. The Elders went last year and invited us to join them this year. We arrived to find a large room for the 5 of us. The room treasure hunt was easily solved. We made use of the hotel swimming pool. All very much geared for 4-7 years old I'd say. We played lots of games in the hour we had in there.

There was a lego competition to build the best thing before 7pm. We decided on Tower Bridge and made a half decent effort. Lily wasn't feeling at all well so we decided to get the food from the restaurant and eat in the hotel room whilst playing board games. We played Codenames, Chameleon and Ticket To Ride. Ben and Katie loved playing Ticket To Ride. We finished at about 10pm and fell asleep soon after.

Legoland Hotel

Daddy took the day off and Mummy had to run in and out of work for Katie and Ben's interviews at Tomlinscote School.

First up was Katie. We reviewed her mock exam and predicted GCSE grades. They mainly ranged from a 4 to 6, which is a C to B grade. She had worked hard in the mocks. Her behaviour was good. There was some discussion over her poor Religious Studies result. She cited writing the answers down on the wrong sheet of paper. There was pressure for her to concentrate on RS. However, she disagreed as there was a reason for the poor result. She rather concentrated on English. It was a good meeting.

Ben was next with her French teacher. You could tell he was adored by her. She was very good at asking Ben to push himself one level higher and to look at what Oxford need for a politics type degree, which Ben later did do. He was asked what he wanted to do in the future. To which the reply was to be the Chancellor of the Exchequer. His foresight was admired. His report showed Excellent behaviour in class for all subjects. Ben's current choice for his 4 options are: Business Studies, French, Drama and either Sports Science or Geography.

Later in the afternoon Katie had her interview at Farnborough 6th Form. It was 10 minutes long. The interviewee was sarcastic saying that Katie was following the popular trend of taking Criminology. The other subjects Katie wants to take are: Photography and Sociology.

After the interview Katie met up with Ben in Farnborough and they went to wathc How To Train your Dragon at the cinema. Sweet.

Katie and Mummy went off for a walk around Frimley Green. Along the Hatches they heard an old lady shouting for help. She was sat in her doorway having fallen in her house earlier in the day. She was slightly deaf so it was difficult to communicate with her. Katie rushed home to get Daddy and her phone and Mummy rang 999. She was left on hold for 3 to 4 minutes before she was even answered. That's terrible!

Having got through and making checks for about 10 minutes, an ambulance was said to take up to 2 hours. The old lady wasn't able to get up too well. Daddy made conversation with her for an hour and half. By this time Mummy had gone home. Katie didn't want to go in her house because it was dirty and she was smoking. After an hour and a half, Daddy managed to sit her in a chair, and then the old lady was able to move about slowly. The phone rang and it was the ambulance service asking whether the old lady needed assistance still. She answered no. It was a tricky situation as she was unable to walk up the stairs to bed. Daddy had to help her into bed. Daddy was concerned that she would not be able to get up in the morning, so he took the front door key so he could let himself in.

In the morning Daddy popped in at 9:15. Calling up there was no response. He thought that she must be still asleep. He then went a little later, close to 11:30 and fortunately she was up and downstairs. The key was returned. She was very grateful for the help (20 The Hatches).

We left in the morning and headed to pick up Jessica who slept over at Ma Ma's. Then on to somewhere near Winchester for this 4 miler in the frozen snow. It was very crunchy under foot.

Route

Snow walk

Farley's Mount

In the afternoon Katie had her science tutor and Daddy sourced bits off ebay for the car. He got a front bumper for Â£100 and a new headlight unit for Â£30. He also got the gaffer tape up to temporarily repair the bumper.

Busy day with us all splitting up doing different things. First off Daddy went to parkrun in the snowy conditions. It was an energy sapping 27 minute run. The Frimley Flyers have now completed 5000 parkruns.

Daddy just in front of Jodie

Route

Then we split 3 ways: Jessica went with Farmor into Camberley to the sewing shop. They then went back to Farmors to do some sewing and made a camp in the front room.

Meanwhile Katie and Mummy drove over to Bluewater to try some prom dresses on. It's not until June. However, these things need to be prep'ed early. They had a nice time looking around and Katie tried a dozen or so dresses on. There were a few she liked, but waiting on some online try-outs before committing.

Katie Prom Dress Shopping

Both the Falcons and Chertsey had their games postponed, which meant the boys had a spare Saturday to go up to London. Their primary focus was the Cabinet War Rooms near St James' Park. They caught the train up to Waterloo then Charing Cross. Farfar loves telling stories and facts to Ben. A fresh audience. They hit Trafalgar Square before two contrasting eating stops. The first was a Danish bakery on Haymarket. The pastries actually tasted as if they came from Denmark and they were the same cakes. The second was a McDonalds. Ben wanted to try the new Bacon Big Mac! A short trip to Lillywhites which was tinged with disappointment as it was just a big Sports Direct!

Trafalgar Square

OFAH at the theatre

They then walked across St James' Park to the Cabinet War Rooms. There was a 30 min queue, so Ben and Daddy looked around all the treasury buildings. Somewhere Ben will work in the future? After the Â£50 entrance fee was paid, inside the war rooms they listened to audio commentary. There was a Churchill Museum as well which was very interesting. The boys ran out of time and had to skirt past the final half of the museum to get back home.

Route

Benny at the treasury

Nice one of Daddy and Ben

Cabinet War Rooms

In the evening the adults went to Danielle's, a Sicilian restaurant in Upper Hale. The children stayed at Ma Ma's and had a big snowball fight.

Danielle's

When we returned to the car which was parked on the hill by Ma Ma's house we noticed it had been hit. Someone had slid in the ice down the hill into the car. They had left an empty note. The bumper and headlight had been damaged enough for them needing to be replaced.

Jessica stayed overnight at Ma Ma's.

title.value: parkrun, Prom Dress Shopping, Sewing with Farmor, Cabinet War Rooms, Ma Ma 45th Wedding Ani Meal, Car hit

info.content: It snowed lots overnight. A chance to get the sledges out and make a snowman

Jessica competed against 11 other schools in the area at various events in Guildford. Frimley C of E won! They now proceed to the next round. Jessica was involved in 3 relay races which she won in all of them. She also had a jumping contest and a throwing the ball competition. Well done Jessica.

Jessica winning

The mighty Falcons trained as the first flakes of snow fell

Falcons Football Training in the snow

title.value: Jessica 1st Schools Athletics Day, Falcons Training

info.content:
Daddy and Ben left early for their 2nd leg of their tour of all the London football grounds within the M25. They started in Tottenham. It only took them 70 minutes to get there in Sunday morning traffic. It was a proper dodgy looking area. Not one to be visited after dark. There was a cutting strong wind. Tottenham's stadium was still not finished. Almost there. After Tottenham's poverty, they headed south towards Arsenal's, Emirates stadium. In contrast the area seemed quite attractive and affluent. They circled the stadium before reaching the busy Regent's canal. They headed south east. Daddy on navigation duty missed a turning and they headed 6 miles out of there way reaching Limehouse Basin. Whoops. They headed north again past Mile End, via a hot chocolate stop. By the time they reached West Ham's stadium they were ready to push on again. Leyton Orient's ground came quickly after. A large looking non-league ground. The final leg of the journey involved going up the River Lea. The phone ran out of charge as they reached Tottenham, they circled to stadium before reaching the car and home.

Route

Football grounds postcard

Meanwhile, whilst Mummy was running Sunday club with Jessica, Katie had her science tutoring with Paul. They went over the recent mock paper. Paul said that Katie could get a 6 mark.

In the afternoon, Daddy and Jessica went to the Arena and tackled the inflatable assault course for an hour. Jessica won the head to head battle. Daddy is just too old now! They had fun.

In the evening the Fars popped over to hand out some presents from their recent trip to Central and South America. Daddy was shattered after this weekend.

title.value: London Football Grounds Ride 2. Katie tutoring, Swimming, Fars pop over

info.content:
Katie spent last night at Catherine's with another friend. They had alcohol! Today Catherine's dad drove to London and spent Â£60 on just parking. Sounded as though they parked in the Mayfair area! They went shopping.

Meanwhile Daddy went to parkrun. He had a hypo whilst running so didn't too well. He was seeing white blobs in his eyes.

Afterwards, Ben's football. Mytchett were playing Camberley Rascals. There was a bit of bother in the previous game. Needless to say it kicked off again on the touchline and on the pitch. Loz and their management had verbals. There was also a lot of unnecessary comments and challenges made on the pitch too. Unfortunately the referee was pulled in as a favour last minute and really was too young to referee. It ended up with Loz sending a complaint in. It mistakenly got sent to the opposition. All a bit unfortunate really. Daddy kept out of it. The game ended with a 2-0 defeat. We played some nice football. Ben was battered and gutted at the end of the game.

In the afternoon Mummy took Jessica to her favourite shop, Hobbycraft. Daddy started painting the downstairs toilet. A change from brown to blue. He also took Ben to the rec to watch Loz play in the second half of Frimley Green reserves.

In the evening Daddy and Ben went to the Queen tribute band with Ma Ma, Pop Pop, Steve, Richard, Sue and Lindy. It's always nice to see and hear the old favourites being banged out. The boys ended the day exhausted.

Katie, Amelia and Catherine in London

title.value: Katie London, parkrun, Mytchett Football, painting downstair toilet, Queen Tribute band

info.content:
As part of Katie's GCSE History she is studying the Norman invasion. As part of this she has learnt about Pevensey Castle. We decided to pay a little visit to see whats left. Daddy took the audio guide. The rest of us just walked about. It was pretty cool.

Mood shot

Pevensey Castle wall

Pevensey Castle first floor

After Dad took us on a walk around the castle, much to our despair, we drove down to Pevensey Bay where Katie did some of her GCSE Photography cousework. She took some pictures into the mirror. Who knows?

Pevensey Bay - mirror mirror

A time for reflection

We quickly moved and got a Shakeaway in town. Jessicas combo of raspberries and strawberries was to die for! We then up to Beachy Head for another little tour around. The skies were blue and beautiful.

Mucking around at Beachy Head

Beachy Heads

Lighthouse 1

Lighthouse 2

A little tired, we went home.... and then almost straight out again over to Ma Ma and Pop Pops. Jessica was tutored by Ma Ma as she had her SATs next week. Daddy went for a 5 mile run through Farnham Park and Mummy watched a cartoon on the TV with Pop Pop.

title.value: Eastbounrne Weekend: Pevensey Castle, Pevensey Bay, Beachy Head. Jessicas tutoring at Ma Ma's

info.content:
In the morning Daddy ran parkrun at Frimley Lodge park in a semi respectable time of 25 minutes. He then had to pick Ben up and dash to football.

We were the home team, however playing at King George V. We had to net the goals and move them into position. There was a good response for the call out for helpers. The boys were eager as this was an important game to win. We played Badshot Lea earlier in the season and lost. If we beat them we'd go third. We started with possibly our strongest 11. We had 5 subs.

We went 1-0 down and 2-1 down. However, we pulled it around. It was very gratifying to see from a coaches point of view. The boys came of age. We saw new things, including:

  • Abe the captain barking orders out and telling Oli W off for not clearing the ball in a vulnerable position. Not in a nasty way. In a way a captain should.
  • Oli S making sliding tackles (not seen that commitment before).
  • A number of players heading the balls strongly. Not been scared to head. Headers directly from a goal kick. Something we've been wanting as coaches for a long time... previously they be too scared to head the ball. We had been working on this in training.
  • It's ok to pass backwards. We passed back to retain possession when there was nothing available forwards.

We then got home, gulped some lunch and headed to Hsatings and the True Crime Museum. Something Katie was interested in seeing. As we parked up and got out of the car, a homeless man spotted that Jessica has dropped her headphones. We took pity on him especially as it was so cold.

The True Crime Museum was relatively small. It cost us Â£30 to get in. There were lots of boards explaining some really gruesome murders. We all enjoyed it for the 1.5 hours in there.

Jessica really looking the part of a crim

Villans

Katie looking beautiful

We walked along the beach for a bit. Jessica and Katie were doing lots of posing photo shots. It was freezing!

Hastings Posers

We decided to go into a coffee shop for some warm drinks and scones. We decided to buy the homeless man a cup of tea and a doughnut. However, when we returned to the car he had gone. We looked around the area and couldn't see him.

We headed off towards Eastbourne. Stepped out to get some fish and chips and ate them near Eastbourne Pier. We went back to the Premier Inn for a bath and watch TV.

Eastbourne Front Fish and Chips

title.value: Eastbourne Weekend: True Crime Museum, parkrun, Falcons win

info.content:
Ben and Daddy met up with Charlotte and Loz in Kensington on this crisp, clear Sunday morning. Daddy had made a 13 mile route that took in some of London's landmarks:

  • Start at Olympia (kensington) - Free parking!!
  • Hyde Park (Kensington Palace, Prince Albert memorial, Royal Albert Hall, Diana memorial fountain, Serpentine)
  • Park Lane and Mayfair (posh area on Monopoly, The Dorchester Hotel, Berkeley Square)
  • Oxford Street (shops, shops, shops. Oxford Circus)
  • Chancery Lane
  • Temple
  • Embankment (River Thames, London Eye)

    Embankment

  • Westminster (Parliament, Abbey, Whitehall, Downing Street)

    Houses Of Parliament

    Westminster Abbey

  • Trafalgar Square
  • The Mall (St James Park, Green Park Buckingham Palace)

    Buckingham House

  • Knightsbridge (Harrods)
  • Natural History Museum + V and A Museum
  • Earls Court
Route

Daddy squeezed in a parkrun, this time both Ellie and Charlotte ran too. Ellie got a PB at 26:21, and Char came in at 31:33. Daddy ran hard and just got under 25 minutes.

Straight after the Falcons were playing Hart Tornados. Hart were bottom and got thumped most weeks. However, we started off slowly and only managed to be 1-0 up at half time. Ben started off as sub because he has been having some knee pain in the past week. The second half was a lot different and we managed to run out 8-0 winners. Mummy came to watch for a bit.

Church New Party

In the evening Daddy went down to Southsea and a bar called Dice. It was designed for board gamers. For Â£4 each, you could pick any of the hundreds of board games out and play it. Daddy, Ellie, Michael, Pop Pop and Lucy all went. They played Ticket To Ride, Code Names and a couple of other games. It was a late return home.

Board gamers

title.value: parkrun, Falcons 8v0 Hart, Church New Year Party, Board Game Cafe

info.content:
The girls came back fairly early from their sleepover with Ma Ma and Pop Pop.

In the afternoon Barrie left for home, whilst Ben and Mummy went to Bracknell cinema and saw Aquaman. They enjoyed it.

The Christmas decorations came down and Daddy did lots of DIY, including getting Jessica's shelves up.

In the evening the Fars popped over for a cup of tea. Later we all sat down and watched James Bond - The Living Daylights. We weren't convinced with Timothy Dalton.

A busy day for the boys starting with a 9am meet in Hindhead for the match against Beacon Hill Sparks. Despite winning 7-0, it wasn't a great performance. Ben had injured his leg at cross country in PE at school. I think he may have aggravated it and made it worse.

Meanwhile Mummy took delivery of our new dishwasher. The old one was 15 years old and wasn't functioning too well.

Barrie came over to spend the day with us. Daddy, Ben, Katie and Barrie went over to Chertsey for their big match against St Austell in the FA Vase 4th round. Close to 500 people there. Katie was helping in the tea bar. Even Graham turned up to watch. He seemed as he really enjoy the match. It helped with a 5-0 scoreline.

In the evening Jessica and Katie went over to Ma Ma and Pop Pops to watch a film and sleepover. Lily and Toby also were sleeping over.

Meanwhile Daddy went to the Prince Of Wales with Barrie, Michael, Phil, Nick, Martin and Steve. It was the postponed Christmas drinks. The boys had a good laugh. Barrie came back and stayed the night.

title.value: Falcons score 7, Chertsey score 5. Sleepover at Ma Ma and Pops. Boys night out

info.content:
With a house full of children, Daddy tipped toed out and ran Rushmoor parkrun.... then ran to Frimley Lodge and did their parkrun, then ran home! About 11 miles in total.

Route

In the afternoon we went out to the north of Newbury, into horse racing stables territory and walked in the hills of West Ilsley. Very nice to get away from it all with just the 5 of us.

Route

Race Horses in West Ilsley

105 Walkers

In the morning Daddy and Ben went to their favourite London carpark, Gunnersbury Park. From there they started a 18 mile tour of West London's entertainment centres. Ben was on a navigation as well as biking on the London roads. Only once did he swerve right in front of Daddy almost causing a collision in the road! The boys took in Brentford FC, Fulham FC, Chelsea FC, Earls Court, Olympia, Shepherds Bush Empire and QPR. Ben loved it and wants to do some more London landmark based bike rides.

London Bike Tour

Route

In the evening we had the Elders over for a traditional New Years Eve party..... with the usual party games. Boys v Girls. Toby, Lily and Joey all stayed over which was nice.

News Years Girls

title.value: West London Football Ground tour, New Years with Elders

info.content:
This year there were 20 of us attending the Yvonne Arnaud theatre in Guildford. The theatre was one of the best. Great view, big stage and circular. A theatre has to be circular to be proper!

Cinderella

We all enjoyed the performance.

In the morning Daddy went to Langley to do the Black Park parkrun. There were over 800 runners on a relatively narrow pathway. It took a kilometer to get over the traffic. The last 4km were all sub 5 minutes which is the goal these days.

Later in the afternoon we had a visit from the Sanders crew. We've not met up since last Easter. We swapped presents. The Sanders got us a lovely game called Get A Grip - we decided to play it. You wrap a glove around your hands which restricts your thumb. Then there were a series of rapidough, titles and physical challenges. It was good fun to play. Ma Ma and Pop Pop popped in for a cuppa too.

Jessica's long term friend Imogen came for a sleepover. The girls played with all the children in and out of the conservatory. Being locked in! They played Minecraft on the PS4 too.

Playing Get A Grip

title.value: Black Park parkrun, Sanders Over, Imogen Sleepover

info.content:
Us three children had over Â£100 each given over Christmas and so we felt the need to spend.... and spend big in London. Katie was brave enough to travel the tube from Acton Town to Leicester Square.

At Leicester square we saw the big cinemas, where our favourite, Capital Radio was produced and went into M and Ms World. Massive it was.

Capital Radio, Leicester Square

M and M's World

We then headed via China town and Soho up to Oxford Street where we did a lot of shopping. Ben came back with some new Nike Huarache's and a t-shirt. Jessica came back with a Lush Bath Bomb and an Umbrella. Katie bought some shorts and a big, white jacket.

Entering China Town

Daddy of course found somewhere free to park but got scared the Gunnersbury park gates would shut. So after getting off the bus at Acton Green, he ran 2.5km to get the car and collect us. A long day out deserved a fish and chip supper.

In the late afternoon we headed over to the Elders for the usual fun and games with the Barnett family. There were lots of games contributions mainly from Ma Ma and Eva this year.

Boxing Day Family Games

Ben stayed at the Elders, whilst Lily came over to us.

title.value: Boxing Day, Ben and Lily sleepover swap

info.content:
It was a 6am for us. We clambered into Ben's bedroom to see what Father Christmas had left behind. There were 17 presents. Katie's main presents were here pink watch and a Calvin Klein handbag. Ben got a Man Utd top and a boxing punch bag and gloves. Jessica got a manikin and an IPhone 6. We then when into Mummy and Daddy's room to watch them open presents from each other. Mummy got a coat, dress and a jumper. Daddy got a jumper, a t-shirt and a lot of food stuff.

6am start for the opening of FC's presents

We then headed downstairs to open presents from friends.... which was nice.

We got to the Fars for 9:30am for some breakfast and our traditional game of Coppit. Daddy won!

Christmas Breakfast

we returned home for 30 mins whilst Mummy made up some of the Children's Christmas dinner. Auntie Ellie was doing the other half. It was nice and a bit different this year as it was the first time not spent in Istead Rise. The adults also ate, Daddy of course doing his impression of Henry VIII with his massive turkey leg.

Children's Christmas Meal

The post lunch walk was only attended by half the crew. It was a nice walk around Caesars Camp with Lenny.

Route

Grandma joined us this year for the festivities which was nice to see. She sat on the sofa soaking in everyone elses enjoyment. She did very well to keep with it all the way till 9pm.

Philip and Emma also came to see us Children open our presents.

Present opening at the Westons

The adults were next opening their presents. After we had a game of Articulate we collapsed and watched a bit of Michael McIntyre before heading home.

Daddy worked in the morning while the rest of us got on with doing bits and pieces around the house. Jessica made a gingerbread house.

At about 3:30pm we got to the Fars and started straight away with a Treasure Hunt around the Tomlinscote estate devised by Farfar. It was a little easier than last year and Farfar used WhatsApp. A first? Despite that it was felt better if the clues were written on paper on the course. Tough crowd. Each of us won Â£5 each.

Auntie Susan and Graham arrived and we started eating a little after 5:15pm, of course a traditional Danish affair.... except that is us kiddies. We had the usual butchers sausages!

Danish Christmas Meal

After Daddy won the Risalamande challenge, we played the dice game had a boys vs girls quiz and then on to the main event that is the present opening.

Opening presents at the Fars

In the morning Mummy went to church and watched a nativity play.

After lunch we ventured out into the mild, Berkshire air to complete walk 104, Thatcham Lakes. It was nice. Not much resistance from the troops. Only Ben complaining about the amount of time it would take to get there and back. Daddy had lovely chats with Katie and Ben. Jessica is just a fruit loop.

Thatham Lakes walk

Don't mess with this lot

Route

After returning home we had a family game of Risk. Ben won!

In the evening Daddy went for a run and then watched Watership Down with Mummy. They both almost cried. Mummy not feeling too well at the moment with a sore throat. We are all very excited for tomorrow.

Daddy went off to do Brooklands parkrun this morning and ran his fastest since May 2016, 24:06 minutes. So he was well happy and celebrated with a cuppa down the canal cafe.

Meanwhile, Farmor had both Katie and Jessica over for Christmas cooking. They cooked giffler, vaniljekranse and as Katie calls them, brown cakes and a bakewell tart! Lovely. Jessica also managed to finish sewing her "I Love You" cushion for Mummy.

In the mid afternoon they were picked up by Ma Ma and taken over to Farnborough cinema where they met with Lily to watch the latest carnation of Mary Poppins.

Mummy, Daddy and Ben went over to Mercedes Benz World over in Brooklands (again Daddy!). A place we've surprisingly not been before. There were three floors of cars and history..... as well as a few interactive things. One was a remote control car game. 10 lined up on the grid. Daddy came 4th and Ben 2nd.... although Daddy did get 2nd fastest lap!

Daddy and Ben went on a 4x4 experience where a driver took the pair around a steep gradient off road course. Ben was on the brakes for a 60% decline..... which ended in them sliding down the hill! Ben loved it. They also saw a car race display. It was a really nice chilled afternoon.

Mercedes Benz World

Mummy and Daddy in front of their car

The World Championship winning F1 car

In the evening we all watched Jingle All The Way!

title.value: Mercedes Benz World, Farmor Cooking, Ma Ma Mary Poppins

info.content:
Daddy was let out at 3pm, whilst us three for relieved from school yesterday. Katie had spent most of today doing her Maths homework. It took her ages, but at least she has done it now.

Each year we have a family meal out. This time around we headed to Frankie and Benny's in Aldershot. We all had a go on the kids game sheet! We had a lovely meal.

Frankie and Benny's Christmas Meal out

Mummy and Daddy went out to the Highlight Christmas Meal at the Giggling Squid in Farnham. Same place as last year. We sat opposite Anthony and his wife, Rachel which was very nice. The food was too spicy for Daddy. They had a good time. KBJ were left to themselves.

Daddy and Mummy pre going out

In the afternoon Farmor and Susan took Jessica to a pottery shop where you could make pottery pieces and collect them a week or so later.

Jessica and Farmor pottering

The Potters

title.value: Jessica Pottery making with Farmor and Susan

info.content:
The football was very touch and go this morning. The ref delayed the start and eventually we asked the parents if they accepted a few icey patches on the pitch. We had spent half an hour travelling and almost an hour waiting around, so the resounding response was yes - crack on. Just three weeks previous the two sides met in Mytchett and the scoreline was 2-2. Today was a different story, 8 - 0 to Mytchett. Ben even scored an overhead bicycle kick. Not that I want to take anything away from Ben, it was just a yard out in a goalmouth melee and he hooked the ball over his head as he was falling. Still it was a second goal within a month. Daddy was well pleased, especially as Ben, Abe, Kevon and Ben H all scored! Joey wasn't too gutted at the result. After stopping for a cup of tea with the Elders, they returned home with Joey.

Meanwhile Mummy went with Ma Ma to Cedar Lodge and Holly Lodge to sing with the church to the old people.

In the early afternoon Katie was dropped into Camberley with a few friends. It was kind of a date with Dan who bought her cinema ticket. She watched Spiderman into the Spider-verse. She had a nice time and we gave Dan a lift back home. Katie was all excited and confused. Nothing will come of Dan we suspect.

In the evening we had the traditional Gay's Christmas Party which we hosted. This year we invited just the Elders, Maisey's and West's - no Julie. Mummy made most of the games up which included of course; spoons, titles, give us a clue, a bush tucker trial of a sprout smoothie, the electrocution game and Linkee. Daddy roasted a pork on the BBQ and boiled a gammon up. The food went down well. It was good fun. Proceeding finished at about 10:30. Ellie, Joey and Lily stayed over.

A packed day with the weather looking decidedly dodgy putting pay to Ben's football match.

Instead Daddy could attend parkrun and Chris's 250th attempt and the cafÃ© after.

Chris Peddle's 250th parkrun

Katie had left the night before to go down to Summer's. They went shopping at Bluewater then stayed in a Premier Inn just the two of them. Summer has here first boyfriend. They spent lots of money getting Christmas presents.

Katie and Summer's shopping haul

Jessica doing Aerial acrobatics

Mummy, Daddy, Ben and Ma Ma went down to Bournemouth. They were going to help the Maisey's to move to their new house in Springbourne. They hadn't completed, but were allowed to move stuff across. However, the estate agent was not too forthcoming with the keys. Mummy and Daddy went in to the town while they waited to look about.

We got the keys, and started unloading a van load of stuff. The house was in need of a lot of decoration. It's has a lot of 1950's hallmarks. There was a lot of potential. Loz is going to have his hands full for many months to come.

After some fish and chips and unloading a second load, we all headed into town and the Christmas Tree walk. It was mainly situated in the Winter Gardens. Some massive trees with beautiful lights. We tried to go ice skating but it was all booked up. We went for a bit of aprÃ¨s ski in one of the temporary ski huts. Mulled wine. Warms the old cockles.

We headed back to the car via the upside down house. A very nice trip out.

Christmas Tree walk in Bournemouth

The boys continued on the bikes and went into the adjoining woods. It was quite wet. Ben slipped over whilst pushing his bike up a hill!

Route

Ben MTBing at back of Dettingen Park

Later Daddy and Ben went to the Restaurant at the Packhouse for the Frimley Flyers meal. James made a number of speeches. After 3 hours we only had the main course. We had to skip the deserts. Daddy stood up and made a speech about next years events.

The weather has been terrible which cost Falcons their fixture this morning. This allowed Daddy to go to parkrun and even a trip to the cafÃ© afterwards.

After lunch we had planned to go to the cinema and watch the new Harry Potter film and Grinch 2. Due to the weather everyone else had the same idea, and the films were booked up. Daddy and Jess then tried the bowling alley. That too was booked up.

We all returned home and we made a Bingo Christmas card game. We each drew 20 Christmas items and placed them on a bingo card. Each time we open a Christmas card any items that match our bingo cards gets crossed off!

Whilst mummy watch Strictly, Katie went to Kian's 16th birthday house party. There was alcohol involved! Daddy, Jessica and Ben went over to the Fars and played Coppit. Ben won!

Playing Coppit with the Fars

info.content:
In the morning Daddy went to parkrun at Frimley Lodge park. First time in a long while. After, still at Frimley Lodge was the big match, Falcons v Alton Huskies. It was a fiercely contested match with Alton taking the lead in the first half, with Tyler equalizing. Joey was making some last ditch tackles in the heart of the Huskies defence. Ben was battling in the centre of midfield. Both had battle wounds at the end of the game. In the second half Alton regained the lead with some dodgy keeping from Cam. Ben popped up later from a corner, used his physical presence (i.e. fouled 2 players) whic allowed him to scramble in an equalizer. Late in the game, Tyler was through 1 on 1 with the keeper and Joey miss-timed his tackle and wiped the Falcons forward out. Joey was booked. The first time we've ever seen a player booked in Ben's football! A proud moment. The game ended 2-2.

Auntie Charlotte had just had her eggs implanted into her, so she had to take it easy. For some reason she thought it would be relaxing around ours so we were happy she stayed the day with us..... along with Len Dog.

The girls made a camp in the lounge and lay and watched films in the afternoon. One was Polar Express. Very relaxing. Later on in the afternoon Jessica's acting academy had an awards evening coupled with 10 acting and singing scenes. Jessica had one to do, but we were very disappointed that it got cancelled last minute as they couldn't find the music. To make up for this Jessica was called out and won a certificate for being a helpful and good member of her class. Well done Jessa.

Jessica's Acting Certificate

New carpets

Biking near an explosives depot

After lunch, we departed for walk 103. Katie stayed at home to do some revision and because she lost 0.5kg last week which is not good for her anorexia. Exercise, albeit a walk, wouldn't help. info.content:
Last day and we packed up our bikes and tided up. Daddy went for a quick run. It was hilly and slow. There was nothing left in the legs.

There was a bit of a panic at the house, we couldn't find the second set of keys. We must have spent an hour looking for them, emptying bags, looking all around the house. Fingers were being pointed. In the end Michael had them in one of his bike bags!

The trip back was good. We all went to Gatwick to meet Daddy. As Daddy travelled between the customs and the doors to the outside world he dropped his green bag and lost it! Dipstick.

The weather was terrible and we had some bike issues to sort. Daddy needed brake blocks and a tyre, Tim needed a new front wheel. Eventually we got going up to the peak of Tiede, attempting to get above the rain clouds. Robin had decided to leave earlier and bike up in the rain. Nutter! We caught him three quatres of the way up. He was very wet and cold and welcomed seeing the rest.

Once on top, the boys were just above the rain clouds. They headed off on a 'there and back' sortie, going via the cafe for a spot of lunch. It was beautiful up top and they stuck largely together.

Heading north towards Tiede

Beautiful straight road to Tiede

What a bunch

Route

In the evening they went to the same Restaurant as 3 days previous. Big portions and a lovely meal.

Evening meal at Restaurant

title.value: Teneriffe Biking Day 4 - El Tiede, Ride on top

info.content:
After yesterdays efforts we all wanted something a little less demanding. Another of the routes was the iconic TF12 looping north of Santa Cruz. It was another 1200 metre total climb. There was some stunning scenery on this peninsula. At points looking left we could see the dramatic southern coast, to the right the north coast. We reached the top at El Bailadero however there were no cafes here. A very chirpy girl pointed us in the direction westwards. Daddy set off first, keen to be first for once. However, he raced down the hill on the wrong side of the road. The boys were shouting to get on the right side of the road. However, it fell on deaf ears. Daddy rounded the corner downhill at speed and thought what on earth is that car doing on the wrong side of the road coming quickly towards him. Daddy skidded, the backend of the bike going sideways for a bit. A change of underpants later and he somehow managed to avoid the car!

Some lovely scenery climbing TF12

Hills!

Finally they found a great cafe stop called Casa Santiago and ate Tappas. Almost at the top now and again they split up, leaving Daddy trailing behind..... and bang! Puncture going down the hill. Not only that the same 'valve' problem as before at London Ride 100. The pump kept unscrewing the valve. This was exhausting work. Finally Daddy managed to get going again. Everyone else was waiting a while. Another two miles on. Bang! Not again! A second puncture. He almost threw the bike in the bushes. He cut through some slippery rocks having gone off road attempting to reach the others. Michael took a look and noticed that the brakes block had been scraping against the tyre sidewall and created holes! A boot was made, a second change of innertube and the boys were off and running again.

Second puncture repair

It was all downhill from here and they all stuck together going through the city centre and final stretch of flat where Daddy could confidently put some power down and wasn't last! The finish line was crossed and they collapsed into a beach side bar overlooking the Atlantic Ocean.

Finished and a well earned beer in the bar on the beach

In the evening Bazza made us all a Spag Bol and we all played Killer pool.

Route

title.value: Teneriffe Biking Day 3 - Santa Cruz TF12

info.content:
A lovely sunny day, 22 degrees. A suggested route we decided to follow was the Bradley Wiggins trail from Los Christianos to the top of Tiede, around 2300 metres above sea level. Los Christianos was on the other side of the island. We decided to start by the beach so we were at sea level to begin with. After a bit of a mishap at the start with directions, we crossed north of the TF1 and ascended up Tiede which was the focal point of the whole island.

At the beginning in Los Christianos

Daddy really struggled compared to the others. After just 8 miles he was ready to quit, only a quatre of the way up. Michael had an injury and was taking it easy, so went up with Daddy. They stopped off half way up at Vilaflor for a baguette, coffee and coke and replenish water. The others had nearly reached the top by this point!

At 2200, by the Tiede national park plaque, Michael decided to turn around and head back to the start point to pick up the van. Daddy was determined to continue to the top and continue onto the other side of the volcano.

Reached Tiede park, near the top

Made it Tiede in the background

Reaching the cable cars by the volcano took a lot longer than expected. Five and half hours predominantly in first gear (28 cassette). The final 3 miles had quite an ascent. Daddy was still going up hill after the cable cars. Dusk was forming. The views were amazing. Some sand dunes, strange rock formations and a dried lava river. Fantastic. The light was drawing in quick and as the sun descended and the shadows grew, the temperature dropped as Daddy started his descent down the north side. Cars had there lights on, Daddy unfortunately had no front light and the back had run out of battery. However, not a problem in the semi light, Daddy descended at a steady pace. Within the next mile or two, close to Portillo Alto, the skies were clear and the moon could be seen clearly. Still enough to descend. Now the rocky landscape changed to pine trees lining the roads. This meant what little light there was had now gone. Daddy was freezing, especially on the hands. He was shivering so much it slowed him down as his bike wobbled down the hill. With no light Daddy chose to use the maps on his phone to know when a bend was coming up. Fortunately most of the traffic had gone, but there was still the odd car coming down the mountain. Whenever car lights were seen from behind, Daddy thought it best to stop and go into the side of the road. Daddy had managed to descend about 1000 metres like this.

It's getting darker. I can see the moon

Another car came from behind quite quick and Daddy went to the side of the road on a bend. However, he couldn't see the side of the road and misjudged it. He rode into the gutter \ ditch. He fell off into the gutter, his bike ended on the road, on the bend. Fortunately the car behind swerved around it, the car following also managed to somehow miss it! Daddy picked himself up, brushed himself down. He sustained a bruised elbow and a small cut to the knee. The bike however had a buckled wheel and was un-rideable.

As there was no place to stop, the two cars went 50 yards down the road and then stopped. Both drivers spoke to each other in English. Daddy could hear that they were saying I was stupid for riding down a mountain with no lights.The second was accusing the first of hitting Daddy! Daddy assured them it was his fault and apologised profusely. They both offered to take Daddy down the mountain in the car. Daddy had already international rescue, aka Michael to pick him up. The first driver who was a German tourist offered to take Daddy back to the villa with the bike. A little taken aback from his generosity, Daddy politely refused and urged him to continue on his travels. Michael was an hour away. The German tourist insisted in staying until Michael arrived. He left his car lights on so Michael could see where we were. After conversations about WWII, Brexit and the car industry, he noticed that the car lights dimmed. He tried starting his car, but all that was heard was tick, tick, tick! Oh no. His battery was now flat.

The obvious solution was to push start the car, but both were unsure. What happens if that was not the problem and the car was pushed down the mountain in the pitch black, little on the brakes (servos no power) and no place to rest up if it didn't work. With Daddy's luck he envisaged pushing the German off the mountain to his death!

Michael arrived and with some convincing the car was bump started and all was good. The adventure was over. Goodbyes were said. Michael laughed at Daddy.

Route

Corner I crashed at on the right, but in the pitch black

The boys drove down the mountain into Puerto De La Cruz to pick up the others. Barrie, Nick and Phil had been drinking since midday. They were hammered.

Daddy, Michael, Nick, Phil, Barrie, Steve (Alton), Tim (Alton) and Robin (Alton) all went off to Teneriffe for a few days of cycling. The plane took off late from Gatwick, there were queues at passport control at Teneriffe and a long car journey to the north of the island all meant there was not enough time to do any riding today.

The villa was massive with a swimming pool. Daddy and Michael shared a room together. It was situated just outside RincÃ³n, near Puerto de la Cruz.

View from the villa up to Tiede

Jessica was chosen to be included in the Frimley C of E cross country team. All schools in Surrey Heath were represented. Jessica finished the 2.5km course in 36th place out of 72 runners. Well done Jessica you did very well.

Jessica racing at Lightwater Country Park

Farmor teaching us to make Aebleskiver

There were narrow lanes and mummy got road rage at this old couple in a fat 4x4..... from the back seat. Calm down dear! We headed off on the 2.5 mile adventure. The weather was good and we strolled through the woods.

Route

info.content:
Ben and Jessica went out with Yuv and Amerette knocking on doors. They went to a really house in Mytchett where you had to queue up to get into the haunted house.

Scary Ben

Ben was desperate to go to the Fright Night at Thorpe Park. He loved it there. He went with Yuv and Oli whose birthday treat it was.

Ben at Fright Night

We took Summer back to Gravesend. On the way Daddy did a very hilly Lullingstone parkrun in the beautiful hills.

Daddy at Lullingstone parkrun

We popped in at the Teales for a cuppa before making our way down to the Cyclo park. Daddy forgot the helmets! Daddy took all 5 children around the mountain bike course. Then Ben, Jess and Daddy had time trial races around the tarmac surface.

Jessica lining up for a time trial at the Cyclo Park

Jessica went over to the Teales, whilst Summer came here. Ben, Katie and Summer went to Thorpe Park.

Katie and Summer and Thorpe Park
Broadditch Farm haunted house

Our travel back day. We headed off straight after breakfast. We passed through Wrexham. Daddy therefore had to seek the football ground and have a mooch around. Close by was Pontcysllte Aquaduct which we walked along. It was pretty high up and pretty windy. Scary stuff.

Pontcysllte Aquaduct Route

On Pontcysllte Aquaduct

Pontcysllte Aquaduct walk

We moved on down the River Dee down to Llangollen which was a pretty village and stopped for some lunch and again a walk around town. It had a fantastic bakers shop.

Llangollen

We made it home mid afternoon. Lovely few days.

We had a nice cooked breakfast before snaking our way through the picturesque route to Betws-y-Coed and Go Below. Here we had booked in to go on an adventure trip around Penmachono Slate mines which ran for 200 years. We kitted up in wellies and a hard hat and caught a mini bus, southwards. The site was close to Ffestiniog. The slate was also quarried at this site. We could see the rejected slate. We climbed up on the slate, then through the most beautiful wood ever. It was thick with trees, ladened with moss on the trunk. It was almost eerie as we climbed a kilometer or so to one of the modest entrances to the mine. Last wee stop for a few hours!

We entered the mine. Glad we had wellies on as the ground was a mix of puddles and a running stream. We continued to climb and got to a chamber filled with water. The only way to the next stage was to get in the rubber dinghy and paddle across. The guide told us all we needed to know about the slate mine. We had a number of other elements to tackle during our 3 hour stint under ground including: zip wire, abseil and plenty of rock climbs. Interestingly enough we were told to be careful when we stopped for lunch as any crumbs created would turn into lumps of penicillin. There is nothing else to take the debris out of the cave! We finally climbed up a 80 foot ladder back to the surface near to the top of the mine. A great experience in a beautiful part of the country.

Not very accurate Route

The woods where the mine entrance was

Underground boating lake

Rope climbing

Underground abseiling

Out and concerned!

We got back to Rhuddlan and decided to walk to the Castle and mucked about there for a bit. There was a lovely sunset. Opposite our hotel was an American Diner place where we stopped off and ate too much!

Rhuddlan Castle with a lovely sunset

Rhuddlan Castle

info.content:
We awoke in Holyhead Travelodge, picked up some breakfast at McDonalds and the local supermarket for those that were a little more health conscious. The weather was turning. Within an hour the rain was coming in sideways. We first headed to Parys Mountain, a copper mine. Due to the weather we were the only ones there. It was an interesting walk. We headed towards the tower, crossed the high bridge and looked at the bleak landscape.

Parys Mountain Route

Parys Mountain

A little further around the coast was Llanbadrig, just north of the most northerly village in Wales! Again another walk in blustery, but dry conditions. We saw a dead fox. Daddy and Katie continued on the walk to the head. We again headed off towards a cafe highly rated on Trip Advisor. It was closed. Closed till Easter!

Llanbadrig Route

Llanbadrig

Llanbadrig

After the dissapointment of not getting food at the cafe, Daddy looked up Trip Advisor and found Pete's Burger Bar... we travelled there only to find it was a burger van! We all laughed at Daddy. Thankfully just down the road was the Bull pub who were doing a Sunday Carvery. Yum.

After our fill, we headed for our third mini walk of the day at a 5,000 year old Burial Chamber in Bryn Celli Ddu. We had fun running up and down the hill, which I guess isn't too respectful. We had fun.

Neolithic Burial Chamber Route

Bryn Celli Ddu Burial Chamber

Within 8 miles was Newborough Beach. A huge stretch of sand with a spit of land reaching out in to the Irish Sea. It was quite picturesque especially with the sky. First dark and cloudy, eventually the sun won through and gave us some nice pictures. Katie and Daddy walked a fair way until Daddy got a hypo so they turned back. Meanwhile Jessica and Ben were playing secret agents.

Newborough Beach Out Route

Newborough Beach

Newborough Beach

Newborough Beach

Newborough Beach

Newborough Beach

Newborough Beach

We headed to Rhuddlan for our next hotel, a Premier Inn. Whilst Mummy watched the Strictly results, Daddy went out for a run around the village.

Rhuddlan Run Route

info.content:
In the morning Daddy did parkrun, then the Falcons lost 9-2 to a strong Windlesham side. We went down to a bare 11 men. Ben really played well, getting stuck in with some tough sliding tackles.He won Man Of The Match. Well done Ben.

We then travelled on the long journey north up to Wales. We stopped off a few times, but reached Holyhead in about 6 hours. We got Fish and Chips and sat on the quayside and saw the ferries which travel to Dublin.

Fish and Chips on Holyhead quayside

Katie had a photography project. She needed some family members and a gloomy beach.

Ben, Daddy, Jess at Southsea beach in the rain

Southsea beach

In the afternoon, us girls went to Camberley shopping.

Katie going to the party

info.content:
Katie and Jess stayed in the car from 5pm till 11am the next morning.

Katie and Jess in the car

In the morning, Daddy went off for a bike ride. This time wanting to ride the A331 and the Hogs Back. Mummy went to church. Katie had her second tutoring session, this time on Chemistry.

Farfar popped around and played with Jessica, Ben and Daddy in a game of Hotel.

In the afternoon we chilled out and later Ben and Katie went to Church Youth Group.

Last night Katie went for a sleepover at Summer's. So we went to collect Katie from Guildford later in the day.

In the morning, after Mummy and Daddy's flu jab, Ben and Daddy went off to Windlesham for a match. They were far better than us. Daddy was on his own as Loz was away. It was also Silent Weekend, so no coaching during the match. We ran out 8-3 losers. It tipped it down by the end of the game.

Later, Mummy and Jessica went into Camberley to do some shopping.

Mummy came to collect us from Bournemouth.

Daddy was waiting for the Russian to turn up for him to be told he can't take the bike away! Daddy put his motorbike on Autotrader at Â£750, listing all the problems with it. The most severe was an oil leak. On Thursday he got a phone call from a Russian chap (Russian 1) wanting to come down from Leicester to see it. He arrived after football training in the dark. He could barely speak English. So bad, Daddy had to send the house postcode by text. The Russian brought his friend along (spoke equally as badly) who almost drove it through next door's front window. They were obviously concerned about the oil leak, but they really didn't have a clue about motorbikes. They liked the bike and offered Â£700 which Daddy accepted. They paid a Â£300 deposit and said he'll be back on Sunday morning (today) to collect it.

Friday came along and a short email message came through from a chap called Dimitri asking if I knew where the oil leak was. Daddy replied no, and the chap asked to see the bike that evening. Daddy thought it was Russian 1, given the name 'Dimitri' just wanting a closer look at that oil leak. Dimitri emailed to say he's had a job cancelled in Watford and he come down. Bearing in mind this was Friday night rush hour, he must have spent an hour and a half getting from Watford. He arrived and Daddy soon realized Dimitri was not the same person as Russian 1. Massive dilemma. Does he tell this new chap that there is a mistake in identity. Daddy couldn't do this so explicitly seeing he had traveled so far. Daddy's tactic was to exaggerate the oil leak and all the other faults. He did such a bad job that Dimitri offered the full amount and could pay for it all right now! Arrrgghhh. Daddy couldn't say no - what excuse could he have given? So the paper work was done, the only proviso was that he couldn't take the bike away till Monday, during the daytime. So Daddy gave him the keys to the motorbike so he could just ride off.

Daddy then frantically tried to get hold of Russian 1 to say the deal was off. Citing a problem in Daddy's new bike, therefore needing his old bike. Over a dozen calls and texts were sent during the Saturday and Sunday and no reply.

Daddy was very nervous. What if Russian 1 just turned up, having not read any of the messages, seeing the motorbike in driveway and wondering why he couldn't drive it away. Fortunately, he didn't turn up. Not a peep. Perhaps he'd forgotten.

In the end Russian 1 contacted Daddy a few days later, and was ok about the situation. It then took another week for the deposit money to be returned as there was an issue with receiving SMS texts from him. Daddy feels he got away with that one.

The silver bullet has got to go

Katie has been struggling with science at school, which is partially at the fault of the school and their bad teachers. The tutor, said he tutors many from Tomlinscote! Katie found it rewarding. He charges Â£35 for the hour.

In the afternoon Jessica really wanted to go Banger racing over in Aldershot. They saw hot rods and caravan Bangers. There were only 4 caravans and they raced in a figure of 8!

Caravan Banger Racing at Aldershot

info.content:

He even went to bed slightly earlier to be fresh for today! The game was physical from the opposition. There was a little bit of needle. We suffered as a result, many of the boys not liking it and not really wanting to play. Part of the managers were thinking the boys have got to get used to this treatment. Some parents really didn't like it. In the end we ended up losing 2-0.

After a speedy lunch we headed down to Bournemouth to see Charlotte. Once the Elders arrived we headed into town to get a Shakeaway. It took forever, but well worth it.. Mummy and Daddy headed home after and we stayed with our cousins and Auntie Charlotte. We played games; code words and linky. We watched Shrek and went to bed at gone 1am!

info.content:
A busy morning starting off with Daddy running his 250th parkrun (or is it 251st, eh James?). It was nice to see all the well wishers. Daddy ran with Loz to start with and completed the course in an average time of 26 minutes. There was an announcement before the run and photos, cake and a card after the run. All very touching, especially as we all turned up to support him including the Fars. Jessica and Ben ran the last kilometre with Daddy.

Daddy ballooned and carded up

The celebration crew

Fortunately today's Falcons match was at Frimley Lodge Park, so Daddy quickly swapped to manager role. We faced Yateley, who went 2-0 up. A few changes at half time, saw a fight back by the boys and eventually we ran out 7-3 winners. Ben played well as a terrier in midfield.

Jessica heard that Farmor was running the tea bar down at Chertsey T Football Club, so got it in to her head that wanted to go down and help. She took her apron and made herself at home in the tea bar, helping making the teas, coffees and tidying up. She loved it. Chertsey also riding high, top of the table having won every game so far.

Jessica and Farmor tea barring

Later in the evening Daddy went to buy a motorbike from someone at his work's friend. He bought the 4 year old, CB500X for Â£2250. It is nice to have a bike where everything works, it has heated handlebar grips and a scotoiler. It is noticeably less fast, but more trustworthy around the corners. It has 50,000 miles on the clock. Now we need to sell the old bike.

New CB500X motorbike

title.value: parkrun 250, Falcons 7 v 3 Yateley, Jessica at Chertsey T FC teabar, Bought Motorbike

info.content:
We went over to see Auntie Susan and Graham as it was Susan's birthday this week. We had a cup of tea and sat in Graham's new Mercedes. Loving the internal lights.

In the Tremear's Kitchen

Jessica prepared a speech to the rest of the class in a bid to become House Captain for Endurance. There was a little bit of pressure seeing both Katie and Ben had previously been voted in as house captain. She had practiced her talk a number of times, amending it a bit here and there. Anyway today we found out she had been elected. Well done Jessica.

Exert out of the Frimley Times

title.value: Jessica voted in as House Captain

info.content: The Fars invited Jessica out to see the circus in West End. There weren't too many people in the audience. Jessica had a nice time.

title.value: Jessica and Fars to Jay Millars Circus

info.content:
Daddy set off early for Brands Hatch. He was supposed to be joined by Robin, Michael and Nick, but they all bailed out for one reason or another. Daddy was set the task of doing 100 miles in 6 hours. After the first hour he was 5 to 10 mins ahead of schedule, by 3 hours he was just on time having completed 50 miles. However, he had used all his energy to accomplish this and only managed 30 miles in the final 3 hours. Can't say it was enjoyable, but at least he's done 34 laps of Brands Hatch. He finished 20th out of 51 in his category.

Daddy taking on Graham Hill Bend

Route

In the morning Ben had his first game of the season, away to Hart Tornados. He won 6-0.

As part of Jessica's birthday present she was treated to a trip to London. First off to the Barbican (via the normal Gunnersbury route) to see a fashion show.
