Expectations were high because it was London Fashion Week. However, they didn't have a great seat, the models were young children and brands, although posh, we hadn't heard of them.

So they skipped out in the interval and headed towards Oxford Street and Regent's Street for some retail therapy..... lasting hours!

Just off to London Fashion Show

Not sure!

Jessica and her balloons

title.value: Hart 0 v 6 Falcons, London Fashion Show, Oxford Street Shopping

info.content: Jessica invited 12 friends over for a party. We hired a big bouncy slide. Amirette stayed for a sleepover.

We started in bed with opening cards and presents..... well mainly cards with money in them. She accrued over Â£300! Shocking and a very lucky girl. Of course pancakes for breakfast before a day at school.

After school the idea was to go to Thorpe Park. However, a combination of it being shut and Great Grandma being whisked to hospital meant we went to Frimley Park Hospital instead. Great Grandma had fallen over and cracked a vertebrae! She is in pain, but getting on as well as can be expected.

Jessica wanted to go to eat in the middle of a roundabout for dinner. Sound strange eh? Well she is referring to the Shepherd and Flock pub in Farnham. We booked a table and dressed it up with some banners and a balloon. She loved it. Jessica chose the exotic 'beans and chips' option. IT wasn't even on the menu, they were just side orders. We stayed for a while before going for a walk around the 'island'. We decided who in the family should live in each of the 14 or so houses.

In the morning Daddy went out with Bob and Jim for a Guildford circular. The pace was faster than usual which was good. They stopped to watch a few Flyers run in the Pilgrims Half Marathon.

Route

Bob, Jim and Daddy cycling

In the afternoon we relaxed at home and played a new quiz game on our mobiles and PS4. It's called Knowledge Is Power. There are a number of rounds on various subjects. The Maisey's popped around so they joined in a game as well. Jessica won!

Jessica won a family game of Knowledge Is Power

title.value: Guildford Circular Ride, Maiseys Over For Knowledge Is Power

info.content:
In the morning Daddy went to do parkrun. Ben came along but only did one lap as he had to get back and take Jessica for a 1-2-1 football training session. The girls went off to a fashion show in Guildford. High Street shops were the presenters. There were a couple of dudes from Love Isalnd which pleased Katie no end - she went bright red when she went next to them.

Guildford Fashion Show

Jessica's drama group were putting on a show. This was slightly different. The script was first seen by everyone at 7:30pm on Friday. They only had 24 hours to produce it and learn the music and lines. It was Joseph and his Amazing Technicolour Dream coat. There must have been a cast of 40 or 50 ranging from Jessicas age to old adults. Jessica had a small part. We dropped her off at 3pm at the theatre. We all came along with the Fars and Ma Ma and Pop Pop. She loved it.

Jessica in Joseph

title.value: parkrun, Fashion Show, Jessica in Joseph Theatre

info.content:
New School years:

Katie Year 11

Jessica Year 6

Ben Year 9

Off to school

Ben set the bath off. However it was dinner time. He had forgotten about the bath. When Katie finished dinner and went in to the front room she shouted out that water was pouring down the light and onto the carpet! Oh dear. To coin a en-vogue saying from Ben himself, 'You plonker' Ben. Fortunately there was no lasting damage.

title.value: Ben forgot to switch Bathroom taps off - water pouring through ceiling

info.content:
We split today. Daddy, Ben, Farfar, Ma Ma and Pop Pop went up towards Milton Keynes to visit Bletchley Park. It was a veterans day and Great Grandma was invited too, however, she fell over yesterday and was not well enough to attend.

The day started registering for the veterans day and grabbing a cup of coffee in the hospitality tent. Ma Ma got talking to one of the hosts who setup a future interview with great grandma to talk about her days at Bletchley Park. We found out that grandma was part of the WRENs working in hut 8 and doing detective work from the messages received. It was said she worked on the Italian and Japanese intercepts. We then toured around some of the huts and saw the exhibits, including a very interesting piece on the war pigeons.

After the buffet lunch, we went on a tour around the part of the house and park. Some very interesting stories. After, we ventured into hut 11 and the Bombe. The machine used to decipher Enigma messages.

Bletchley Park House

After finishing up at Bletchley Park itself, we walked around the corner to the National Computer Museum. Seeing the Bombe gave us thirst to see more, especially Colossus, the first programmable computer. For the hour or so we were there it was very interesting. There was a man describing the Harwell Dekatron computer aka WITCH, which allowed you to see memory registers change values. We also saw Colossus working away, with tape whizzing around. Daddy also got to see many of the home computers of the 80s. We had to wrench him off playing Manic Miner on the Spectrum! A good day.

Colossus computer

Meanwhile us girls went to Thorpe Park. Jessica tried a number of new ride including Stealth.

In the morning Daddy and Ben went to do parkrun. Ben is now regularly beating Daddy. It would be a shock if Daddy finished ahead.

The ugly job of re-felting the shed roof was upon Daddy. He has been putting it off for a while now. Â£80 of felt. Ben helped getting the old felt off the roof. Hopefully this will stop it leaking now. Although not sure about the nails, leaving gaps for rain water.

We know it's not Mummy and Daddy's anniversary until tomorrow. But tomorrow Daddy is out. Ben, enthusiastically stated that he'll host and cook the meal right from menu planning, shopping, cooking, prep'ing the table and room and washing up. He hired a couple of helpers, in Jessica who made the desert and Katie who made the starter and washed up. It was very sweet of them.

They exchanged presents. Daddy received a waistcoat, whilst Mummy a jumper that she'd asked for. For starters they ate homemade garlic bread, mains was a pasta in a tomato sauce and chrizo, desert was a gin and tonic sorbet with homemade brownies. The meal was delicious, even down to the Rose wine! Thanks guys. Top cooking.

Anniversary Meal

18th year

title.value: parkrun, re-felt shed roof, 18th Wedding Anniversary Meal

info.content:
The weather still wasn't great on this bank holiday weekend. Still we were determined to make the most of it and continue with our trip to the coast. The main aim was to actually use Ben's body board that was bought a while back. Daddy being daddy saw this trip to the coast as an excuse to get the bike out, so we dropped him off in Bordon and he biked down from there.The rest of us continued and first went in the cafe to get some food and drink and then had a go on the funfair with tokens left over from a previous excursion.

When Daddy arrived we met in our usual spot next to the volleyball court. and had a picnic lunch. Then it was time to enter the water. Who was brave? Well Mummy, Jess and Ben were. We did use the body board for about 15 minutes before the cold got the better of us.

We returned home and played a family game of risk. Despite a poor start, Ben came back strongly and won, much to his hapiness.

Lunch on the beach

body boarding it up

In the morning Mummy went down to the lake to join Ellie and Lily and mermaid it around the usual circuit.

As we were away on Farfar's birthday, Auntie Susan and Daddy decided to have a family meal at the Leathern Bottle in Wokingham. The weather was terrible, raining all day which scuppered the supplementary Crazy Golf. However, we spent over 3 hours chatting and eating away. It was good fun.

Leathern Bottle, Wokingham

In the evening we played a family game of Monopoly. This Monopoly was a 'Make Your Own Monopoly' where you could make up your own properties and chance / community chest cards. There were some forfeits like, 'Farfar tells you a long story. Miss a go', or 'Go on one of Mummy's walks, miss a go' or 'Daddy buys a dodgy car, pay Â£100'. Daddy won!

Sadly it was home day. We handed the villa back at 11am and packed our bags and went to Los Abrogos to scrape the undercarriage of the car on some rocks, oops, and to try some Churros in a local cafe type place. They were OK to eat. We headed up the road and did some supermarket shopping for presents and lunch. We then headed back to Costa Adeje and took a long walk along the promenade to Playa de Torviscas. Here we hired another pedalo boat with a slide. However, it wasn't quite as good as the other day. There were some islands 100 metres from the beach which we all swum out to and had a look.

J and D in sand. for Jessica and Daddy

Ben and Daddy in Costa Adeje

We dawdled back to the car, stopped of for a KFC and McDs before returning the car back at the airport. The flight went well, landing back in Gatwick at just gone midnight. However, because we parked the car a couple of miles away and we were so late, there were no buses, there was no way Daddy would stretch for paying for a taxi, so he decided he could run it! Getting out of the airport was a mission in itself. Or at least getting out at the right exit. Eventually he was out and running up a dark, spooky path with 6 foot high chain link fences either side. At Horley some people who had finished in the pub for the night were wondering why I was jogging at 1am in the morning! Having got back to the car (it was OK), Daddy then didn't do too well at re-locating us at the bus station. We rolled into the house at 2:30am, leaving the suitcases in the car. It had been a long day. Daddy had 5 hours sleep before work next morning!

Back to car route

title.value: Tenerife Holiday - 8 - Costa Adeje and Home

info.content:
Everyone was looking forward to this day. The reason we chose Tenerife was because we looked up where the best Water Park in the world was. Siam Park was the answer, so based our whole holiday around this. Mummy had saved Â£600 to get us all the VIP tickets. This granted us unlimited fast pass entries and unlimited food and drink. The Teale's were also in Tenerife and we met up here to experience the day together.

The big question was going to be whether Ben could get on the Tower of Power. The large, drop slide. The big problem was you had to be 14. When Alice also said you had to be 45kg, Ben was upset and had resigned himself to not going on the slide. There was a bit of phaffing at the start, but by 10:30 we were off and starting our first slide. Mummy was relishing the free food and drink. Having the fast pass was certainly useful. The normal queues were long and would have taken 30 / 40 minutes plus. Fast passes were about 10 minute queues.

Most rides involved an inflatable ring. Many of them needed 2, 3, or 4 people to ride in them. It was great. Having got around to the afternoon having tried all but 2 rides. Probably the best two rides. First up the Tower of Power.

No fast pass on this, but the queue was reasonably short. Daddy was confident that Ben would not pass for 14. He was shocked at the exchange. Attendant: How old are you? Ben: 14 Attendant: Really? Ben: Yes. Attendant: OK then, on you go! Unbelieveable. Ben very happy. Daddy dreading what was coming up. 20 minutes later Ben at the top and the lady gently shoving him down the slide. Daddy followed. Ben's reaction: it wasn't that scary! The second ride was one with a shared inflatable with 4. It went so high up the banked edges. Daddy and Ben went on with some weighty people. We stayed to the end. Daddy and Ben calculated 18 slide goes and a trip on the lazy river and big wave machine.

Jessica and Alice

We were invited back to the Teale's villa just 10 minutes away. It was gorgeous. We even had a go in their pool which was even bigger than ours. We strolled down to Costa Adeje's beach front to get dinner in a restaurant. Very nice end to the day.

Meal out

title.value: Tenerife Holiday - 7 - Siam Park, Teales Villa

info.content:
We headed to the north coast. Another challenge for the car, who had to make a number of climbs. Once we had got to the north the roads got even steeper. So steep that the brakes were getting very hot. Daddy could smell them and decided we needed to stop, fearing a brake failure. We needed the brakes. El Tanque and Les Cruces are not for the driving faint hearted going up or down! Definitely the steepest roads Daddy has ever driven. After an hour and a half of driving we eventually we reached the town of Garachico.

Garachico used to be the biggest port in the Canaries until a volcano erupted and destroyed the town. The lava formed these natural rock pools which is used to today by us and other tourists to swim in. Dare devil Ben was finding the highest rocks and jumping in first. The rest of us timidly followed in after him. It was an interesting setup. We played around for an hour or so before heading in to the sleepy town. We walked the picturesque streets via the church and town square. We made it to an ice cream shop to have some much needed cool down time.

We returned to another part of the natural pools. Daddy got stuck right into the rock pools and saw about 50 crabs scaling an isolated rock. There were some massive crabs. They were scared of him which was a relief.

First Swim Route

In the rock pools

After completing the long journey home via KFC (again), Daddy cooked up a BBQ before our now traditional hot tub and swimming pool trips.

Later in the evening Daddy decided he needed to do a local run. Having plotted, what he thought was a 5km run, he began heading north, 5km had passed and he was still heading away from the villa something not right. He passed the end of Tenerife's main runway and was later on the road to El Medano. He had plotted incorrectly. Near the end, he got a hypo which restricted him to run walking the last few kilometers. As Ben would say, 'you plonker Daddy'.

Runway Route

Being a Sunday we found a church for Mummy in Los Christanos. She said it was a good service. Whilst she was praying the rest of us went to the sea front and hired a pedalo that had a slide off the back of it. We had great fun. Ben challenged us to jumping from the top step of the slide. We saw some big ships come in and we had ample of space to play around. The weather again was scorching. At the end of our hour, mummy made it to the beach and swum to join us. We loved it.

Pedalo'ing Route

Finishing on Los Christianos beach

Just outside Los Christianos was the Camel Park. A little, strange place with a slightly eccentric lady running the place. It was nice to experience something a little different. Between the five of us we shared 2 camels. Children on one, adults on the other. There were 6 camels in the caravan, all roped closely together. So close that the camel behind us was less than a metre away from the back of our head. We got intimate knowledge of the camels mouth movements. On occasions they got so close we had to duck out of the way. We headed off on a 30 minute walk, zig zagging along some paths. It was interesting and something to say we had done, but wasn't amazing.

Camel Route

We returned back to base and had an ice cream and a dip in the pool. We then split. Daddy decided he wanted to climb the local Mountana Roja, whilst the rest of us went to the beach where the kite surfers seemed to hang out. Daddy chose the most difficult of routes up the mountain it seemed. He enjoyed the stunning view from the top. The rest of us enjoyed the crashing waves, before being told off for being in the wrong area of the beach. It was reserved for sports people!

Mountana Roja Route

Mont Roja

title.value: Tenerife Holiday - 5 - Los Christianos, Camel Riding, Mountana Roja Climb

info.content:
Daddy found a nice treat for us by taking to Amarilla Golf and the Pancake Cafe. We of course had pancakes except mummy who had a full English! It was yummy. We then made our way for a stop off at Los Christianos, one of the touristy hot spots. We walked along the promenade and enjoyed the sun.

Jessica tucking into a pancake breakfast

Aviators

We then headed up the coast to Los Gigantes for a spot of lunch, then down to the harbour and the Dive Centre. We had booked a snorkeling trip under the 500 metre cliffs. We got kitted up and taken out on a speed boat for 10 minutes. We anchored under the cliffs and told to explore. The flippers handicapped some of us. Snorkeling was great. Seeing all the types of fish. The rocks under the sea were a little boring but we had an interesting time nosing around. Daddy retrieved a shell for this girl who dropped it too deep. We were snorkeling for an hour or so before returning back to the harbour and taking on some much needed ice cream.

Route

Los Gigantes coast we explored snorkelling

Daddy had parked up the cliff, seemingly miles away so we sent him to get the car. Our next stop on this road trip was another popular resort, Playa De Las Americas. Here we relaxed on the sandy beach, explored the shopping mall and stopped off at a restuarant for a bite to eat. Jessica and Ben hired an electric mini jeep and terrorized the promenade.

Playa De Las Americas Route

Beauty queen in Playa De Las Americas

Katie on the beach in Playa De Las Americas

Daddy and Katie

Ben on a quad bike on the promenade in Playa De Las Americas

title.value: Tenerife Holiday - 4 - Pancake Cafe, Los Christianos, Los Gigantes Snorkeling, Playa De Las Americas

info.content:
We headed to the local supermarket to get breakfast, which mainly consisted of doughnuts and croissants.

Daddy drove us up the east coast, along the motorway to the capital of Tenerife, Santa Cruz. On one side of the motorway a steep incline up the mountains, the other side it was the ocean and coastal landscapes.

We decided to go for a walk first to the food market in the centre of the city. There was a large range of food, like a mini Borough Market. We bought some tomato pasta and some sweeties of course. We then walked to a shopping mall where we Katie bought a swimming costume from the much loved Primark and Jessica an inflatable for the pool.

Santa Cruz Walk Route

Getting ready for the pools

We then entered the purpose made swimming pools. There were two massive pools, one had an inflatable slide. We had a great time here. Daddy decided to go for a Flyers 5km run around the city which took in the large football stadium.

Santa Cruz run Route

We spent most of the day here. At the end, Ben and Jessica played football on a inflatable, water pitch. Ben made a Spanish football friend for a bit. Quite interesting to see the both of them communicate in their opposite broken language.

We made our way home and Daddy cooked us up a nice BBQ, whilst we chilled in the hot tub.

Playing the locals at water football

We left our villa in La Tejita and drove up and up and up again to Mount Tiede. Tenerife all came about from the Volcano Tiede. It must have been an hour's drive, winding our way up. There were no flats and no downhills. It was just up. If we did have the Fiat 500, then we would not have made it. The Clio struggled with the 5 of us in it! There were some stunning views. Us children were stunned that we could drive above the clouds. We stopped a few time to take pictures. Our final destination was the last 500m and the cable car to the top. It was scorching hot. Unfortunately, we needed to book in advance to ride the cable car. No one was that gutted, having seen the length of the queue and the cost. We instead climbed a hill just to the other side.

Route on Mt. Tiede

Looking from Mount Tiede

Mount Tiede

We descended and a few miles down we stopped for a picnic lunch. We were still above the clouds and the sun was 'El Scorchioo'. On our way back to the villa we stopped at a supermarket for supplies and then hit the swimming pool at the villa.

Later in the afternoon we hit the beach, our local beach. It was 600 metres away. It was a course sandy beach and with the strong wind, it made for an unpleasant walk as the sand whipped around our ankles. With wind, comes bigger waves. The sea water was the warmest we've experienced ever. We were having such fun battling the waves. In the end, Ben got himself wedged into the sand and a wave came over him and he bent his back under the water. He was hurt and we had to return back to the villa. Great fun.

Route down to Playa De La Tejita

After some dinner, we headed out to the local big town, El Medano, a couple of miles down the road. We walked around the town, down to the sea front. A lovely walk.

Route

El Medano Family shot

El Medano quay side

title.value: Tenerife Holiday - 2 - Mount Tiede, Playa De La Tejita, El Medano

info.content:
For once we had a sensible take off time in the afternoon, so drove to Gatwick and parked in our normal 'housing estate' car parking spot in Carlton Tye, Horley. We caught the bus into the South terminal, then the 4.5 hour BA flight to Tenerife's South Airport. We landed on time, got our luggage, but then the wallet was dropped with about 30 coins rolling out in all directions! Then the rental car was sought after and that's when the real fun began!

Gatwick travelators. Always fun

Mummy had booked a 5 seater car as it clearly stated on the email. We arrived at our car and it was a Fiat 500. A small, four seater car. Oh dear. Houston we have a problem. So Daddy went back to the airport terminal to get a 5 seater car. The Europcar lady behind the counter basically wasn't having any of it and said that's the type of car provided for that booking. Daddy pointed out that the sales said we should get a 5 seater car and it would be illegal for the 5 of us to go in the Fiat as it only had 4 seat belts. The Europcar lady replied when asked Daddy said there were only 4 people. Daddy called her a liar, because he hadn't said that. The voices were raised and anger displayed from both parties. At the 'liar' accusation the lady threatened to call the police. Daddy welcomed, this and invited her to do so. Daddy wasn't going away! The lady turned to her next customer, who was listening to this and served them for the next 10 minutes. Daddy waited patiently. After dealing with the customer, Daddy asked where the police were, so the matter could be dealt with...... she hadn't called them. Daddy said she had therefore lied again! Eventually she allowed the use of her phone (which was not available) so Daddy could speak to customer services. They agreed straight away and after a 10 minute heated discussion between the Europcar Lady and Europcar Customer Services, we were granted a 5 seater, Renault Clio! The Europcar Lady still wouldn't have it, and expressed that we should pay more for a 5 seater car. Daddy responded that you shouldn't falsely advertise. The whole getting the car thing took an hour out of our holiday.

Fiat 500 anyone?

This little incident made us late meeting up with our contact at the villa. It was dark now. We did eventually meet up and the villa was lovely. It had a bed for each of us, a hot tub and a shared, big, swimming pool. We got some local food and it was time for bed.

Daddy ran in the Hart 4 with a strong number of Flyers. It was 4 in a team (Daddy, James, Peta and Oli). There was a 4km lap and they had 4 hours to see how many they could do. Daddy ran 3 laps.

Hart 4 Lap 1 RouteHart 4 Lap 2 RouteHart 4 Lap 3 Route

Hart 4

After 37 hours of work, Daddy finally got his coaching certificate

FA Level 1 Coaching Certificate

A friend from church worked at parliament for an MP and was able to give Daddy and Ben a tour around the place. First, they went up by train (Â£42) to Waterloo. Ben directed, with his new phone, them to the Imperial War museum. They continued touring around where they had left off 6 month ago. Mainly they saw the floor on the conflicts since 1945.

Imperial War Museum

The pair got lunch and ate it on the wall of the Thames looking on to the Houses Of Parliament, watching all the tourists go by. After, they walked around Parliament Square looking at all the statues and onto Westminster Abbey.

Lunching by parliament

2pm and they made it to Portcullis House, got security screened and met up with James. He's a church friend who works for Gary Streeter MP. He happens to be the chairman of the Christians In Politics group, which James helps on. James's degree in Politics and Theology means this is the perfect job it would seem. However, after 5 years he leaving to train as a vicar.

James first led us through a tunnel, under Westminster Bridge Road, which we didn't realise existed. He began by taking us to Westminster Hall, the only original part of Parliament after the fire in 1834. Through St. Stephens Hall and into the Central Lobby. We first turned right towards the Lords end of Parliament. Everything is red and gold. It was very interesting to hear the stories and protocol. We headed towards the Commons next. At first I thought this was big, then thought how small it was to house 650 MPs. It was interesting to the galleries which you don't see on the TV. Again some interesting points of fact. After an hour and a half we ended back up at Westminster Hall and thanked James very much for his time.

Westminster Hall

We caught a bus and briefly got off at Trafalgar Square. Ben was very pleased to see London again. Because of Katie's anxiety over London we generally don't go up much these days. Ben loves it. They continued on the bus past Piccadilly Circus and up Regents Street. They disembarked went in the Bose shop and visited all 5 floors of Hamleys. Harry Potter and Lego are still the big sellers. They walked through Carnaby Street, visiting some sports shops before hitting Nike Town at Oxford Circus. The initial purchase was made for a school bag. We then went into many other sports shops. Ben loved it as there were all the shops he could hope for, and they were all the flagship outlets, which meant they were big. Time was marching on and they were both fatigued from their excursion. A tube ride took them back to Waterloo. They were then able to train it back home.

Various London bits

title.value: Parliament Tour, Imperial War Museum, Oxford Street retailing

info.content:
Ben turned into a teenager today. We woke late and began the present opening process. Well there weren't many of your traditional presents, mainly cards with money in it!

As a treat we went to Farnborough Gate McDonalds to have some breakfast. Ben had pancakes with maple syrup with orange juice. His favourite.

All sorts of things on Bens Birthday

We shortly went up to London for a surprise treat. We parked up at the Queen Elizabeth Olympic park and went to the ArcelorMittal Orbit, the big red, scaffolding looking structure next to the stadium. First we had a picnic next to the 'Orbit'. We had booked to go on the slide. It takes about 45 seconds to go down it. It was very quick.

The ArcelorMittal Orbit

The slide

We rushed back to host Ben's football birthday party. Dad had made some points based system, with 3 football matches, a game of World Cup and a penalty shoot out. There were 7 others: Oli, Kieran, Jamie C, Freddie, Jayden, Jonny and Joey. After we came back home, had pizza and played in the pool.

In the evening Ma Ma and Pop Pop popped over, then the 5 of us watched Ben's choice of film, Mission Impossible 5.

We left on Saturday down to Wareham to the campsite we went to 2 years ago. We left Daddy at home!

  • Saturday: camp setup
  • Sunday: Rained all day. We went to Auntie Charlotte's and watched a film
  • Monday: Lyme Regis

    Us and our cousins

  • Tuesday: Wild swim and Puddletown tea shop
  • Wednesday: Camp, swimming pool and Swanage fireworks
  • Thursday: Studland Bay

    Jessica paddle boarding

  • Friday: Dancing ledge sunrise, Mud park, Durdle Door

    Jessica through the mud course

    The boys and Durdle Door

    The girls at Durdle Door

  • Saturday: Home time

    Hello campers

This is a bit of a sob story. Not sure whether to laugh or cry. Myself and Michael had entered the Prudential Ride 100. A 100 mile bike ride, starting and ending in London. As a back-drop to this, I had not done any distance training, and I had the Thursday and Friday off work due to feeling rundown, sore throat and a headache. So going into this I was concerned about my overall physical state.

We had to register on the Saturday at Excel. The traffic around to the opposite end of the M25 meant it was touch and go whether we'd make the 5pm deadline. The journey involved going in Michael's mobile gas chamber. There is a fault, such that exhaust fumes go into the car, so we had to roll the windows down. With just a few minutes to spare, we dumped the car in a pub car park close by, hoping we wouldn't get clamped. We got in just in time. Even managed to get some cheeky photos in.

At the show

We made our way to the hotel, 'rebuilt' our bikes and watched the Tour De France highlights. After, I went out to the supermarket to get some supplies from Tesco. Got on the bike went around a bend and almost fell off. Rear puncture! Great one of my two inner-tubes used up before I'd even started! Eventually rode the 1.5 mile trip past Excel to a Tesco Express. There were a lot of people shopping and milling about outside. I was a little nervous at leaving the bike right outside, so wheeled it down a barrier'ed slipway to a car park. I went in got yogurt, milk and some fruit. I was panicking a bit, so quickly went out to check. The bike was still there. I went back in again to pay for the shopping. Must have been 2 or 3 minutes. GONE. Bike was nicked.

Where has my bike gone. Site of crime!

I knew there was no chance finding it. It would have been long gone. I did look around, but nothing. I wasn't so worried about the bike so much, but it had my timing chip on it and the bracket / clips for my lights which are going to be hard to replace. Also, what was I going to tell Michael? I started the long trudge back to the hotel and was resigned to the face I wasn't going to do the ride. It was now 9:30pm, I entered the hotel and told Michael what had happened. After he stopped laughing, he hatched a plan which would involve driving 1h 45 minutes back to Alton to pick up his spare bike and drive all the way back again. So windows down in the car for a 3.5 hour round trip plus a bit extra as the bike had no pedals and needed a tweak here and there.

On returning back, I managed somehow to lose the hotel entry card. So we needed to call the receptionist, issue us a new card. We just needed our beds. As soon as we got in our room, I went to the toilet and pressed what I thought was the cord for the light switch. As it was a disabled toilet, it wasn't a cord for the light switch, instead it was the emergency cord! Oh dear. A mini-siren sounded, a flashing red light out the room and the receptionist running towards us. Again this is 2:30 in the morning! After apologising and setting the phone alarm for 2 hours 10 minutes time we finally went to sleep.

4:40am and the alarm went off. What were we doing? Gulped some breakfast down, managed to lose the second of our room cards, and took our stuff out to the car. Michael hid his car key on the tyre of the car, misjudged it and the keys clattered inside the wheel. We just left it for now as we were running behind schedule. The weather was a little nippy as we rode the 6 miles to the start line. The scale of the operation was vast. 29,000 riders all starting from the same area. Myself and Michael, not only had different start times, but also were starting at opposite ends of the Queen Elizabeth Park. So I decided to try and sneak in and start with the 'Greens' at the earlier time.

It was 7:05am and we were finally off. It was nice to get going finally. Within 15 minutes the heavens opened and for the next 8 hours it rained and rained. We hooked on to some fast trains as we snaked our way through London and finally out into the countryside. My 'new' bike was great. Loved it. The seat post needed adjusting, but otherwise the ride was much better than my Giant Defy.

To the Tower

Michael picked up a puncture around the Byfleet area. The stop and the rain made us a little cold so we stopped in for a coffee. We got to Newlands Corner and stopped for a bit, before heading down the fast descent down towards Gomshall. As I raced down, Pssstttt. A wobbly front wheel made me almost lost control as I had a blow out. Damm it, another puncture.

Puncture going down Newlands Corner

My turn. We must have spent over 30 minutes trying to sort this out. We had a problem. We changed the tube, pumped it up and as we unscrewed the pump, the valve unscrewed with, making the air come all out. We must have tried 2 or 3 times. It really is exhausting stuff trying to get enough pressure into the tubes. Michael ingenious idea was to tighten the valve to the inner-tube by trapping it in the rear axel with the use of the quick release. This worked a treat and finally we pumped the tyre again, and off we went. Better still there was a track pump just up the road to get me up to the ideal pressure. Also a chap sold his spare inner tube as we had none between us and we hadn't much luck so far. Then down the next hill again and Pssssttttt. Arrrrgghhhh. Another puncture in the same wheel. Something fishy going on now. The tyre sidewall had eroded a bit. We worked out that the brake block was set too low and was rubbing against the tyre, causing the punctures. We happened to fix the puncture at the bottom of the road leading to Netley House, my company's old premises. Again quite a time was spent re-enforcing the tyre with a gel and getting the tyre pumped up. It was still hammering down with rain. Again we were down to no spare inner-tubes between us and now I couldn't use the front brake. We were just entering the really hilly section now!

At this point, chucking the bike in the hedge was looking appealing

We were diverted past Leith Hill as someone had a heart attack and CPR was being administered by the paramedics. That explained the various ambulances and medical vehicles screaming passed us. I found a track pump, but rather than making things better it made them worse as all the air escaped. It was a rubbish pump. I managed to get back to 40 psi, but it was less than half inflated. It was slow going through Dorking due to the traffic. The organisers had shut Box Hill due to an accident. So we avoided both main hills and it meant we were only going to do 90 miles, not 100. At the next stop there was a bike shop. Yippee.. I managed to get full pressure again in my tyre, but they had sold out of inner tubes. With 25 miles to go we hit another blockage in the road at Leatherhead.

Held up in Leatherhead

The rest of the journey back to London was quite pleasurable. The weather started to clear and as I hadn't actually felt we had started, I had plenty of energy to push some pace. We finished at goodness knows in what time. It was largely irrelevant.

Finishing down The Mall

The Medal shot

We collected our medals, took some photo's and headed back to City Airport. However, we were determined to do 100 miles. Considering we had done 6 extra miles to get to the start line, we decided to ride back to Tower Hill and catch the DLR. I made it back home at 8pm. What a journey the past 28 hours were. Because my timing chip was stolen it hadn't counted officially, so that means I got to do it again another year. I'm chasing the London Classic medal.

Route

Summer came over to stay, whilst Jessica went over to the Teale's. Jess went to the beach at Bluewater.

The majority went over to Fiona's and played in their pool along with Helen and Guy.

Mummy subjected to an attack

title.value: Summer here - over to Burrows, Jess to the Teale's

info.content:
Katie turned 15 today. Shock, horror, the standard format of eating breakfast in Mummy and Daddy's bed has been temporarily postponed! The present opening did happen. And there were loads. The main present was her new IPhone7+. Katie was mightily pleased after begging for one for months.

After the present opening, we all went into Camberley and surprised Katie by going in Frankie and Benny's for breakfast. We were just about the only ones there, but we had a nice time nonetheless. We all sang happy birthday after having polished off our brekkie.

Frankie And Benny's for breakfast

When we returned Auntie Charlotte came over with Lenny. She took Katie and Jessica out to get their nails done and buy them a subway lunch in Camberley. Whilst the birthday girl was out, the rest of us dressed up the back garden with banners and got the bouncy castle up and running. A couple of Katie's friends popped in to give presents and say happy birthday.

At about 4:30pm our guests began to arrive for a party. The guests included the Elders, the Fars, Ma Ma and Pop Pop. We ordered in Dominos Pizzas and had lots of goodies to eat, including a birthday cake. The party was in full flow and somebody suggested we make a circuit up which included the bouncy castle and running or walking it blindfolded. It was like the ministry of funny walks. It was very funny to see peoples attempts. Ma Ma almost dug into next doors garden! That entertained us for almost an hour!

Singing happy birthday as Katie blow birthday cake candles out

One of Katie's bucket list items was to sleep under the stars. Most of us stayed behind and gave it a go. However, there were a lot of mozzies about. Many of the adults gave up some part of the night, but all the children managed to last till dawn. Katie had a really good birthday.

Sleeping under the stars

We headed towards Cullompton and Diggerland, Devon. Daddy was a little worried at the target age group for this attraction. There weren't many cars in the car park at 11am. Still we eventually got in after a bit of admin trouble from our end concerning vouchers. There were a dozen or so rides and things to do. We enjoyed them all. Jessica and Katie drove a Land Rover and a JCB for their first times. Daddy even drove a JCB for the first time. Jessica was pretty competent for a first attempt. She wasn't phased at all.

We had a go at using the claw and actually digging a hole in a JCB, as well as some games in mini diggers. Quite difficult controlling the arm and claw. Ben was enamoured by the 'Crazy Carts'. Small, electric powered carts with trolley wheels. He wanted one for home!

We tried everything out and made our way home to end a lovely, family weekend.

Placing tyres

Tip trucks

Jessica digging for gold

Mummy v Katie 10-pin bowling

This was Daddy's birthday treat. We were heading down to Torquay for the weekend. Of course on the way we had to stop off at a parkrun. Montacute House is National Trust venue which hosts the Yeovil parkrun. It was double hot as Daddy went on his own around the 5km course. There were plenty of sheep, some there I am sure to trip you up by running right across the traffic of parkrunners. Daddy came in at 26:45 which he was pleased about.

Montacute House

Onwards to Torquay, more specifically Oddicombe Beach where we stopped off for a spot of lunch on the pebbles. We then walked along the coastal path to Babbacombe beach and then up the 30% gradient road back to the car.

Jessica on the way to Babbacombe Beach

We were advised to come up the wrong way up a one way street because the other access was shut...... well we were slightly mis-advised as the road had re-opened. Needless to say we faced an oncoming car. Whoops.

We met Charlie, our guide for the coasteering session. We squeezed into our wet suits and buoyancy aids and headed down into Anstey Cove. It was a reasonably quiet and secluded cove with no obvious public access. We climbed around the fence and jumped in. Katie stood on the sidelines not sure about what was ahead so dipped out of this one.

The rest of us spent the next two hours swimming from rock to rock to cliff and jumped off various ledges and boulders. Some high and some not so high. There were a couple that Mummy, Daddy and Jessica were unsure about. However, we all managed the jumps in the end. Poor Ben got stung a couple of times by a Compass Jellyfish. You could see them from the ledges in their bright orange clothes!

We got some great photos from the experience. One that comes highly recommended.

The coasteering crew

Group jump

Rock climbing

We then headed to our hotel. A Travelodge near Exeter on the M5. We got ourselves cleaned up and then headed out again for Fish and Chips..... as well as an Indian for mummy. We then drove to the River Exe and ate them on picnic benches.

River Exe'ing

Daddy and Ben went to Frimley Lodge park for the Frimley Flyers Handicap event. The competition rules were very different. This year who had to predict a time that you were going to run 5km, and then without a watch or any timing device had to run that time. Ben had chosen to run 26 minutes and Daddy 27 minutes dead.

We were all let go in intervals, in theory we all cross the line together. Out of the thirty two running, Ben was just 7 seconds slower than his predicted time. Daddy was 5 seconds too quick and came in 7th and 6th respectively. Bob and Alfie were spot on with their predictions and were joint winners.

After, we went over to the BBQ pits and had a BBQ, prize giving and a game of rounders. By this stage Mummy and Jessica had joined us. Daddy scored the winning rounder!

Flyers at our handicap event

In the morning Daddy and Ben did Frimley Lodge parkrun in 26 minutes.

Route

Charlotte came over to stay for the weekend and we all decided to use the Wild Swim book she got us. There was a reservoir over in Ceasers Camp. It was a long walk to get there and once we did we found it was out of bounds to swimmers! Gutted.

The unlucky would be swimmers

title.value: parkrun, Failed Wildswim, Charlotte stay over

info.content:
Katie, Ben and Jessica all go to the trampolining club every Monday. Tonight was the end of season competition. Jessica was placed in a higher ability group than Ben and was awarded a bronze for her performance.

Ben was awarded a gold medal for his jump.

title.value: Ben and Jess in Trampolining Competition

info.content:
Jessica has been going to the acting group for about 5 months. Each week she has been practicing her lines and role as Lord Capulet, Juliet's Father. She did every so well with her lines. She must have had 20 or so. Auntie Ellie, Joey, Lily and Farmor all came to watch too. The production, at Camberley Theatre last for about 40 minutes and all the actors were 13 or younger. Katie's friend Katherine was part of the production staff. Well done Jessica.

The boys rushed back to watch the England game in the semi final of the World Cup.

Jessica as Lord Capulet

Daddy turns 43 today. We made breakfast for him in bed and gave him his presents. From Mummy we are going on a Coasteering weekend in a couple of weeks time. From Ben, Daddy got a bumper Tour De France pack which included a big magazine, water bottle, socks and energy tablets. Katie got some veg crisps, Marmite crisps and a nice t-shirt. Jessica got Daddy a nice new belt. From the Elders Daddy got some 3 peaks bits, Susan got Dad some nice swim shorts and beer preserve.

In the evening we had a lovely Lasagne, one of Dad's favourites and he relaxed watching the France v Belgium World Cup semi final match.

Daddy opening 43rd birthday presents

So things have moved fast. Today all five of us went to the Eating Disorder clinic in Epsom where we had a 3 hour meeting talking about Katie's condition. They were assessing whether they would take us on for a 6 week course of treatment which largely involves giving advice and helping Katie get back to a healthy weight. The meeting involved the Nurse, a psychiatrist and a student nurse. In fact Mummy knew the psychiatrist from a talk she gave a few weeks previous on the very subject matter. The nurse also lived in Mytchett and had a son who goes to Tomlinscote and is in the same year!

It was very hard to hear Katie's account. It boils down to body image. The trigger point happened in February. A number of contributing factors include: Being called fat by one of her friends, body image pressure, looking up to friends who have a thin figure, seeing on the internet that you shouldn't eat after 7pm, sometimes bored after school, thinking we were too poor to buy food and probably lots of other things. Daddy cried in the meeting - when Katie was out of the room, it distressed him greatly. Mummy was obviously very concerned and anxious as well. Jessica and Ben contributed as well in the meeting and had a role to play.

We were told that BMI was not used as a measure in children. Instead they use some other height vs weight measurement. It was expressed that 100% is a normal, healthy weight. They recommend children should be between 95% and 105%. At 80% they recommend that the child should be taken out of school. Katie was just above that at 81%. Very concerning. The solution was simply to load calories. Avoid anything that takes away the calories such as exercise. 3000 calories was suggested. 3 meals a day, 3 snacks a day and a pint of 3% fat milk (blue top).

The clinical team went away to meet and they agreed to take Katie on. Initially for a 6 week stint to get her weight back. After that, depending on how she is doing, some psychiatric treatment will be given.

It was quite a session, but at the end of it, we had acceptance from Katie and we felt we had a plan going forward.

After, we went into Kingston and went to Pizza Hut to eat the unlimited buffet. We walked around the shops and got a few bits and pieces for the house and bought the English version of Monopoly, after having the American version for so long.

WE LOVE YOU KATIE.

Daddy joined Auntie Ellie, Rachel, Jon, Loz and Michael on a massive road trip around Britain, with a few mountains thrown in for fun too. They set off on Friday at about 5pm, arriving for a 5am start at Ben Nevis.

The mountaineering was tough. The challengers were certainly putting a sweat on. It was shorts and t-shirt weather even where the snow was and even at night. The weather was hot to say the least.

Driving

  • Alton to Ben Nevis: 528 miles
  • 3 Peaks Route: 463 miles
  • Snowdon to Alton: 252 miles
  • Total: 1,243 miles

Mountains

  • Ben Nevis
    • Start Time: 5:01am - Peaked: 8:06am - End Time: 10:24am (Up: 3h 5m, Down: 2h 18m)
    • Ben Nevis Route
  • Scafell Pike
    • Start Time: 4:53pm - Peaked: 7:28pm - End Time: 9:35pm (Up: 2h 35m, Down: 2h 7m)
    • Scafell Pike Route
  • Snowdon
    • Start Time: 2:20am - Peaked: 4:55am - End Time: 7:36am (Up: 2h 35m, Down: 2h 41m)
    • Snowdon Route

The crew got back to Alton mid afternoon on the Sunday. Exhausted and barely able to walk, but satisfied of their weekend's achievements.

Scafell Pike

Ben Nevis

Snowdon

Snowdon - We did it

We went to church as usual, Mummy was on Sunday school. She was running late, so entered the church service and sat in one of the pews. For Sunday School she needed a microphone so the children could be interviewed. The nearest we had was Ben's megaphone which was accidentally left on. This unknown to anyone played havoc with the church's sound system and basically provided feedback. The feedback was so loud, the congregation were blocking their ears. Unknown to anyone the megaphone was the cause of this problem. Some stand in engineers were up on ladders, fiddling around with cables attempting to fix the problem. They even switched off the sound system and yet the feedback was still reverberating around the church. It was then decided that the service could not continue inside, so it was decided that the service should be held outside.

As Mummy went to leave the church to go outside with the others, she picked up the bag and all of a sudden the noise stopped for a bit, and the pitch of the squeal changed. At that point she knew the cause of the problem. The Megaphone!

Instead of owning up or even just removing the bag, mummy panicked and just left the bag inside the church and joined the service outside.

After 10 minutes Mummy had to leave the service to do Sunday school and made Auntie Charlotte go and get the bag which was in church. However, the men who were busy attempting to find the source of the problem were still there. Mummy told Charlotte to grab the bag and quickly escape. Instead, once the bag was moved it became very obvious to everyone the source of the problem! As no one knew her, she just owned up and said it was her sister's and then sheepishly sloped off. After Sunday school we all ran home without talking to anyone.

The parishioners later were gossiping about the silly girl who brought a megaphone into church. I mean who would do a thing like that.

title.value: 3 Peaks Challenge - Mummy Caused Church Evacuation with Megaphone

info.content:
Whilst Daddy and the Elders were away doing the 3 peaks, Mummy looked after Toby, Lily and Joey. She took them to the RLC Army show at Deepcut. It was very hot. On the parade ground we saw motorbikes do a display. Toby loved that. We also had a go on the fairground for a bit. It was far too hot so came home shortly after.

Meanwhile Ben went with some Tomlinscoters up to Alton Towers. It was a trip for the well behaved. It was a reward for their efforts of the year. You didn't go unless you were a good boy or girl. Ben managed to go on just 4 rides, spending a lot of his afternoon in front of a big TV screen watching England beating Sweden in the World Cup quatre finals.

Back at home again, Mummy took us to the Hale Carnival with Ma Ma and Pop Pop.

Kaite at the RLC Army Show

title.value: RLC Army Show, Ben to Alton Towers, Hale Carnival, Elders overnight to stay

info.content:
Jessica competed in three running races. She was the final runner in the relay and won!

Jessica starting her race

The highs and lows of being a parent. In the evening we went to an awards ceremony at Tomlinscote School. Pupils from all years of the school were present to pick up awards from different subject area. There were just two awards for maths in year 8. Ben won his for attainment. A fantastic achievement. He went onto the stage and received the award from the Head Of Maths and from a guest speaker. Well done Ben we are very proud of you.

Ben receiving his award

The previous day, Ben was selected to go on a Maths and Computing exercise over in Crowthorne. He didn't enjoy it very much. He likes to be thought of as a geek, but does not like all the other geeks because they are too geeky. Now that's logic that no-one understands.

Over the past couple of months, Katie's weight and diet has become a concern. The lack of food intake has been minimal and what is being consumed has all been healthy stuff. She has been having fruit for breakfast, skipping lunch at school (because she hasn't time) and then not eating much for dinner. No snacks either. Today and last night it all came to a head, and Mummy took her down to the GPs where she was diagnosed with Anorexia. She is 43kg and her height is 163.5cm. The GP has referred her on, and in 2 weeks we have a follow up appointment for bloods. Katie does not like speaking about it and has been in denial about it. Today, however, she recognises there is an issue and is positive about resolving it. She loves 'planning' at the moment. So we popped to Hobbycraft and purchased a large piece of card. Katie has looked up meals and snacks that she would like and has written them on cards. So for each day of the following week she knows what she is going to have at breakfast, lunch and dinner. She also has a snack card. She seems quite determined to follow the plan. She says she feels a lot happier and that she has turned over a new leaf. This week at shopping she went around the supermarket and got all the ingredients for the menu's she has devised. We are very proud how she wants to turn this around.

title.value: Ben Top Of Year for Maths, Katie Anorexia

info.content:
In the morning we made an early start on this gloriously sunny summer's day. We made our way down to the Mytchett lake where we swum. Daddy came for the first time, and I think we'll leave him behind because he was so slow and struggled to do 500 metres. Katie and Mummy whizzed around. Jessica even beat Daddy back. It was a busy lake. There must have been over 100 swimmers during the morning.

Mytchett Mermaids and Mermen

After Mummy went to the early church service, we headed to Cookham, just the other side of Maidenhead for walk 101. Daddy loved his new walking boots. It was a very hot day. Katie has been converted to a walking lover, not a hater. DoE has changed her she said.

Holy Trinity Church, Cookham

As it was what we thought was to be the 100th walk we decided to stop off for lunch at the Bounty pub half way around. It was only later that Daddy miss-calculated (really it was walk 101). Just to think walk number one was completed on 31 December 2010. 7.5 years later we get to 101! The walks have larger been taken from a number of children's walking books: London, Surrey, Hampshire and Berkshire. We still have 21 to complete before all the walks have been done in all the books.

After passing some cows who took refreshment in the Thames, we finished the walk hot and bothered and needed to get home for some ice lollies and iced water.

We met cows who went for a swim

Daddy and Katie going through a farmers field

Route

title.value: Mytchett Mermaids and Mermen, Walk 101 - Cookham

info.content:
In the morning Daddy went with Ben to a very hot and well attended parkrun. 670 runners. They battled through the traffic and came in at 27 minutes.

Ellie was 40 today and to celebrate she hosted a BBQ with the invite list restricted to the Barnett family members. We had a good time playing in the back garden with the water. She got a Mini Clubman as a present from Michael!

After work Daddy went to Elstead and ran the 'marathon' for the 2nd time out of the 106 that have been run. The run includes some sandy parts and because of the exceptionally dry, hot weather. There were dust clouds as the leading runners passed. Daddy had to jump a gate, go over some very rough farmers ground and of course a splash across the River Wey. A cracking event, with a short pub trip after.

The river crossing

Liquid refreshment

It was the final group game for Denmark which they need to get a point in order to qualify. Daddy took half a day holiday and went around to the Fars house to watch the France game. Aftr school both Jessica and Ben arrived. It was a fairly drab match, but we enjoyed ourselves there.

Jessica not watching the game sharing a joke with Farmor

Mummy's 42nd Birthday. We started the day in bed opening presents and cards. From Daddy she got the weekend away in Flamingo Land. From Jessica she got a charm for an impending bracelet. Katie got some clothes. Auntie Susan some shorts and a top. The Fars a frying pan and a camping bucket thing. Ellie and Charlie a Pandora bracelet.

Birthday treats in bed

Ben made a treasure hunt where he hid 16 bars of chocolate around the back garden which Mummy had to seek out. Mummy had the day off, but didn't do anything special. In the evening she took us to trampolining whilst going to Palettes.

We had an early 5am departure from Frimley Green for our trip to Yorkshire. We made it for the 9:30 gate opening and plotted our route around the half theme park, half zoo. Jessica wanted to do her first upside down rides. Before now she has been too small, but the restrictions here were generous. She was tentative on the first ride, Hero where you lie on your front and get whisked around upside down. However, she managed to pluck the courage up and went on Mumbo Jumbo with Daddy and loved it. There was no stopping her now. We managed all the white knuckle rides, well except Daddy who couldn't take any spinning around. There were some firm favourites, like Velocity and Kumali. I don't think many enjoyed the high chair-o-plane ride.

Jessa looking beautiful

Posers in the park

In the afternoon we walked around the zoo bits. Mummy was fascinated with the hippos. We perched on a viewing platform so had excellent views of the hippos in and out of the water.

We took a cable car back to the main theme park, where Ben, Jess and Daddy went to play laser quest. Daddy went out within 5 minutes, Ben 7 minutes. Jess must have lasted 15+ minutes. I think her tactic was to hide and hide good. She was very proud of her achievement of lasting longest.

We scrabbled around in the last half hour to fit in as many rides as possible. It was a good day. A smallish park, witch was not packed out like a Thorpe Park and kept us entertained all day.

Real life Call Of Duty

We trundled off and stopped at Malton and ate Fish and Chips by the river. It was a glorious evening. We then had a 45 minute drive to Leeds where we had a hotel for the night. We were all fairly bushed. We watched the end of a very tense Sweden v Germany World Cup game.

Katie has arranged to do a week's work experience at Loseley Park. It is centred around events planning which is close to the wedding planning that Katie eventually would like to go in to. Today was her first day and she dressed appropriately, got there in time for the 9am start and began work! She was looking forward to the experience very much.

Katie just before work

Here tasks through out the week involved:

  • Monday: Group interview for front of house staff. All applicants passed. Katie did some data entry on employees profiles.
  • Tuesday: More data entry and a couple of meetings with couples who are having their wedding at Loseley Park. They were discussing menus and costs.
  • Wednesday: Serving guests in the tea room as well as more meetings.
  • Thursday: Bike BBQ where there was a lot of washing up and clearing of tables. There was also some office work on a computer. The accounts lady offered Katie a summer job!
  • Friday: Tours around the house itself.

Employers Report

Daddy woke and eventually he got some breakfast in bed!!! There were some presents floating about including some chocolate, veg crisps and a wallet to replace the one that Daddy dropped down the toilet whilst he was doing a poo!

Daddy

Us 3 stayed in and missed church. Auntie Charlotte popped by to pick Lenny up as we looked after him yesterday and overnight.

Daddy went on a long bike ride. He left without a plan and ended up having to rush back for 1pm. He managed 40 miles around the Bracknell and Windsor areas. He tested out his new rucksack in preparation for the 3 peaks.

Route

In the afternoon we all went to Petersfield to go strawberry picking with the Westons and Elders. We manage to eat as many strawberries in the field as we paid for. We got 2 punnets, had a cup of coffee, saw a load of posh people and made our way home.

Strawberry pickers

In the evening Daddy went off with Farfar to play croquet over at St Johns. Daddy won and played reasonably well, making some nice breaks. His hitting in was still a bit wayward. It was nice to see Barry Huxley who Daddy hasn't seen for over 20 years!

Dad playing Farfar at croquet

Daddy and Ben went off to parkrun and shifted around in slightly slower than average pace.

Ben beating Daddy at parkrun

There were four World Cup matches on today. The third of which was Denmark v Peru. And for that special reason we had Daddy's friends around for a World Cup BBQ, with WAGS. Daddy went out to Costco yesterday and got Â£180's worth of stuff.... which Mummy thought was excessive.

We had the usual food fare and the same level of mayhem with a mix of children running about. The boys tried to do keepy-upys. They were rubbish! They've certainly lost any talent they might had once had. We sort of watched the football. Denmark won 1-0. All the WAGS got on very well with each other.... in fact it was a lovely afternoon. We finished at about 10pm.

Carnage

title.value: parkrun, Denmark v Peru World Cup BBQ

info.content:
James poked his head into the tent at 3:30am. Martin you're up in 20 minutes. Great Daddy thought! It was a nice time, because it was the first lap where the torch was not needed. Dawn was breaking and the birds were twittering away. The third lap of Daddy's was slow again at 50 mins.

Ellie finished her lap and effectively her Endure24 2018 with another solid effort. She did a fantastic 15 miles. She said she enjoyed it enough to come back another year. Woo Hoo.

Although the knee was hurting Daddy had one more effort at around 10am. He felt he ought to do 4 laps otherwise would feel unfulfilled. He made amends with his relatively slow lap 2 and 3 efforts with a 46 minute 4th lap to complete 20 miles. He could barely walk after as he put so much effort in.

Daddy horsing around

We all crossed the line together as a team and collected our medals, had photos and went to take the tents down.

Overall a very enjoyable weekend. Ben wanted to come back and do more laps. Auntie Ellie wants to do it again....and Anthony enjoyed it. Jury is still out whether he wants in for 2019.

Lap 3 Lap 4

Daddy and Ben medalled

This year the Frimley Flyers entered 3 teams into the Glastonbury for runners. Yesterday Daddy and an army of tent erectors went to prepare the site for 30+ runners, friends and family. This year Daddy wasn't on is own. He had Ben, Auntie Ellie, Joey and his friend from work; Anthony.

Tent setup

Team lineup

Daddy and Ben arrived at about 11am, met up with everyone, made introductions, did the obligatory photo shoot and away the Flyers went.

Daddy smashed around the circuit in 43 minutes which was his quickest since 2015. He was happy with that, although there was still knee pain. Anthony went sub 40 minutes and Auntie Ellie threw in a steady 48 mins. Ben was desperate to run, however there was a bit of talk of disqualifying teams who raced with non registered runners. So we decided against it until night fall. At around 11pm Ben went out for his first ever 5 miles and first ever night run. Ellie guided him around in a time of 48 minutes. A really good time, better than Daddy's 50 minute night lap.

Lap 1 Lap 2

After showers, a chance to sleep at 1am. Unfortunately Joey tried to clean his knee with water in the tent above Daddy's sleeping bag. Needless to say Daddy had an uncomfortable, damp sleep. Uncomfortable because the knee was hurting bad.

Daddy Completing Lap 1

Night runner

Daddy managed to get Jessica and Mummy Â£25 Thorpe Park annual passes off Eagle Radio. So along with Ben and Alice Teale they headed to the Theme Park and enjoyed themselves for the day. Ben went around with his mates.

Meanwhile Katie was with the Teales and visited Brighton.... again! She was spoilt and was taken on the fair rides and shopped in the Lanes.

title.value: Teale Swap - Thorpe Park and Brighton

info.content:
We went out with the Burrows and Elders to Liquid Leisure which is a big water adventure park in Wraysbury.

Later Alice came over to us for a sleepover with Jessica, whilst Katie headed in the other direction and stayed with Summer overnight.

title.value: Water Inflatables with Burrows and Elders. Alice, Katie swap sleepover

info.content:
Written by Farfar

It was an early start on the Wednesday, but not as much as the outward journey, for our journey back to England. Graham and Susan took Jette to Thyregod railway station as she was going to Copenhagen to stay with Joan and Gert for their joint 70 birthday celebrations. The rest of us went direct, well via some country roads actually, to the airport for the 11.15 flight back to Blighty. It was delayed here and there which eventually put an extra hour on the clock but we all got home under a leaden sky mid afternoon, happy but exhausted. It had been quite an intense holiday, even if we were unable to experience the delights of RÃ¸rbÃ¦k SÃ¸!

Written by Farfar

It was wall to wall sun again on the Tuesday. Having run out of theme parks for the time being, we all went to Horsens, and the newly opened museum that once was a Victorian prison. It proved to be bigger and more comprehensive than first imagined. Katie was absolutely fascinated with the place. She has a thing for prisons at the moment.

Katie in Horsens Prison

Farmor's Uncle who worked at the prison

Tempting to drop her off

Later, we journeyed into the town and took in the shops. Ben and Martin though, hired a couple of âBoris Bikesâ at the prison and made their own way into town, but we met up for a while near the main square.

Route

Daddy and Ben Bike ride around Horsens

The next item on our itinerary was to swim in a lake. Jette had done this in Ejstrupholm So as a child but a repeat performance was not possible as there were too many reeds separating bank and water. We took a fifteen minute drive over to Hampen SÃ¸ which was suitable and the Frimley Green contingent took a dip, although Laura was uncertain about the experience after seeing fish swimming about. The lake was something akin to Frensham Pond but without the crowds.

Hampen Lake for a Mermaids outing

We stopped off at Ejstrupholm church and the Uhrskov stone for some photo oppotunities and see if we could spot any ancestors in the graveyard. There were some Uhrskovs and Hansens, but none rang a bell in the current family tree.

We then returned back to the house for a short while before rolling off again, almost back to the same place, but this time a little nearer, to the roadside cafÃ© for a full evening meal.

Ejstrupholm church

The Uhrskov Stone - don't look at the spelling!

When we went back to the house, a car was there when we arrived with Johanas sat in it. I did say that we would visit him during the day on the Tuesday but the Horsens trip, planned at short notice, thwarted that idea. Anyway, he suggested we might like to go to the airfield (that he formally owned) for a drink at its clubhouse. Thus, me Jette and Martin did for an hour and met half a dozen other people to watch the sun set over the heather in amiable conversation. It turned out one couple had stayed in Deepcut when the Farnborough air show was on a little while back. The place again threw up move coincidences.

Meeting Johanas

title.value: Denmark Day 4 - Horsens Prison, Bike Ride, Hampen Lake Swim, Airstrip Johanas

info.content:
Written by Farfar

Monday morning broke with yet more sunshine. This time the journey was not so far as we went back to Billund, this time to Legoland. We set out a little later than planned and arrived soon after opening time. All nine of us stayed until the six oâclock closing time and ran out of minutes to fit all the rides as they stopped at five. The place was quite busy but with hardly any queues for the rides. Not all the adults went on with the kids, but most were represented by one or other of the older generation.

The highlights were the aquarium where we saw a shark close up as well as manta rays. We even got to get tickled by a shrimp! The Lego cars were eagerly awaited and didn't disappoint. Katie was an expert at pulling off a u'ie without notice, Ben an expert at looking cool and easy and Jessica loved a good car wash and petrol station visit. There was the River Tyre ride which Daddy got soaked on (see video) and possibly the most exhilarating rides were at the end of the day. Mummy said the Polar Express rollercoaster ride was the best she's been on, whilst Ben absolutely loved the Ice Pilots School where you could design your own ride. Sounds a bit bonkers. Anyway overall a good visit.

Legoland - Billund

Katie swimming in the aquarium

Jessica stuck in the aquarium

Tickled by the shrimp

Lego Millennium Falcon

Beautiful smile

Trouble on the roads. Evacuate!

Legal to drive now

Log Flume ride

Fars join us for the rapid river drop

Billund Airport

The evening was spent back at base playing board games or watching the television which was dominated by football. Jette and I went for a walk around Ejustrupholm which, as expected, was pretty well deserted. However, I was pleased with myself after conducting a ten minute conversation alone, entirely in Danish with a local man who was walking his dog. Martin came too and, in the meanwhile, tested out his knee with a 5K run around the village.

Route

Written by Farfar

Sunday morning dawned full of sun. An isolated rain storm was forecast but none were encountered at any time. This time we set off for the Summerland Theme Park near Randers. The journey, at a little over two hours. Rather than run along the motorway for most of the miles, I wanted to take a more picturesque route via Silkeborg, but one route was closed so we had to divert along country lanes and there was more holiday traffic on the roads than expected. We got there a little before noon.

They were delighted to see the queue times were very low. There was the usual fill of rollercoaster rides, however it was the other bits and pieces that made this different. The family quad cycles, the 50 or so trampolines, the air cushion, the basketball, the canoeing around a lake. They were there right to the end at 6pm.

High risers

Drive by

Log flumes

Canoeing

Written by Farfar.

This was a gathering of the clan in that Martin, Laura, Susan, Graham, Katie, Jessica and Ben joined me and Jette for a four night foray into deepest Denmark; to Ejstrupholm to be precise. We all traveled together on the 7.45am flight from T5 at Heathrow to Billund which meant a really early start from our respective homes, but we all made it on time. The day was bright and flight smooth, if a little noisy as it appeared to be doubling up as the âLegoland Special.â We touched down on time at around 10.30 (Danish time) then spent an eternity queuing to go through passport control. There were only two positions available which was obviously inadequate.

That hurdle passed, our next task was to collect our vehicles. Susan and Graham had their own Merc but the rest of us had to do with a more functional nine seater âbus,â but one that did the job admirably well throughout our stay that stretched over four nights. We set off into the sunshine to the nearby town Grinsted and arrived to a near deserted town centre soon after noon to seek a cafe for lunch. A walk through the main street, popping into what shops were open (most close at one oâclock on a Saturday in Denmark), brought us to a highly suitable eatery where we sat outside in the sunshine for a varied lunch.

Katie and the church in Grinsted

Thus sated, our next task was to stock up with provisions which we managed at the Kvickly supermarket (in contrast, they stay open all hours) in the town of Brande, five miles from our destination. Beer, of course, was an important item in the inventory, along with sufficient food to get us through the weekend. Arrival at our destination was effected by about two thirty which gave us an hour to settle in before our first event.

The accommodation was at the Damgard B and B on Fasterholt Vej, set back 200 yards or so, just outside Ejustrupholm. It was an annex of a former farm and set in many acres of land that could be explored. Downstairs, it consisted of a utility room, kitchen, living room, one bedroom and a bathroom, all of generous size and well appointed. Upstairs lay a large landing, a room in itself, a bathroom, two ânormalâ bedrooms and a large family bedroom. There was heaps of room all round.

Our first adventure, the Lego House, beckoned for we had tickets for a 4.00pm entry. Billund, direct, took a smidgen over half hour. Our time at Lego House was the full four hours and proved to be very entertaining for all of us. Favourites were the Stock photo filming, car racing and fish designing as well as marveling at all the Lego villages, dinosaurs, trees, etc.

Making a Lego stock movie

Lego Dinosaurs

Tonight was the Mytchett Athletic FC Presentation evening. Daddy presented the boys with trophies. Abe won the Player's Player and Supporters Player of the year awards. Charlie got Manager's Player. Daddy got a load of beers and a trophy.

Jessica was picked for the school cricket team who played in a Surrey Heath schools tournament over at the Marconi recreation ground. Jessica's team came second out of six and enjoyed it enough to continue play cricket at school.

Jessica chasing the runs

We split up as a family today. First off was mummy who had to go to some church meeting in Windlesham, Daddy rode his bike on a 12 mile Blackwater River ramble which took in the parkrun at Rushmoor - he supported his fellow Frimley Flyers.

Ma Ma, Pop Pop and Grandma all came over for a Royal Wedding BBQ.

Farfar got FA Cup tickets through Chertsey Town FC. There was some debate whether Daddy or Farfar was going to accompany Ben into the ground. All three traveled to the greasy spoon in Hillingdon before moving onto the stadium. There was aobut 90,000 spectators. Farfar took Ben into the Man Utd end. Daddy watched the game outside and enjoyed sitting against the stadium listening to the radio commentary. He had a luck escape as the game itself was very drab and disappointing. Chelsea beat Man Utd 1-0.

In Wembley Stadium

Flying the red flag in vain

Jessica went swimming with Ma Ma in the afternoon.

In the evening Mummy and Katie went to the Maisey's for a Murder Mystery party.

Mysterious murderers

title.value: FA Cup Final, Royal Wedding, Maisey Murder Mystery, Swimming

info.content:
Jessica and Mummy, joined Natasha and Lily for the mermaids second outing at the Keys. They had good fun.

Daddy went off to do his coaching course again at Winston Churchill school. The third of six sessions done. More of the same. Planning and carrying out coaching sessions.

The rest of us went to the cinema in the afternoon.

Mermaids

title.value: More Mermaids, FA Coaching course, cinema

info.content:
In the morning Daddy who is injured, volunteered at parkrun. It was hard for him not to run. Farfar however, did run!

Farfar running!

Katie and Ben went with Catherine and Johnny down to Brighton to stay in the family static caravan for the night. They shopped and bought quite a few items of clothes. They also had some nice food in subwway and KFC. The weather wasn't great so they didn't make much use of the beach.

Katie, Ben, Johnny and Catherine playing in Brighton

In the evening Jessica decided she was going to do Bake Off, but got confused with Come Dine With Me. Earlier in the afternoon she went out with Mummy to get all the ingredients she needed for her 3 course meal. She was so sweet as she wanted to keep it a secret and do all the cooking herself..... she even made a colourful menu up. For starters she made soup, mains was home made potato chips, chicken breast, sweetcorn and cucumber. Pudding was Eton mess. Very well executed. We even got a glass of hot chocolate!

Jessica cooked dinner

Jessica and Mummy slept in the tent for a second night.... although at about 3am they came inside as they got scared and decided to punish Daddy by drawing makeup on his face. Daddy had the last laugh though, as he woke secretly and ROARed at them when they least expected it. It didn't do much for Mummy's anxiety!

title.value: Katie and Ben Over nighter in Brighton, Jess cooking and back garden camper

info.content:
In the evening Mummy and Jessica setup the tent in the back garden and slept all night in there.

Daddy headed down to the Prince Of Wales in North Farnborough and met up with Nick, Phil, Martin and Barrie. Nick announced he was getting married at the end of the month.

Nick looking on as Barrie opens Christmas and Birthday cards

Hopefully, the traditionally participation of the Windle Valley Pairs 10km event which we entered two teams into. Team 1 the seniors, Mummy and Daddy. Team 2 the juniors, Ben and Katie. There was some competition as Daddy and Ben were roughly equal and the girls were largely an unknown quantity. The girls set off first from Windlesham Memorial field and headed off down towards the playground. The race was a relay with 1km intervals. Each person did 5x1km. Sounds easy, but in fact very hard, as you are killing yourself 5 times.

Katie came around the first lap before mummy which condemned the old'uns to a loss. However, everyone did very well. Daddy unfortunately picked up an injury which really only became apparent the day after when he could barely walk. It was the cartilage in his left knee again! Well done fam. You did amazing. Same again next year.

Katie handing over to Ben

The Gallivanting Gays

Another boiling hot day and another early departure from chez Gay, this time heading north to Warwick Castle.

We arrived and had a long walk from the carpark to the main entrance. The castle looked impressive. There was plenty to do. We saw the old fashioned cannon / catapult in action which was interesting. We also had a small guided tour looking at the owners and how scathing they were. We then walked around the ramparts and towers in the castle, saw the gaol, the time tunnel and watched the archery. Inter-family rivalry was rife in the maze. Claim and counter claim who the real winner was, was debated hard! We were exhausted from all the walking around in the heat and the ups and downs.

The gang one of the regal rooms

Katie with her armour

The gang again infront of the main castle quatres

In the keep

Send them to the tower

From up high

We made our way down to visit the Elders for Michael's 40th birthday BBQ. Ma Ma and Pop Pop were also there. Lovely BBQ punctured by Henry being sick multiple times. We got Michael a track day experience driving 3 super cars around his favourite circuit, Brands Hatch. A nice time had by all. A fitting end to an exhausting bank holiday weekend.

Jessica waterfall

Early doors and Mummy and Jessica went off for their open water swim at Mytchett.

In the afternoon Ben and Mummy went to the cinema to watch Infinity Wars.

Daddy started his FA football coaching course. It was an all day event. There must have been 15 or so students at Winston Churchill school in Knaphill. It was another boiling hot day and half of the tutoring was done outside - this gave Daddy a bit of a tan!

Meanwhile the rest of us went to church and church club

title.value: Mermaids, FA Coaching Course, Inifinity Wars

info.content:
We had a busy day. There was just four of us waking up in the house. Katie was away in the east part of Surrey doing her Duke Of Edinburgh award hike.

We headed up to London, starting at Gunnersbury and the parkrun. Ben and Daddy were going to take it easy, but when do we ever believe that. There is only one gear, and that's full throttle. They were pleased with their sub 25 minute performance. Meanwhile Jessica and Mummy played hide and seek around the playground area. Route

They moved on in the sweltering heat to the underground station and headed to Southwark. A short walk near the Shard and onto the Clink. London's private jail it seemed for the area owned by the Bishop of Winchester. It sounded like the owners were as crocked as the inmates. There were many tales of torture. Jessica and Ben were pleasantly surprised with it. It must have consumed 90 minutes of our time. Next up lunch and a tour around the nearby Borough market. Ben and Mummy got a scrummy pie and Daddy some expensive bread. They were selling doughnuts, 4 for Â£10! Somewhere to come back to one day. We sat and ate by the Golden Hind.

The Shard

In the chair

Inprisoned
