To tough with a princess, so back tracking up the river they decided to get out just before the pub onto someone's land. Daddy walked to the house when a neighbour stopped him and grilled him before allowing them to pass through and drop off all the lifejackets, bag, paddles, etc. When they returned to get the kayak a different neighbour came out and mentioned it was private land and the problems they have with trespasses. Again Daddy managed to be subservient enough to get away with it.

In the afternoon Ma ma, Pop Pop and great Grandma came over to watch the Frimley Green Carnival procession. Later Jessica performed with Liberty Gym on the green to the masses. She did very well.

Jessica in her gym display at Frimley Carnival

Later in the afternoon Ben went to Freddie's football birthday party.

title.value: Daddy's 41st Birthday, Frimley Green Carnival, Freddie's birthday party

info.content:
After a slow-ish parkrun, we headed off to Henley for firstly a picnic by the river, then an hours playing on a motorboat. Unknown to us the Henley Festival was on, which I think encompasses the Regatta. Anyway all us children had a go on the steering wheel. It was good fun going up as far as the lock one way, then where the races ended the other.

Picnic by the River in Henley

Motor boating on the Thames at Henley

Today's driver is Jessica

In the evening Daddy went out to the Aviator in Farnborough for Emma's 45th birthday. The hotel was very plush. We got a disturbing insight into Chris's psyche, concerning old body parts!

Ben had a cinema party at Magnus's, Jessica also had a party.

Meanwhile Katie was taken out with the Teales to Southend on Sea.... and again more fairground stuff. Katie had a great time and gets on so well with Summer.

In the morning Daddy and Ben went to parkrun and completed an average run. At lunch Daddy did a BBQ and the Teales joined us for some charcoaled food. The weather was showery mixed in with sunshine as we headed up to Deepcut and the army show. The usual fair, however, the weather got in the way. Still the rope over the water was the highlight. Ben scrambled across quickly and confidently. Jessica went across bravely. You could see that she was a bit scared and was hurting her. The fairground rides was pretty much all the kiddies were after.

Ben doing the rope bridge

Jessica doing the rope bridge

In the evening Mummy went off to the Dartford Taverna for Auntie Charlottes Bacheloress party (Hen Night).

Chardo

The Westons

title.value: RLC Army Show with Teales, Charlotte Hen Night

info.content:
It's not really a marathon. However, the 5.5 mile course has a variety of ground from bogs, sand, tarmac, mud and even a river crossing - yes wet feet. Daddy also had some sunshine and rain. Good fun.

Elstead Marathon
Ben and his friend Olifer auditioned for Frimley CofE Got talent contest. He's written a song which they are performing. They won through to the finals. Well done Ben.

title.value: Ben auditions in Frimley's Got Talent

info.content: Jessica's brownie pack / troop went to Cedar Lodge and sang some Brownie Songs to the old folk.

title.value: Jessica sings at old people's home

info.content:
After church we headed off to Brooklands Community Park for a family picnic with the Weston's, Barnett's and Gay's. Mummy got a load more presents, including one from Steven and Matt which was a trip to see the Bodygaurd at the theatre in London and an Aston Martin experience from Autnie Susan and the Fars and a tent from Ma Ma.

Mummy looking beautiful

Firework on the cake!

Today it was actually Mummy's 40th birthday. We woke in the hotel room and Mummy opened her cards and presents. She got 50 pounds Primark vouchers from Great Grandma, a lovely 'Laura' book from Helen, a neck garment from Fiona, some earrings, a necklace with our names on it from Daddy, a purse from Ben, and a set of pyjamas from Jessica.

Croissants and strawberries for breakfast. Daddy and Ben went off to do the local parkrun. The 26th different parkrun! Ben was blocked off a couple of times when he tried to overtake this older boy. Not very nice. Daddy had to have a word. Anyway they cut through a golf course. Maybe the first 5km lap course.

A quick shower and an argument with a busy body stopping us from waiting in a disabled parking zone later and we were away towards Bourneville and Cadbury's World.

We just about made it for the 11am start, and instantly 15 bars of chocolate were planted in Daddy's lap. Great! There were a number of sections throughout the factory, from the history of cocoa and Cadbury's, to live chocolate making, packaging and advertising. Both us and the 'elderlies' (as Jessica now calls Mummy and Daddy) enjoyed it equally. A picnic later and we queued for the 4D cinema and magic show. A really good day out for Â£56.

History of chocolate section

Chocolate with choice of toppings! Heaven.

Mirror, mirror on the wall who is the most beautiful of them all

Chocolate electric guitar

Family chocolate shot

Chocolate drops

A long trek home arriving just in time to watch the end of the Wales and Northern Ireland game. The Fars later popped over to give part of their present, a hanging basket. A good day

Daddy took a half day and prepared for the journey up to Leamington Spa. We headed up on to the M40 after school and got to Leamington Spa about 7pm. It was kind of a surprise. Jessica revelled in the fact she knew where we were going, but Mummy didn't. Daddy had looked up this cool pizza restaurant which was a bit different to the usual setting. We sat down in the basement and munched on pizza, chips and mummy even had a cheeky beer. We walked the scenic route back to our hotel which was right in the middle of town, next to the pump rooms. We had a lovely evening just the five of us.

Leamington town

Basement Browns

Bridge over the River Leam

Striding past the pump rooms
For Farfar's Father's Day present Daddy booked a Hogs Back Brewery tour. It was a really good evening spent. Interesting what the tour guide had to say, and nice beer to boot.

We hosted a number of Daddy's friends for the final group game, England v Slovakia. Daddy was on the BBQ tongs. It was good to see a mix of Casuals friends and parkrun friends. The game itself was dire 0-0 draw. But we are through to the next round. Atendees: James and Duncan Ball, Chris Peddle, Woody, Bob, Alasdair, Nick King, Phil Roe, Martin Aves, Michael and Joey Elder.

In the morning we woke and gave Daddy his Father's Day presents. A bottle of alcoholic ginger beer from Katie and a Star Wars t-shirt from Ben. Jessica was away still on Brownie Camp. After croissants in bed, Daddy, Katie and Ben went over to the Fars to wish him happy fathers day. We played a game of Danish Kings in the back garden which was tactical. Katie made a big 'Summer' poster.

Meanwhile Mummy was at church and Daddy left the children to go and collect Jessica from Brownie camp in Elstead. She had a great time.

We all reconvened and headed off to the Pick Your Own place in Addlestone. Eat one strawberry, put one in the punnet. Â£15 later and we had 3 punnets of sumptuous strawberries.

Strawberry picking

We then trailed over to Reigate Park to meet up with Ma Ma and Pop Pop. We played on the swings and had a late afternoon picnic. All three dads met.

Our fathers

Jessica was sort of looking forward to Brownie Camp. She wanted to be at home for father's day. However, she was looking forward to the Alice In Wonderland themed trip away. She stayed overnight.

Scarecrow fair

In the evening Mummy was taken out by Paula, Lindsey and Sylvie to Zizi's in Camberley for a birthday meal.

The girls

Mummy loves cake

title.value: Jessica on Brownie Camp, Pirbright Scarecrow Fair, Birthday Meal

info.content:
Today Ben left at 5:30am for his school's trip to France. We are all very sad. Ben is very excited.

13th June

We arrived at Le Manoir at around 6pm French time, after a long day travelling. There was lots of entertainment on the ferry to keep the children occupied, including a limbo competition! After settling in, we had a lovely (and very filling) dinner and we are now sat outside shivering and windswept while the children blow off some steam! I'm looking forward to bedtime.....

14 June

Lovely morning exploring the picturesque town of St Malo - the children spoke French very well when buying their delicious ice creams, although some had eyes bigger than their stomachs (deux boules s'il vous plait)! We then had a picnic lunch on the coach as there was a downpour, followed by a fun afternoon in the aquarium! Bit of downtime and diary writing now, with some play time before dinner and much needed tea/coffee for the adults!

St Malo

15 June

Lovely sunny morning for a trip around the bay on an open top boat; picnic lunch back at the centre, followed by a trip to the beach - we are optimists! We got rained on in a heavy shower, but luckily it calmed down and we had a pleasant afternoon! ?? Find the wallies in the photo....

Ben at the front

16 June

Lovely morning shopping at Dinan Market and strolling around the town, followed by an afternoon of outdoor games in beautiful sunshine. A quick trip to the supermarket followed that (sorry, they headed straight for the confectionary aisle!) and we are now packing and having some down time after a lovely traditional dinner from the region.

Daddy started Sunday at 2:05am with a night time run with torch. The night time run was 3 minutes slower than the previous two laps. It was quite nice to run at night, giving a different perspective on the course. So nice and quiet.

The rain woke Daddy up in the tent at about 5:30am. A few others were about. The fourth and final run completed in 47 minutes again and Daddy was done! Great atmosphere between the Flyers. Really nice to have them around. Wouldn't do it otherwise. We had some debutants. We also had Richard and Hannah going around as solo athletes! Unbelievable. We collected our medal, packed the tents away, said our fairwells.

The krew

Parade lap at the end

Team line up

Daddy then had to motorbike over to Leatherhead over an hour away to meet us for the Little Welly event. However, due to the lack of sleep and weekend's exerts he was beginning to fall asleep at the wheel of the motorbike. So decided to turn off at the next junction, Slough and found a grass verge outside the Marriott hotel to have a little kip. Waking 20 minutes later, the motorbike had a flat battery and after calling the breakdown van found out it was a charging fault. So it was bundled into the back of the van, Aldershot bound!

Meanwhile the rest of us met up with Joey for the Little Welly event at Bockett's Farm. It was a 2 mile assault course for children. Ben proudly won. However, the others did not treat it as a race. There were A frames to climb over, cargo nets to crawl under, mud baths to tackle and a foam pool. Over 20 obstacles. It was great fun!

Starting off with the hay bail challenge

The slide after the mud bath

The final foam pit

In the morning Daddy and Ben went to Rushmoor parkrun as Frimley Lodge was shut due to the travellers lurking around in the area. Ben does not like the Rushmoor circuit too much.

Jessica went to a birthday party in the morning.

After the 3 mile, 27 minute jog, Daddy went off to Wasing Park for this years Endure 24. Another two Frimley Flyers teams. Basically the team participates in a relay race around a 5 mile circuit, for 24 hours non-stop, midday Saturday to midday Sunday. On average each team member will complete 4 laps, 20 miles, doing one lap in the dark! The venue itself boasts many tents for massages, food, sports clothing and this year a massive TV screen.... needed for the Euro 16 matches. Daddy was sharing a tent with Alasdair again, who kindly put it up the day before. A star.

We all came over to see Daddy complete his first lap at about 3:30pm. He was being chased by a man with a sword! He completed his first lap in 43 minutes in warm, muggy conditions. After a tour of camp we went back home, leaving Daddy to complete his 2nd lap whilst the England game was on!

Capture the Saturday

The krew

Looking fresh at the start

title.value: parkrun, Jess at party, Endure24 Day 1

info.content:
Today we had fibre installed via Virgin. Hopefully satisfy our growing needs!

Also had motorbike MOT, Katie's sports day and Daddy ill. Katie's team won the event although she did not win her races (300m and 100 metre relay).

Katie in full flow

Sitting in the finishers area

After church we headed over to the other side of Surrey, first collecting Katie who had a sleepover at Summer Teales. They are very good friends. Outwood is 5 miles south of Godstone. The weather was vey warm. We had a picnic as soon as we arrived, then proceeded on a 3 mile walk, mainly through farmers fields it seemed. It was very nice to be just the five of us - us kiddies got on well together.

Picnic

Jessica enjoying chocolate cake

A kiss for the kissing gate

Daddy and big boys

Summer strolling through farmers fields

Old Oak
We went with the girls crew to Thorpe Park, taking Summer with us. Ben is just about 1.4m tall, so could go on all the cool rides which he absolutely loved.

Half term week and we went off to Margate for a 11am kickoff at Dreamland, which used to be the Benborn Brothers Amusement Park. We met with the Borrows and Morleys. Daddy came along for the ride as he thought it was different to the normal theme parks. Mummy and Daddy went there once before they were married.

For June it was flipping freezing. It felt like October. No matter, the rain just about held off which was the most important thing and the weather actually probably worked in our favour as it might have kept more people from coming. The kiddies were determined to go on everything they could... and they pretty much did. Quite a few of the amusements were shut, either because of maitenance or staff shortages. The rollercoaster was not running because of the wood expanding in the damp conditions!Still we had a good time on what was open. One of the favourites was the Spinning 'Barrel of laughs' ride.

In Dreamland

We headed inside for a bit and went on the Roller Disco, some showing better moves than others. Mummy thought she was the bees knees.

Natasha, Daddy and Katie on the Big Wheel

Girls Roller Discoing

The Two Spins was the adults favourite, whilst most of the thrill seeker children liked the Barrel of Laughs ride the most. On the way home we stopped off for Sausage and Chips. Summer came over for a sleepover which made Katie very happy.

After church, we embarked on day 2 of our Basingstoke Canal journey, this time the enthusiasm was quite low amongst the younger generation. A raise of the saddle and Jessica was zooming and no problem with her happiness levels. Every person she passed were greeted with a 'hello, thank you and goodbye' in a Jessica, jolly voice. As Daddy was behind, he managed to capture the laughter reaction!

Katie at Deepcut lock

Daddy's favourite part of canal is probably the stretch between Deepcut and St John's. Some picture postcard scenes especially with the sun beating down on to the trees and canal. A lovely sight. Then trouble struck. A Canadian Goose and his young family sat in the path and were not intending to move. He actually ran 10 metres down the canal chasing Daddy, who was as brave as a 'no very brave' person and backed right off. So we had to go back to the last bridge and go on to the other side of the canal!

Ben scooting on down

We stopped at St Johns for a picnic beside the canal, before continuing on again to Goldsworth Park and an expensive Beefeater, where we stopped for Coke and chips! On the other side of Woking we stopped again at the playground and bike halfpipe.

Woking playground

Ben was not feeling too well, so we scotted along to the end at Byfleet and by far the ugliest view of the whole trip. The M25 motorway, a nasty looking bridge and scrubland! Still we made it. well done all.

The end at Byfleet

We cycled onto Byfleet and New Haw station and caught a train back to Farnborough Main and rode home and collapsed in front of the TV!

Ben and Daddy parkrunned, without initially putting any efforts towards a Ben pb. However, after 3km Ben streaked away and came in with a new 23:57 pb - 40 seconds ahead of Daddy! Well done Ben.

Ben's Rio moment

As a family we decided we were going to cycle the length of the Basingstoke Canal over 2 days. Fortunately we live near the middle of the canal so day 1 was heading west towards Basingstoke. Enthusiasm was buoyed by the promise of pub stops and ice creams. First stop was the Mytchett Canal centre where we met with the parkrun crew and our first set of ice creams.

Next stop was the Swan in Ash Vale. At this rate Daddy was going to be bankrupt and it'll take till midnight to reach our destination! Fortunately we picked up a bit of momentum and reached our picnic destination in Pyestock before moving on. Bottoms were getting sore, but us children got on. Jessica did especially well considering the bike she has and the lack of gear changing. One more pub stop at the Fox and Hounds, Church Crookham before making the long picturesque ride to Odiham. We stopped off at an old pill box. Only some were brave enough to enter. The castle never to seem to come. Eventually we stopped off where Daddy spilt water all over his trousers. It look liked he wet himself! Greywell tunnel was reached finally. A sense of relief and achievement when we got there.

Mumma and Daddy

Katie at bridge

The crew towpathing it down the canal

Odiham Castle. Jessica's roll can be seen!

Greywell Tunnel

We had a couple of miles cycle on to Hook railway station. We bought in supplies and had a BBQ when we got home! We were all ready for Britain's Got Talent and Champions League finals.

title.value: Ben parkrun PB, Basingstoke Canal Ride (West)

info.content:
We had one last go in the swimming pool before a frantic clean-up, bacon and egg baps for breakfast and of course the farewell photo.

The Weston's

We end our weekend by going to Avon Heath Country Park, where we played on the playground, went for a walk and had a picnic. Daddy had decided to bike from the house and took ages. He tried to take a risky shortcut, climbed over fences with a bike, crossed the busy A338 (cars beeping) and got lost! He eventually found us!

The trip ended fittingly with a burst of rain, everyone ran for cover into their cars and sailed off home.

Later in the afternoon we went around to the Fars and played Coppitt.

title.value: Shobley Retreat - Day 3 - Avon Heath Country Park, Fars

info.content:
The weather wasn't great today, however, that did not deter at least the adults from venturing out. First up was the Moors Valley parkrun which was unusual in that it was a single 5km loop in the country park.

Moors Valley parkrunners

Daddy and Michael took Lennie for a walk out in the rain and the New Forest. It was a lovely ride, not seeing another sole for an hour or so. Lennie loved it.

New Forest Bike Ride with Lennie and Michael

Later all the adults went for a walk. The children surprisingly didn't want to. They just wanted to live in the swimming pool.

Mummy and Daddy walking in the rain

Later in the afternoon we watched the FA Cup final and Britain's Got Talent and some of us got into bed with Ma Ma and Pop Pop and played some funny games.

7 in a bed, roll over, roll over

We decided as it was Charlotte's 30th and Mummy's 40th that we all go and spend a family weekend away in a big house on the edge of the New Forest. So a million pound house was selected with an indoor swimming pool. The children mostly played in the swimming pool with the odd game of football chucked in.

Living in the swimming pool

Happy eaters

In the morning we went off to church. Mummy was leader today for the 4 to 7 year olds, which meant we all got out of church as well.

Meanwhile Daddy had arranged a Rockets ride for the Mallorca crew around the Dilley Lane loop. Lovely ride ending in Hartley Whitney for a coffee.

The Rockets

In the afternoon we had Theo's birthday party which we were contemplating boycotting due to some of the issues we have with Theo. More out of pity for the parents we allowed Ben to go to the Kayaking party at the Kingfisher lake. The rest of us, plus Natasha biked down shortly afterwards and enjoyed mucking about in the sun.

In the morning we were set for Ben getting a PB after the cock up at Winchester last week. It was almost expected he was going to break 24:52. James joined us on the run, and we were in a 'PB train'. Woo Hoo. First km, was 5:04.... outside the pace, however, we had negative splits all the way to the finish, ending on a 4:27 final km. Finish time was 23:59, taking a massive chunk out of the pb. Well done Ben

We of course went to the cafÃ© afterwards and drank the well earnt Rio!

Rio jump shot! Woo Hoo.

Ben chatting with the other Flyers

We didn't have long until we had to get ready for Pip and Stephen's wedding in Farnham. Pip is a friend we've known since Ben's Pre School days. Ben and Jasper are friends as well as Mummy and Pip often meeting up now in holidays since Pip has moved to Wrecclesham. We also see each other at parkrun occasionally.

The wedding itself was at St Andrews in Farnham.

Ceremony over, march out of church

Family Shot

Katie and Daddy

After the ceremony was slunk off back home for a bit before returning for the evening do where Mummy was enjoying her dancing!

Mumma and a Dadda

Disco Dancers

title.value: Ben parkrun PB - Pip and Stephen Wedding

info.content:
Mummy - How hard can it be, a parkrun with 5 rests in between?

The Windlesham Pairs event was held at the memorial field where there were 123 pairs who alternately run a 1km loop. 5km in total for each person. There were fears how seriously this was taken and whether Mummy and Daddy would come last. Mummy lead out the first leg at a quick pace, but blew up after about 200 metres and found the other 800 metres tough! The baton handed over to Daddy who set off. The course deceptively was all up hill! Anyway Daddy completed his 5x1km's all within 6 seconds of each other, 4:45/km-ish.

Mummy did ever so well considering she blew up so early. Good determination. They finished 93rd out of 123, which was respectable, seeing Mummy has done relatively zero training.

Mumma sporting her sporty look

Team GAY

The Flyers group shot

This week Ben is doing his SATS. We are all fairly relaxed and chilled about it. Ben has been additional practice papers at home. At school he came top of the year for maths achieving 159 out of 160. The one he got wrong was genuine not knowing the answer, rather than making a mistake. Good luck Ben.

The girls stayed up late again last night playing Sims 3, despite having Sims 4! In the morning Daddy fixed up Ben's bike once and for all, learning how to adjust the brake blocks finally.

Because there was not enough room in the car, Daddy cycled over to Guildford where we went swimming at the Spectrum. I say swimming. Ben spent much of the time on the 5 metre diving board. Katie and Summer went off together and Jessica was doing forward somersaults off the 1 metre board, much to Daddy's delight, as well as jumping off the 3 metre board. She did try 5 metres, but peering down she lost her nerve and came back again. After, we returned Summer back to her mum, came home and relaxed.

Summer is stayed over this weekend. Jessica went over to the Teale household last night for a sleepover also. We got up early in the morning and all headed down to Winchester for the parkrun. Katie and Summer decided to join in, however they walked and posed a lot! Ben and Daddy went around the 3 lap course at a good pace. Come the 4km marker, Ben left Daddy for dust and gained a 30 seconds lead or so. Ben was set to smash his pb. However, when it came to the last 200 metres he went the wrong direction and hadn't noticed the detour to the finish line. In the end Ben finished 2 seconds outside his pb, despite running for an additional 30 seconds minimum. Ben was gutted and was reduced to tears given the amount of effort he had put in. Next week Ben.

We continued down to Bournemouth. The weather was top notch. Really summer, low 20's centigrade. The girls demanded a shopping spree, so they were given some money and 2 hours to wander around the shops. Boots and Primark seemed the longest stops. Meanwhile, Mummy, Daddy and Ben parked the car up out of town (Cavendish Road) and took a nice walk in, visited some surf and sports shops and had a milkshake from Shakeaway. A very nice relaxing time.

In the afternoon we went to Charlotte's house where Loz was cooking up a nice BBQ for us and family. We got our Jessica back again as Ma Ma and Pop Pop brought her over from the Teale's.

We went over to the park for a bit of a play, after which we played PiÃ±ata... which had no sweets in the middle. Loz's Dad's Dog, Lenny was there and it's the first time both Katie, Mummy and Jessica have all warmed to a dog. He was so placid and well behaved.

Jessica with Lenny

Mummy and Jessica went home with Ma Ma and Pop Pop, whilst the rest of us went down to Boscombe beach for a bit. We played in the sea, did a bit of sunbathing, pier walking and rock climbing. We ended the day with some fish and chips.

Katie and Summer entering Boscombe Beach

Playing in the sea

Ben on the rock

Cruising down the beach

Here is the result of our blogging from today's shopping trip...

Jessica has been complaining about getting headaches, dizzy spells and blacking out. So after a doctor's referral she went to see the optician. He said that he could see a disc on the images of both eyes which has caused some anxiety. Jessica has been referred to a Ophthalmologist.
Katie has achieved a forward flip. When Daddy came to pick her up, she demonstrated and it looked perfect. No stumbling, just a graceful landing. Katie is really enjoying trampolining.

As part of promoting children playing sports and opportunity has arisen for Ben to play squash. The first week he was rubbish (so Ben confessed), this week he said he wasn't the worst and was starting to be able to hit the ball. Before the session he was reluctant to go, but now he has a little more motivation.

We had stayed over in Istead Rise but without Ma Ma and Pop Pop, so only had a short trip to Stansted for the Cloisters ride. Again we met with the Burrows, along with Fi's Dad, Jo, Bert and little Oliver. Mummy and Jessica went off to Bluewater to do some shopping. Mummy bought a dress for a couple of weddings.

Ben going up Longfield hill

Katie scootering along

Fi enjoying herself

In the morning we went to Frimley Park Hospital to compete in the series of runs. First the 2.5km race which all but Daddy ran. Ben came in first in a shade under 12 minutes. Katie came back enthusiastically saying she could have run quicker. Next Daddy's 10km event which he done better than expected, coming in at 48:13.

Katie and Ben showing their medals

Jessica sprint finish

The Fars came to watch. The next door neighbour, Ian Bailey, won the 10km event and Ethan Yewings won the 2.5km event. The Fars walked home with us.

In the afternoon we popped over to Gillingham for Helen's 40 birthday party. She had plenty of people over. The weather was nice so played in the back garden with the Burrows family.

Happy birthday Helen

In the morning we scooted over to Queen Elizabeth park near Petersfield where Daddy and Ben ran the very hilly parkrun. It was good weather and some nice scenery.

After we met with Ellie, Lily and Toby for walk 80 in West Meon.

We then went back to their house and had a nice BBQ and catch up.

Jessica

Jump shot

Benna

title.value: Queen Elizabeth parkrun, Walk 80: West Meon, Elder BBQ

info.content:
I got up at 6:40am had a massive bowl of porridge, no tea for a change. Katie was nervous about coming to London because of the crowds and fear of a terrorist attack. It was only 2 minutes before leaving she bailed and fortunately the Kelley's were able to take her in. We left at 7:34am and drove around the M25, A2 to Blackheath.

The support crew

I got dropped off at 9am. I met with Louise and Kelly and we started right at the back of the blue start, next to Bobafet. It took us 16 minutes to get to the start line where the support was loud. Felt really good and just wanted to jump and smash the the air to the music. For the first 5 or 6 miles I felt really good. I saw the fars, Laura, the kidies, the Elders and the in-laws. It's not till you get around the other side of the Cutty Sark do the crowds almost deafen you. I saw a 15 foot dinosaur, a man running in bare feet, Jesus and so many in fancy dress costumes. I was aiming for 6min a km for as long as I could.

Kelly, Loiuse and I starting at the back

Moving swiftly past 8 miles and Canada Water, nature called. Fotunately there was a fence where a dozen or so blokes were lined up water the plant life. I had to join them... then off again into the quietest parts of the marathon, Bermondsey. Clicking past 11 miles and I began to feel the first effects of fatigue. However, the distraction of Tower bridge was welcommed. Again amazing support. I ran straight down the middle. You don't get the chance of running down the centre of tower bridge all that often, so made the most of it!

Turning the corner and heading towards the Docklands it was nice to see the fast runners 7 miles ahead still running strong. I thought it might be de-motivational but no. I did have a look out for the likes of Phil Jelly and Ali but to no avail. That was the only point in the run I looked out for other competitors. I started to talk to an old guy who said 32 years ago he would have been 7 miles ahead of his current position. Got to give the old'uns the respect due, but I was struggling to maintain a conversation as my legs were on the turn.

By mile 14 I was looking forward to seeing the family and kept a look out for them as communications were a little skant. My calfs felt so tight, I was ready to give up. However, thought I had to get to the family.... and then I became a little emotional on seeing them. I felt very privileged that Ellie and Gerry had made the effort to see me, and I re-paid them by running slowly and not really saying hello when I saw them. I cuddled Laura, Jessica and Ben, then ran off again. If I could I would have cuddled everyone. Shortly after I entered the Isle Of Dogs and the 15 mile marker. I was crushed. I began to walk and run for the next 5 miles. Each time I ran after 5 minutes the pain was insufferable and I had to walk. Others with the same idea of walking were overtaking. I couldn't even walk fast. I was so dissapointed as I felt this run was not doing myself justice after all the training. It was a problem I had not encountered before.

Tower bridge

Anyway 20 miles, out of the Isle Of Dogs and again by Westferry I saw the family. This really spurred me on and the tighten of the calfs disapated. Just general fatigue kicked in. The furthest I had run in 16 years now. The face slowed still dispite my spirits lifting. At 21 miles James and Duncan almost had to break the barriers and grab me before I noticed them! I went in for a Ball man-hug.

21 miles and the Balls

24 miles and the Embankment, I tried to keep going. First time I felt the end was achieveable soon. Again I saw Laura, Ben and Jessica on Birdcage walk. It sounds stupid, but it is as if I hadn't seen them for a month, such a welcome sight. Buck house and rounding the final corner, up the home straight I remembered to finish in the middle lane where Kelvin was welcoming the runners in. The final official time was 5:06.13. I came 30255 out of 39083. 14 minutes quicker than my personal best, but 25 minutes later than what I was aiming for. I was disappointed in the time to be honest. People say I done well.... but I know better. I know I should have got a quicker time, and no one can convince me otherwise. Still the finish time only equates to 25% of the enjoyment of the very well run event.

The medal

7:00 min/km

Louise Parker came in a few minutes later. We both struggled to walk up the Mall. We collected a goody bag, but I was in no shape to look at it. I needed some food and drink. Thinking about it. I barely ate anything during the past 5 hours. I had a banana at 20 miles, an orange segment handed out by a crowd member, 4 energy gels and probably a pint of water in total. I would have consumed more at home on the sofa!

Laura, Ben, Jess and the Fars all met me in Horse Guards Parade and nursed me back to Charing Cross where we caught a train to Lee and drove back.

We got in about 6:30pm after a trip down the Fish and Chip shop!

Total raised for Anthony Nolan was Â£1002.44.
In the morning Daddy volunteered as a barcode scanner at parkrun whilst Ben and Mummy ran.

Number 14739. Mr Graham Elder. Well so it says in the records. Daddy went to register at ExCel, giving all the relevant documentation. Race number, chip and the all important goody bag was handed out. Memorabilia was quite expensive. Â£35 minimum on a standard running top! I think Daddy will have to wait till after the marathon and pick one up on eBay.

Medal winner.... let's hope so

In the morning Daddy did his final training run. 8 miles around Camberley. Meanwhile the rest of us went to church.

In the afternoon we were invited around to the Barnett household in Spencers Wood. We had a scrummy BBQ. The weather was nice enough to sit outside. Molly was not the only baby on show, Joyce's sister, Georgina and partner Jack had their new born Milly in attendance.

It was good to see them. It's been a while. We played nicely in backgarden with Eva.

Jessica with Molly

In the morning Daddy and Ben went to parkrun. Unfortunately Ben's leg hurt so could only manage one lap (2.5km). The Fars came to watch which was nice, so they came back with us and had a cup of tea.

Later, Katie and Ben went with the Kelley's to the cinema in Camberley.

Jessica went to a birthday party in Fleet where she crafted some pottery.

In the evening Katie went over to Natasha's and had a sleepover there.

title.value: parkrun, cinema, Jessica at party, Katie sleepover

info.content:
Daddy went for his last long run before the marathon. Confidence is quite low as he struggles a lot with dizzy spells and seeing black and white dots. Anyway Daddy ran from home into Lightwater, across to Bagshot, back into Camberley, Frimley then Farnborough. A slow time at 6min / km, but better than the week before. The rest of us went to church of course.

Running along the Maultway

In the afternoon we had the West crew over for tea and treats. We played with Freya, Harry and Josh really well.... although we made a mess of the back garden!

What a mess!

title.value: Last long training run, Entertaining the Wests

info.content:
In the morning, just Katie stayed at home whilst the rest of us went to parkrun. Ben pb'ed post leg operation which was very pleasing for us all. Daddy went down the cafÃ© afterwards to celebrate James's 200th and Alex's 50th.

After lunch we drove to Alresford for walk 79. In fact there was not too much moaning from the kiddies. We walked along the river Alre which was very nice stopping off at the playground and at the co-op for some treats. Ben and Daddy went to see the steam train shunting at the station.

Nice Cottage on the River Arle

Daddy and Jess

Katie and Jess on the river

On the way home we stopped by the Elder household and had a nice cup of tea and watched the Grand National. We did a sweepstake, Â£1 each. Mummy came out the winner.

title.value: parkrun, Walk 79: Alresford, Elders for a cuppa

info.content: Jessica went over the Teale household for a sleepover whilst we had Summer. Summer and Katie got on very well together, mostly playing Sims on the computer!

title.value: Jessica over to Alices, Summer to our - Sleepover

info.content:
We met at Shorne Country Park with the Burrows and Teale clans.

Jump shot to a new level

In the morning whilst we were in church, Daddy ran from Chertsey to Weybridge, then all the way down on the Basingstoke Canal down to Deepcut. 30km in total. He was almost run over in the first mile. A car didn't see Daddy cross a zebra crossing until the last second. The car thankfully skidded a halt 5 metres from Daddy's legs! The run did not go that well. Daddy blames pre run fueling and blood sugars management!

In the afternoon we played. The favourite game at the moment is ..... Ben and Jess played football in the back garden.

Footballers

In the morning Mummy continued her stratospheric improvement in parkrun, knocking over a minute off. Her pb now stands at 28:15! She was accompanied by her coaches Daddy and Ben.

In the afternoon we all went over to Brooklands to play around the circuit. We had time trials on our bikes and roller skates. We ended the afternoon with a nice ice cream.

Skaters
Toby came to ours for his first sleepover, accompanied by Lily. We had 'Donalds' for dinner.
We stayed over a Ma Ma and Pop Pops for a sleepover with Mummy.

title.value: Ma Ma and Pop Pop's sleepover

info.content:
Storm Katie had hit overnight and continued in the morning which made for a tough half marathon run along the River Thames from Walton bridge. Anthony came down to watch which was very kind of him. Daddy completed in 1:58. Pretty slow for these days.

Meanwhile the rest of us went over to see the Sanders new house. Us kiddies played Sardines (like hide and seek) for a number of hours. Daddy came later to take a tour of the house and have some lunch.

title.value: River Thames Half Marathon, Sanders New House

info.content:
After church we went over to the Elders who were hosting the Weston Easter lunch this year. A nice roast beef. The boys had a game of football tennis which was good fun.

Later in the afternoon we all went over to Pete's for some games and had the traditional Easter Egg hunt in his back garden.

Katie rushing to get eggs

Katie and Lily's haul

title.value: Elders Easter Lunch, Petes Egg Hunt

info.content:
Mummy now getting into parkrun ran with coach Ben and achieved another pb. Now down to 29:20. She earnt another can of Rio.

In the afternoon we headed on walk 78 - down in the bowels of the New Forest. We parked up at Lepe Country Park to start the 2.5 mile walk. It was split in two: one in a nature reserve area and the other along the sea front. There was a lot of tree climbing.

Jessica climbing a tree

More tree fun

Beach walking

title.value: Mummy parkrun pb, Walk 78: Lepe Beach

info.content:
We had the Gay family over for a Easter lunch. Mummy did ever so well cooking a nice roast pork. After lunch we turned the tables on Farfar and gave him a treasure hunt to accomplish.

The Easter meal krew

Farfar collecting his prize.

Farfar finding the treasure

Later in the afternoon, the boys went and played football up on the rec, then they came back and everyone played Rapidough.

Jessica performed a reading in church, and did very well. Stumbled on the word Jerusalem.

We invited Great Grandma over for lunch. We felt very privileged as she doesn't like to venture out too much these days. After roast port, we played a game of Uno. Ben was not impressed by the supposed cheating from Jessica, so stormed off half way through the game. Jessica forgot to say 'Uno' directly after laying her penultimate card and eventually won the hand. Ben was not forgiving! The rest of us had a good game, Katie running out the eventual winner.

The porkers

The last card

Winner

title.value: Great Grandma Over For Sunday Lunch

info.content:
Daddy was ill. So ill he couldn't face parkrun! Wow. So mummy picked up the baton and took Ben to parkrun. Mummy stormed it to another new pb. 30 mins exactly, so she deserved the Rio.

Rio moment

After lunch, Daddy took on his 40th birthday present from Auntie Susan which was an Ariel Atom experience. 3 laps around the Longcross circuit. First was a demo lap detailing the rules of the road, then it was action time. Daddy loved it, although really could have done with 10 laps. Each of the 3 laps got better as confidence grew. A very enjoyable experience.

Driving an Ariel Atom

Daddy in the driving seat

Daddy had entered for his longest run yet, a 20 miler around the Top Gear track. Luckily he had support in the Frimley Flyers and Anthony, who he is running the London Marathon with.

The Frimley Flyer spitfire pilots

We travelled down yesterday after Daddy got in from work to Bournemouth as we were visiting Auntie Charlotte for a couple of days. Charlotte had prepared a nice, big roast and an evening watching the Reading match on the TV. Ben and Daddy were due to go to watch it live with fat Phil.

In the morning we went to Kings Park to first see where Bournemouth play their Premier League matches then to do the parkrun. It was quite foggy and cold. We saw the Rushforth's strangely there to. This week Mummy, joined Ben and Daddy on the 5km circuit. She did very well breaking her PB. Now at 30:28. After our parkrun we went and played in the skate park near by.

Jessica on the skate park

Atmospheric photo from Katie

Mummy in a sprint finish

Hold on Ben

Katie and Daddy in a race

After we showered, Auntie Charlotte took us to Boscombe so we could walk the 5.5 miles to Bournemouth. Still at least it was free parking. A woman who knows Daddy well! It was still very foggy which made for an eerie landscape.

Daddy and Big boys looking out to sea

Along the way Katie was interested in taking some more pics, we were all interested in having a go at the exercise apparatus and to dip a toe in the sand. We contemplated how much money it would take us to jump in the sea right now, given how cold and misty the conditions were. We walked up an appetite and because we had parkrunned, Daddy said we could choose whatever we like for lunch. Harry Ramsdens was the first eatery we past, so for most that was the choice of poison.

Ramsdens Finest

We wandered around the shops in Bournemouth, McDonalds, for Ben's lunch, Lush, WH Smiths, Primark, then Daddy was flagging. Too much shopping!

We returned to Bournemouth Pier and us three went on the trampolines for about quatre of an hour before our return back in the direction of Boscombe.

Bournemouth Beach

Brave to sample the cold water

Boof girl

Big boys

On the groins

We got back to Charlottes to have baths, watch England beat Wales in the rugby and have dinner. We returned home well relaxed. Thank you Charlotte and Loz.

Snuggled up with Auntie Charlotte

We got mummy breakfast in bed and gave our presents which were mostly home made.

Mummy and her children!

We all went off to church, whilst Daddy joined Dave, Alex and Alasdair for a long 27km run. Daddy struggled quite a bit again.

In the afternoon Katie and Jessica performed their rollerskating show to Mummy and the rest of the congregation including, Ma Ma, Pop Pop, The Elders, Great Grandma and Uncle Pete. The Show went very well, with a number of acts. Each having a different dance and constumes. All performed in good fun.

Jessica and Katie performing in front of her fans.

Jessica and Katie Roller Dancing

The cast

Later in the afternoon we went over to the Fars to wish Farmor a happy Mothers Day. We play Coppit, watched Home Alone and ate a lot of Cream Crackers!

Daddy and Ben went to parkrun in the morning. Ben completed in 27:15, his fastest for a long time. Good running Ben.

Mummy and Daddy had volunteered to shake a collection tin for an hour at Longacres. Ben was treated by each of them as they took it turns to look after Ben.

Addy Curie

Meanwhile Jessica and Katie were at the Fars preparing for a Mother's Day performance!

In the afternoon Daddy was setting up the Raspberry Pi 3 that he's just bought. He's hoping to setup Danish TV on their for Farmor. In the evening we watched Ant and Dec's Saturday Takeaway.

So at school Jessica and Ben had to dress up as book characters. Jessica loved dressing up as an old granny and Ben.... well Ben thought it would be funny dressing up as a girl, for David Walliams, Boy In A Dress.

Gangster Granny

Boy In A Dress

title.value: World Book Day - Gangster Granny and Boy In A Dress

info.content:
In the morning Daddy devised a half marathon route which Bob and Alasdair joined him on. It was pretty hilly and it did not help that Daddy got a little lost on the way around, subsequently adding another 2km to the route. Bob also fell in a pot hole, so it was a mighty eventful 2 hours 10 minutes for 23 hilly kilometres!

5:38 mins/km

In the afternoon the Elders came over. Daddy and Michael organised their October biking holiday to Mallorca. After all the boys went up the recreation park to play football.

Daddy went alone to jog in his 150th parkrun. Ben was too tired. On his return we went to Oxford for a day out.

From the park and ride bus we went past the Headington Shark, an abombination! A 25 foot, fibreglass shark. We all wowed at it.

In Oxford we had our picnic, then went in to a fun party shop and through the indoor market.

We climbed the narrow stair wells of Carfax Tower. It was a bitterly cold day and quite windy at the top of the tower. All of the sudden we heard Mummy shriek and start feeling her hair. A pterodactyl had whoopsied on Mummy's head. How we all laughed, except for one person of course. We cleaned mummy up with an empty crisp packet. Credit mummy she allowed us to look at the Oxford views from the top of the tower before we had rush and clean her up.

Pooping Heck

Once we had to returned to the deck, the first visit was to boots to get some wipes to clean up mummy's hair as much as we could, before moving on to Oxford Castle. We climbed the mound next to the castle then went into the pub adjacent for a warm up and a nice drink. A couple more visits into shops afterwards and we were homeward bound.

Bridge Of Sighs

Oxford Castle

In the morning Daddy took James's place in the Wokingham Half Marathon. This was going to be a real test. Has Daddy lost his running form, after the last two bad runs? It was a nice day, a little windy preventing it from being ideal. Daddy started off well, seeing Bob and Kelvin cheering on at the side which was a pleasant surprise. 10 miles in at 1:24 which was pleasing. Daddy then struggled over the last 3 miles, although the times don't suggest by too much. Final time 1:51. Daddy quickly collected the medal and headed straight for the car and homeward bound.

Within 30 minutes of Daddy arriving, we left for walk 77 and Friday Street in the Surrey Hills, by Leith Hill. Katie continued in being interested in taking photos. Jessica and Ben were playing some kind of army game which involved a lot of stick collecting and waving.

Daddy and Ben down the street

Street goings on

Loggers without a V insight

Family Shot

title.value: Walk 77: Friday Street, Wokingham Half Marathon

info.content:
Ben continued to improve his 5km time at today's Frimley Lodge parkrun. Daddy and Ben went to the cafÃ© afterwards to celebrate Duncan's 250th parkrun. Good times.

Later the boys went off to watch Reading play. We picked up George and Matthew, Phil's Dad and nephew and met with Phil at his house along with Steve, Eva and Nick. Reading were playing West Brom from the Premier League in the 5th round of the FA Cup. 19,553 packed into the stadium. We were in row 6, in line with the touch line. It was an entertaining second half, Reading running out 3-1 winners. The game made the news because a West Brom fan threw a coin and hit a West Brom player after the match! The whole crew went back to Phil's. Anna had made us all a nice dinner.

Reading vs West Brom

Meanwhile, the girls cycled in to Farnborough to watch the latest Chipmunks at the cinema.

title.value: Reading V West Brom, Chipmunks Cinema

info.content: Alice and Summer came over for a sleepover. We went into Camberley with Karen for a spot of shopping and a visit of the obelisk! Ben still at Ma Ma and Pop Pops.

We spent last night at Ma Ma's. Today we went to Cobtree which was close to MA Ma's horses. Us children went on the horses whilst Mummy and Ben went to Helen's for lunch.

Jessica and Natasha Horsey Riders

Mummy picked us from the Fars on the way to church after we had made another Den in their front room.

Dendengineers

After church and a Sunday roast, we headed to Brighton for an afternoon out.

We started in the main shopping area, the Lego store had a really cool gimmick where if you went in front of the camera and tv, it would video you with the lego box you had, then superimpose the built version of the lego on top.

We trekked down the Lanes, went in Chocy Woccy Do Dah and big sweet shop and then finally on to the beach where there was a gorgeous sunset. Katie still into her photography took lots of good photos, trying out the different lenses and different framing techniques.

Chocolate named after us

Brighton Beach

Playing dare with the waves

We went on to the pier and had a go on penny arcades and on the fair rides. Jessica went on her first up side ride which she was petrified about, but came off confidently. For Ben it did not pose a problem. Hard as nails! Katie went on the helter-skelter slide. Another Fish and Chip supper.

Brighton Pier

Upside down fair ride

It was a bad weather day. It was raining and very cold. However, Jessica was not detered, she was going to do the parkrun today with Ben and Daddy. She borrowed a pair of Ben's tracksuit bottoms which made the run even more remarkable as she picked up extra weight through mud and water at the bottom of the trousers. She managed the first lap fine, then started to struggle a bit, only on a couple of occasions did she stop to walk.... but just for one step only until the big, nasty Daddy came along and gave her gentle encouragement with a hand in the back to push her along. She did ever so well. Very proud dad. Oh and first 5km time was 31:41. Very respectable.

In the afternoon us girls went shopping in Camberley, Ben went to Yuvraj's house to play Lego and Xbox.

In the evening us little ones went to the Fars for a sleepover. They treated us to a game of bowling in Camberley finished off with Fish and Chips and a watch of Match Of The Day.

Bowling with the Fars

Meanwhile Auntie Ellie and Fiona came to our house and marched off to the Ely pub for Karen's 40th Birthday party. Karen certainly had a great time. There was a bit of boogying going on as well.

Fiona and Ellie stayed the night. 4 adults, 0 children weird.

Karen enjoying herself

The gang

Mummy and Daddy

Karen Fee and Mummy

Mummy, Ellie, Fee and rachel

Mummy, Ellie, Fee

Sisters

Mummy, Ellie and Fee

title.value: Jessica's first parkrun, Fars sleepover, Karen's 40th Birthday party

info.content: Bob and Chris came over to do a bit of bike gear DIY before moving on to the 6th birthday party of Frimley Lodge parkrun at Frimley Communty Hall. Ben had fizzy drink, Haribo, cake and Pringles. What more could a boy ask for?

Ben has to cook a meal for one of his Scout badges so embarked in making burger and chips with of course pancakes for pudding

Ben in the kitchen

In the morning we went off to church whilst Daddy went to Chertsey and then ran 15.3 miles back home again! The rest of us were far more sensible and went to church.

In the afternoon we returned to the Elders, this time for Toby's 3rd birthday. Ma Ma, Pop Pop, Howard and Susan also came. We sat around the fire trying to get the children to talk to us. Fail!

title.value: Chertsey Town FC run, Toby Birthday

info.content:
Ben and Daddy went off to parkrun. The target was to consolidate last weeks time. We didn't want to stretch it as Ben had Joey's football party to run about in as well. Watch was out of action so it wasn't until later we discovered we got 28:29. We were well happy with that. We both popped into the cafe after for a hot chocolate, then popped into see the Fars for 20 minutes and hear about their recent trip to Norway.

After lunch we headed to Alton Sports Centre and Joey's Birthday party which started at the football court. It was a 5/6 a side game with Michael and Daddy getting involved as well. The game ended in a draw and penalties. A good match.

Ben in goal for penalties

After, we went back to the Elder household where the boys had a mini league of Fifa 16 and table football. Daddy read a story to Toby.

Table football competition

Sending Toby to sleep!

In the evening we went to see Mike West and Emily Benson perform in this years HATS panto. Another success. We enjoyed it.

HATs Panto

title.value: parkrun, Joey's 11 Birthday Party, High Cross Panto

info.content:
In the morning Daddy increased his training and did a 14 mile run around Bisley ranges with a few of his running friends. He was pleased with his run. Meanwhile we all went to church.

After Sunday lunch, we decided to go for a walk, disguised as a phptography outing for Katie, who wanted to enter three photographs relating to nature. So we end up at Turf Hill in Lightwater. Daddy was really pleased to share some of his limited photography knowledge which Katie was enthusiastic to accept.

Brown River

Plop

As a treat Daddy then took us to the Nook. A coffee shop that has been open for a few months practically opposite the house. We had hot chocolate and cakey!

Mmmm. Cake and drink

The Nook

title.value: Bisley 14 miler, Lightwater Photography, The Nook

info.content:
Ben and Daddy went to parkrun in the morning. Target was 30mins and they came in at 29:30, so well happy.

After lunch Daddy and Ben went with Phil, Matthew and Nick to see Reading play Walsall in the FA Cup. Thinking it would be OK to sit in the signing stands to get a bit of atmosphere, Daddy soon realized this was a bit of a mistake. I think Ben has doubled his swear word vocabulary! Anyway Reading ran out comfortable 4-0 winners. After we went back to Phil's where Anna had made a lovely large Lasagne and chocolate pancakes.

The Reading branch of the Barmy Army

Meanwhile the girls went into Camberley for some female retail therapy. Katie bought a new school bag and along with Jessica bought a new pencil case. They had a sneaky McDonalds.

title.value: parkrun, Reading v Walsall, Girlie Shopping

info.content: A pre SATs test given to the whole of year 6. His friend Oliver got 14 out of 23, second place got 20 out of 23, step up big boys. 23 out of 23. Booom. Well done. Officially head has got to unbearable size. Please fix it! No. We are proud of you Ben.

Daddy took the day off work to take Ben up to London for hopefully his last appointment with the specialists. As the meeting was not till the afternoon, Daddy took Ben to some of his favourite shops.... well they will be as soon as he visits them. First up a bus ride from Waterloo to Regent's street. Hamley's without hoards of people. A delight. Well for Ben it was the best shop ever. They had some 1 to 1's with the toy performers, including magic performed by the second best close up artist in the country!

Board game heaven

Meeting the queen

Ben the new Star Wars figure

After 7 floors of fun we vacated and sat on the pavement in Regents Street ate our sandwiches and planned the next shop. Opposite was the Apple store. Of course we had a look and of course Daddy left the browser open on the Frimley Flyers home web page.

We then went on to Nike Town at Oxford Circus. The legs were flagging. There is only so much you can look at in the shops. Ben enjoyed himself, but it was time to get to Bolsover Street, via a cheeky trip to McDonalds and the BBC building!

We got to see one of Me Pollock's doctors earlier than expected. He did a few tests on Ben, basically checking strength and mobility. He checked the scar out. Everything OK. We mentioned that the physio though one leg was longer than the other, when he tested he thought it was only a couple of millimetres and nothing really to worry about. He discharged us and only to contact them again if there are problems. Yipee.

We made it back in time for Ben to go football training.

Daddy drove the Fars to Gatwick Airport as they started their 10 day cruise along the Norwegian Fjords. He took this opportunity to fit in a London Marathon training run in pastures new.

19km route

The run seemed to start slowly for the first 5km, but by the end Daddy had to beat Anthony's sneaky longer run, so did an extra 1km to mark 19km!

The rest of us went to church, Mummy ran Sunday School with a hangover!

In the afternoon we a den in the front room with sofa cushions, sheets, chairs and goodness knows what. We wanted to sleep in there, which Ben and Katie did... but not all night.

Whilst the Den was being built Daddy went to Watchetts to see his university friend, Claire. They worked out it had been 10 years since they last saw each other. At first Daddy couldn't find her, fearing she had changed in appearance beyond recognition. After an hour they met and recalled old tales and spoke about the kiddies. A reunion with Snell, Rice, Weizey one day? It'll be a tough ask. We watched daughter, Georgia, now 13 play rugby against Camberley.

In the evening we watched the final instalment of Walking the Himalayas.

Daddy went off to parkrun not feeling 100% after last Wednesday's; skipping, circuits and piyo classes! He came back with a disappointing 24:57.

Meanwhile Ben went off to a Scout event in Lightwater, however, because his best mate, Oliver didn't turn up, he also did not want to participate. All the other children were a couple of years older and I think he felt a little intimidated.

After lunch we pottled down to Petersfield and went in the Queen Elizabeth country park for walk 76. The deal was last week that the children were not allowed to moan if we postponed the walk for a week. So here we are.... and by and large the cacophony of grumbles were suppressed. Ben and Jessica had sticks and were playing some army game all the way around. Katie was interested in doing some photography for a school competition. Mummy got us lost, so we made up the last bit of the walk towards the Juniper adventure playground.

Mother - Daughter chatting

Jessica Jousting

Jessa putting Ben to the sword

Last night we had Natasha stay for a sleepover so tonight Katie went to Natasha's. We barely see our eldest these days. Mummy went out for Paula's 40th meal at Zizi's in Camberley.

title.value: Walk 76: Queen Elizabeth Park, Katie sleepover

info.content:
We awoke to snow. A very thin layer. Still it did not stop the three of us from going out early in the back garden to throw snow balls, build a 10cm snowman and do snow angels!

Snowman building

Later in the morning we split three ways. Daddy went for a 17km run with Alasdair around Crookham, whilst Mummy, Ben and Katie went to church. Jessica escaped all these tasks and partied at Laser run as it was Aimee Huggets 8th birthday. Jessica had a good time, although didn't think she done that well.

In the afternoon we all went swimming at the Arena. The inflatable was out.

Daddy had not shaven all week in attempt to grow some stubble. However, the results were not good, so in agreement with everyone Daddy shaved it off.

Off with his beard

Computer games of choice at the moment. Ben - Fifa 16 (for the past 4 months solid), Katie and Jess love Sims 3 and some Fashion Models dressing up game and Daddy's guilty pleasure is sodding Candy Crush (embarrassingly) and Civilization 3 (from 2001).

Daddy did the Frimley Lodge parkrun on frozen ground which turned out slower than it seemed. Then he took Ben and Jessica over to the Fars for a cup of tea and a game of Coppit, which turned out close, with Jessica as the winner.

After lunch, Mummy took us out for the church new years party along with the Elders and Ma Ma and Pop Pop. We played games for over 3 hours.

In the morning Daddy embarked on the first of his London Marathon training runs. Today a 10 miler to the Deepcut, Jolly Farmer roundabout, Camberley, Frimley Road. It went OK.

Daddy after jog!

This is shock news. Daddy came to church with us, but only because Ben was doing a long reading, Matthew 3, versus 1 to 12. He did very well and there was a splattering of applause when he finished. You could not see his head above the lectern. He came across as confident. Well done Ben.

In the afternoon, we finally got out for a family walk. We had been waiting for weeks. Either the time, the weather, or the copious amount of moaning has put a stop to. Despite the weather forecast we decided to go whatever. We arrived and within 2 minutes, there was thunder, lightening and hail! We were all hidden in the church doorway, with Katie going nuts about the lightening. It was hard to calm her down. Anyway fortunately the worst went away after a few minutes and we were able to continue. Daddy went nuts at Jessica for not wanting to wear boots. It was one of the muddiest walks.

Ben walking past a field of sheep

Jessica in what was white trainers!

On the way back

The rain stopped, Daddy calmed down and in the end it turned out to be a pleasant walk. Mummy and Daddy's theory is that us children, although initially protest, actually secretly like the walks, as we have a good laugh going around.

title.value: London Marathon Training, Ben Reading, Walk 75: Crowhurst

info.content:
Ben and Daddy went to parkrun. Again the conditions were very wet. Ben completed his first Frimley Lodge parkrun for 7 or 8 months in a time of 31 minutes.

Finish line of the Frimley Lodge parkrun

Ben, Jessica and Daddy then went down to Southampton for a FA Cup 3rd round tie against Crystal Palace. Daddy did his usual free parking trick. After a burger and some chips they entered the stadium in the Family Enclosure. Tickets were just Â£12 and Â£5 which was very reasonable.

The game started and the Southampton fans were quiet. All the singing was definitely up the away end.

Ben and Jess at St Mary's

Ben loved it and wants to go to football every week. It was Jessica's first time seeing a large crowd. She watched the football, asked questions, which is always a good sign she was not completely bored!

We raced home, as Mummy went out to the Kingfisher for Paula's 40th birthday meal.

As part of Mummy's new get slim regime, she has to jog 4 times a week. Two 5 minutes efforts, a 10 minute and a 15 minute run each week. She has multiple partners each run. We have this week run all together!

Family Jog

In the morning Daddy, Ben and Joet first went to do the Rushmoor parkrun, then Daddy went to do the double at Frimley Lodge. This years running aims are: 750 miles, 200 runs and the London Marathon without walking in a time of 4 hours 30 mins.

Mummy has started her slimming world which now includes 4 runs a week as well as the cutting out of crappy foods.

For Daddy's 40th birthday, Uncle Dawg had bought him tickets to go and see the World PDC Darts, Quatre Finals at Alexendra Palace. Daddy drove with Uncle Michael, had a spot of lunch in Muswell Hill, then entered the fancy dress party! The drink was flowing amongst the non-drivers (everyone except Daddy). He saw Gary Anderson, Wade, Klassen and Norris. To be honest the darts was a secondary event to having a chat and a sing song. Daddy had his banner banned by one of the bouncers. Unceremoniously confiscated from Daddy's lap!

After the darts Steve, Steve's brother in law, Jack, Phil, Michael and Nick all headed into the O'Neils pub (converted church) in Muswell Hill for some more food and lubrication.

Learning from our experiences three days earlier, we went early to Windsor, Daddy even researched the car park to go to! Saddo.

Strangely this world landmark which is less than 10 miles away has never been visited by us. Luckily the free tickets meant we saved Â£51 on admission. It was an airport styled admission, with scanners and friskers!

We entered and was bowled over by how nice the castle stone, design and grounds looked. We looked at the dolls house and the state rooms. Daddy's favourite was the Crimson Room. We spoke to one of the staff and he told some interesting facts and stories.

The state appertments

Ben standing to attention

Family shot

Henry VIII Gateway

Daddy and Katie outside St Georges Chapel

Lower Ward grounds

Daddy and Katie again

Cheeky Jess

In the evening we went to the Elders house to see the new year in. Char and Loz were also in attendance to play games and eat food!

Mikey going for it in the Cereal Box challenge

title.value: Windsor Castle, Elder's for New Years

info.content:
In the morning Jessica went with Aimee Huggets to Bracknell Ice Rink and skated for a couple of hours before moving onto the Harvester for some lunch. Very lucky girl. Aimee's Daddy (who is a good skater) said Jessica had good balance and would make a good skater. It was nice for Jessica to catch up with her old best friend. Jessica is going to start Gymnastics up again with Aimee. Good times.

Meanwhile the rest of us went for a bike ride on our new bikes, only Daddy with his old bike! Anyway there was a lot of moaning especially from Miss Kitkat G.

Downhill in the woods

The route went through the woods by St Catherines Road, up to Deepcut, then past our old house, then through the army grounds down to the Basingstoke Canal and back home. It was good to get the cobwebs blown away.

Back home along the Basingstoke Canal

title.value: Family Bike Ride + Jessica Ice Skating

info.content:
Mummy had organised a load of us to go and see Aladdin at Camberley Theatre. It was very entertaining.

Aladdin

Well we had a bit of a nightmare journey to Windsor after lunch time. The traffic was bad and there were no parking spaces at all. In the end Daddy dropped us of all in town and had to go over the Thames into Datchett, park then run / walk into Windsor.

The reason for Windsor is that we were kindly given free tickets for a tour of the castle. However, the queue was huge. So we decided to abort, and spend some Christmas money instead in the shops.

Bye Bye Windsor Castle

We slept over at Ma Ma's, Daddy waking early to do the Malling parkrun. After, we ventured home to finally have a moment to ourselves and start playing with some of the toys we got and prepare for this afternoons family party.

We had many of the Barnett side of family and some of the Gay's also. It was an evening of games, boys versus girls.

Boxing Day games

Give Us A Clue

Us kiddies were up all night. In the end Mummy and Daddy said 6am was the start.... and 6am on the dot the lights went on and we were invited into Ben's room to see what us three had got.

6am start. Opening Father Christmas's delivery

Ben's main presents were: Man Utd training top, trainers and a bike.

Katie's were: ???? and a bike.

Jessica got: Lego Friends Hotel and a scooter.

One at a time opening Father Christmas's presents

Next up were Mummy and Daddy's from each other. Mummy got a new pair of Converse trainers, Rush 2 perfume, a top, a calendar, a Donna Lewis CD. Daddy got a running magazine, two packets of crisps, a running light to put on his arm.

Next was a small spot of breakfast before opening presents from friends under our own tree.

Friends presents

We then packed up to go to the Fars for breakfast. Mummy popped off to church.

Family Shot

About 11:30-ish we left for Istead Rise for the next part of our Christmas. The Weston's. Here the Elders, Charlotte and Loz also came. This year we all had the turkey roast at the same time and Daddy managed to eat it in good time for once. We then went out for a walk around the estate and bothered some of Ma ma's friends.

A load of Turkey

A civilized bunch of Turkeys

When we returned we played this Russian Roulette type game, but with a creamed pie splatted in your face instead of a bullet in the head. That was fun.

We opened loads of presents, played more games before finally going to bed.... letting the adults then open their presents from each other and family.

Ben opening presents sporting his new Man Utd top

Katie in new pyjamas

Jessica opening presents in her new coat

Tobot the dude

Jessica showing off presents

Daddy worked from home in the morning whilst helping Katie make bread for a late Farfar present.... another game of Formula One also.

4pm and it was around to the Fars, plus Auntie Susan and Graham. We all say this is the most Christmassy feeling we get. First up was a game of Coppit which is traditional now. There was some fierce attacking.

Copp That

We had Roast Pork, sausages, caramelized potatoes and riselamange. Yum. Some could barely move. We went off to complete Farfar's Treasure Hunt around Richmond Close and surrounding areas.... there was some real treasure in the form of pounds sterling!

Next up was the dice game. Similar to a Chinese Auction. The lottery tickets were top of the hit list for most.

Dice Game

Then the main event, present time! There were 3 helpers willing to sort, manage and deliver presents one at a time. Ben received a Man Utd magazine, Man Utd clock, book and a Macarno car set as well as a football goal for the back garden and Match Attax cards. Katie received a lovely outfit, a fashion book as well as some smellies.

Wow going on past 9pm, it was time to leave and prepare some milk, a mince pie for Father Christmas as well as some reindeer food outside the front door. Mummy went to midnight mass..... and Father Christmas delivered really, very, carefully!

Present Time
We met up with the Burrows, minus the Dad's and played in the mud and rain at Box Hill.

After saying goodbye to Katie's friends, we went to church, then had roast pork.

Then we had a round of baking. Katie went to the Fars to bake some Christmas biscuits and put the finishing touches on their Christmas tree.

Meanwhile Ben and Jessica were testing their icing and sculptor skills. Jessica showed some flair.

Later in the afternoon Mummy went to church for a carol service, whilst Farfar came around and joined us in Daddy's childhood board game called Formula 1. We had a laugh. Farfar won, Daddy came last. That ended a weekend where we played the game about 5 times!

Formula One

Formula One Board

Katie had Grace, Natasha and Nina over for a sleepover.

Katie and friends

We also played more Formula 1, which is deffo very popular at the moment.

In the morning Daddy, Jessica and Ben went to parkrun. The weather was very mild, about 9 degrees. Ben and Jessica did very well and completed a lap. After Daddy went down the cafÃ© to celebrate Maddie's 25 volunteers landmark, and Sarah's 50th parkrun. Meanwhile the Fars took us children down the sweet shop and treated us. Mummy went with the church and sung carols at two old people's homes down St. Catherine's Road.

Parkrunners

In the afternoon Daddy and Ben went to watch the new Star Wars film - The Force Awakens, at the new Farnborough cinema. Ben was so sweet and really loved the film. He said during it. 'It was heaven watching Star Wars in the cinema, with sweets and with you Dad.' Sickly I know, but it made Daddy feel good. Ben's rated this as his number 1 movie, in front of; Lego Movie, James Bond - Spectre and Harry Potter.

Star Wars

In the later afternoon / evening, Katie had Natasha, Grace and Nina over for a sleepover. They were relatively quiet, making Christmas biscuits, watching films and chatting. Reportedly some didn't goto sleep till gone 3am!

title.value: Parkrun, Carol Singing, Star Wars - The Force Awakens, Katie's Sleepover

info.content:
Our annual Christmas Meal this year was at Toby Carvery in Aldershot. Exotic I know. Jessica and Ben loved the drinks machine. Free refills and could make flavoured Coke's. We had a strawberry and a cherry flavour at least

Toby Carvery Christmas Meal

A busy morning with Ben doing his first lap of parkrun in 7 months. It was good to Ben back on the new course. Later the boys joined the Elders to watch Joey play a Cup Final at Frimley Lodge park which he won.

Joey in his cup final

Mummy took us girls, Lily and Toby down to the Baptist church to make Christmas craft.

Daddy went to the Frimley Flyers lunch at the Ely. He came 4th out of 14. It was good to see us all there.

Flyers

The Golden Envelope

title.value: Church Craft - Joey Cup Final - Frimley Flyers Lunch

info.content:
Daddy went out with Michael, Millie, Kumar and Rob. All CNL colleagues. It was good to catch up.

Meanwhile, we went puzzle crazy for a bit.

Puzzling

Mummy and Daddy went to see Jessica in her school nativity play. Jessica was in the choir. She thought it unfair that she didn't have the chance to play more prominent role as she was in the library reading when they picked the actors.

At the back in the choir

We had the West's stay over and there was still a fair amount of clearing up to be done from last night's party. So most of the morning was taken up with that and of course a trip to church.

In the afternoon Daddy went down to Frimley Lodge Park and helped on the Scout tent where they were selling refreshments, highlights being camp doughnuts which is a glorified deep fried, jam sandwich covered in sugar and custard infused hot chocolate which tasted very nice.

Parkrun in the morning, and after yesterday's physio meeting, Ben is going to start light running. So the boy ran the 1km from home to parkrun. The Frimley Flyers were pleased to see the young man.

Straight after we went over to the Elders. Lily requested that Mummy run the birthday party in terms of games. Ben weighed in with a music quiz and sounds like everything went very well. Importantly Lily was pleased. Apparently one of the children mentioned to their mum that wanted 'a party planner at their party'! High praise indeed.

Lily's Birthday Party Lunch

In the evening it was the annual Gays Christmas Party. This year we had the Elders, Sanders, Wests, Charlie and Loz in attendance. Some of the ladies started on the Prosecco early and felt a little worse for wear as the evening wore on. The games started quick and rolled off quick. Katie ran the 'titles' game. This year we had a slight twist with individual challenges dotted in between rounds. We learnt that Karen is more agile than Daddy, Josh is stronger than Charlotte, Mummy is more logical than E'ster (work that one out), Bazza can fit more marshmallows in his mouth than Charlotte and Loz can withstand the electrocution test better than Julie!

Looking at awe at Charlie's marshmallow exploits

Perhaps the biggest shock of the evening was Ellie losing out on Spoons at the quatre-final stage. Daddy took the honours there! Overall the boys team won (again!).

Daddy and Bazza were the last men standing at 3am! Josh took advantage of Julie's state and started drawing on her face! Katie was scared off mummy because she was a little tipsy and crashed out early.

Josh handing out flour (strength test)

Julie looking like she's enjoying being electrocuted

For the past month Daddy has been making a desk for the computer in the conservatory. It's been made out of palettes left from the builders.

Palette Table
We went to the Arena in the afternoon and played on the big inflatable in the swimming pool.

After parkrun we went to Badshot Lea garden centre to see Father Christmas come on his horse drawn sleigh. We then went out the back to see a couple of his reindeers crazing on the stone!

Meeting Rudolph

The bolier had packed up earlier in the week. With the condition of the boiler and cost of the repair it was decided we should get a new one.... a Bosch Worcester Greenstar. We're Â£2250 lighter in the pocket! Labour Â£140 per hour. Extortionate.

Mummy and Daddy went out in the evening to the Thai Terrace for the Net Evidence Christmas Do. We spent most of our time with Richard and Julie, the CEO and his wife. Mummy was great, didn't come across too nervous at all. Daddy was proud of her.

title.value: Boiler replaced and Net Evidence Meal

info.content:
We went over to the Fars for tea, make some craft, play the computer and see the latest with the decorating.

Farfar with us

The battle of Devil's Punchbowl. So our family walks had dried up a bit lately so we decided to go out and have some nice family time..... well that backfired! There were 3 of us who were less than enthusiastic, resistance was rife and 2 who ploughed on regardless. Jessica moaned, more because the others were complaining. Then we realised her boots were rubbing against her skin, so bless her the walk was hurting her. Katie remained quiet and moody mostly. Then came Benjamin who refused to dress properly for the low temperatures. His shorts, Man Utd shirt and sweater are a constant fixture no matter the occasion, be it church, being at home or going out on a cold day! He definitely cut off his nose to spite his face. He was shivering at points. Daddy was even carrying his coat around and at one point threw it at him to put on. He walked passed it. He complained, moaned, came out with every excuse under the sun for not participating. That boy!

Devils

Matters were not improved when we lost our way a bit. An hour and a half later it was all over. We apologised to Mummy and Daddy on the way home.

Steve popped over with the new addition to the family; Molly Barnett

Molly Barnett

In the morning Daddy went on a 40 mile bike ride with Bob and Michael from Weybourne to Lasham and Frensham. Daddy struggled a bit towards the end, but enjoyed himself.

Cycle Route

Daddy went to collect Katie bike, Â£30 second hand. A bit more rusty than originally hoped, not too sure if Katie will accept it with open arms. Sunday lunch on Mummy's Slimmers World menu. Still tasted nice. Mummy reckons she's lost a few pounds in the first week of her new diet regime.

The afternoon was spent with clearing the leaves from the front and back garden, doing homework, daddy continuing with his pallet desk and watching Stormbreaker, Alex Ryder film. Jessica continues to have a nasty cough and sough throat.

Daddy parkrunned in the morning followed by a trip to the cafe. Us girls went over to Gravesend for a sleepover with Summer and Alice. Aunty Karen took us into Bluewater to do some Christmas Shopping. Somehow Katie had Â£30 to spend all donated via eyelid actions!

Meanwhile in the afternoon Daddy and Ben started programming in C#. A football management game was born. Ben soaked it all up and was pretty enthusiastic. They started a Windows Form Application and made a couple of the initial screens up.

In the evening Denmark played Sweden in an important knock out qualifier for next years qualifiers. Denmark lost 2-1, although there is the second leg still to come.

Joey came over and played with Ben until gone 3am! They get on so well, playing Fifa and watching films.

In the morning we all went to St Andrews to commemorate Remembrance Day. We all went in our Brownies, Cubs and Guides whilst Daddy turned up in his suit.

After the church service we met with the Fars and went to the Scout hut where Ben not only got invested into Warburton Scout group, but also received a certificate for his Silver Award. Basically he's earned enough badge to get an award. We were proud of him.

Ben earning his Silver Award

In the afternoon we had a family game of Risk. Yes a photo where we were all laughing at a game of Risk and not falling out with each other.... Mummy was first to crack. 'I hate this stupid game' I think were here words. Daddy won!

Risky laughing

title.value: Remembrance Service, Ben's Silver Award and promotion to Scout

info.content:
Daddy didn't parkrun this week. He wasn't feeling too well! The weather was also terrible so we played at home.
