Never mind, the pudding was an interesting combo of a lemon drizzle cake with a slab of yellow dyed icing shaped and carved into a New York taxi. The thought was there. The Empire State building sponge cake, was not handled with particular care in the preparation stage, so end up more like the World Trade Centre towers! Never mind, the boys has spent 3 or 4 hours in preparing for the meal which was reflected in the marks given.

So as the final host, Ben added the scores and anounced that Daddy came 5th, then Mummy, Katie and Jessica all came joint second, leaving Ben as the winner by a single point. He celebrated and shouted winner. It was only 10 minutes later when discussing who gave what marks, that Jessica had given a 6 out of 10, not the nine that Ben had read! Jessica was seeking revenge as she had not forgotten that Ben gave her 1 out of 10 last year! So really Ben came 4th and there was a three way joint winners. However, everyone had accepted Ben as the winner of the prize and got on with it which was nice.

There was a break in the middle of the afternoon. Daddy had treated Farmor et el to a Frenchies, the new Ice Cream Parlour in Camberley, themed like a 1950's American Diner. It was nice that Auntie Susan also came along. Ben had the Blue Moon ice cream, whilst Katie and Jessica had a raspberry and lemon cone with bubblegum balls and marshmellows. Daddy was wincing at the amount of sugar being consumed by all!

Ben's Blue Moon

Lemon and Raspberry, with bubblegum balls and marshmellows

Frenchies Diner

Bens Come Dine With Me Effort

title.value: Frenchies, Come Dine With Me Ben and Resuts

info.content:
It was Rushmoor's inaugrial parkrun and it so happened to co-inside for Frimley Lodge closing for the Surrey Heath show. Over 400 turned up (a parkrun record). It was sunny and all the usual suspects turned up. Even the girls came along to watch and cheer us on. Uncle Michael came 8th with Daddy and Benny coming in at the mid 26 minute mark. It was ran around the polo fields, despite all that space, there were still some bottlenecks.

We dashed straight from there down to Winton to see Charlotte's current residence. She shares a rented house with her friend and her husband. We met Loz for the first time as well. After Daddy had a shower we went to Boscombe Beach and chilled for a bit. We played on the rocks and had a little paddle. After our picnic we travelled to Ringwood and the excellent Moors Valley Country Park. There were loads of different play equipment to go on a tree top walk. We ended with an ice cream and saying goodbye to Auntie Charlotte and Loz.

In the evening we went over to Chertsey Town Football Club as Daddy was involved in the supporters v First XI match. The First XI were short on numbers so Daddy represented them. He came on from the subs bench after 20 minutes and did well playing as a three at the back. He was the centre half general! We got a bit bored in the second half so sloped off home and left Daddy with the Fars. A good, long day

The Lineup

Paddling

Rocks

title.value: Rushmoor Parkrun, Charlotte Bournemouth, Daddy Chertsey Football

info.content:
We all went to church and left Daddy with the Fars working in the back garden. The boys are still sorting out the base for the shed that arrives later next month.

After lunch, Ben with the cubs and Mummy went to St Michael's church in Camberley for the St George's Day parade. Meanwhile, Daddy, Katie and Jessa went swimming at the Arena. Daddy just sat at the edge of the pool as he wasn't feeling too well. the girls played with the Dive sticks pretty much for the whole time.

title.value: More Garden Work, Swimming, St George's Day Parade

info.content:
Daddy was all alone in this week's parkrun as Ben had Yuraj's birthday party to go to, which he was very excited about. It was a laser quest party, and he and his mates had been discussing strategies for the past week or so.

The rest of us were at Farmor's brunch in the morning.

We had a bit of a disaster in the afternoon with the bike rack, which ultimately meant we didn't go for one of our walks!

Ben has moved on to the next craze, which is the Minecraft computer game. The boy is addicted!

The table of food

title.value: Yuraj Birthday and Farmor Birthday Brunch

info.content: Katie went to a lot of effort for her Come Dine With Me. She really want to win obviously.
Daddy met with some old work friends; Michael and Stuart in the Crooked Billet near Hook. Very nice to catch up.
Daddy got a free ticket and went to watch Reading v Middlesborough at the Mad Stadt with Fat Phil.

We met for the Sanders at Shalford Mill, a small National Trust place, but did do an egg hunt, which is now a traditional annual event for us. It took us less than 30 mins to go around the mill to find all the clues and collect our eggs. Having finished early we went for a walk in to the lovely bluebell carpeted woods nearby.

Bluebells in woods in Shalford with the Sanders

For the rest of the day we chilled, prepared for school and Katie continued to work hard in practice Maths questions for her impending Sats.

title.value: Shalford Mill Egg Hunt with Sanders

info.content:
After an early church service we travelled to Alton for an Elder Sunday roast. As ever the crackling on the pork was top dollar. We played on the Xbox, Just Dance game which was a lot of fun.

We then all dashed over to Uncle Pete's for his traditional gathering and general madness. Unfortunately the weather had turned bad today, so we were unable to do the egg hunt in the back garden. We had fun playing upstairs mainly with Barbie's and Playstation 2.

title.value: Easter - Elders Lunch, Peter's Egg Hunt

info.content:
In the morning Ben and Daddy went to pick Max up from his mum's and drove up to Bushy Park, the home of parkrun. We met with Unc Michael and Joey who ran with Ben. It was a nice flat, gravelly track with over 1100 runners! There were even 3 massage tables there as well. Daddy managed to get his year's best time at 23:30-ish, the rest of us got quick times in the 26 minute region. Joey smashed his PB by 3 minutes!

We didn't hang about as we went around to the Stoddart's for lunch and an Easter Egg hunt. We left dad at home replacing the fence panels which had blown down months ago. There has been such a demand for fence panels, that daddy only yesterday got some, and that was by luck.

Daddy was buoyed by his running performance he went out for another few miles along the canal and into Deepcut, whilst the rest of us watched a very entertaining Britain's Got Talent or as Jessica calls it, 'Scots Got Brilliant Talent'.

We left Daddy at stupid o'clock and drove to Gatwick to welcome Ma Ma and Pop Pop back from their Jamaica holiday. They brought us back some lovely t-shirts.

Meanwhile Daddy was busy cooking the gammon and pork on the BBQ. The Fars, Uncle Graham and Auntie Susan came around the house for the first time as a couple. We sat outside all 9 of us and had a good old roast, BBQ style.

After we played some games and chilled in the conservatory. I think everyone was filled. Even the mighty Farfar couldn't finish his lunch!

Susan and Jess enjoying a joke

title.value: Ma Ma Airport Pickup - Gays Good Friday Lunch

info.content:
A bit weird with just the three of us waking in the house. We were constantly in 'text' contact with Katie as she had mummy's phone.

Daddy got up early, borrowed the Fars car and met with Nick, Michael and Steve for a 30 mile bike ride around Hook, Odiham type area. The weather was glorious, so had a nice leisurely trundle around.

In the afternoon we chilled a bit. Daddy carried on the garden clear up. There is a lot of work to be done to get that into shape. We did manage to slope off to the park and fly the aeroplane and watch some park football.

After putting Jessica to bed, the three of us embarked on a game of monopoly. This game went true to form. Mummy, lording it about, letting everyone know she was winning, but overspent and went out first. Ben being ultra picky on the rules got upset when Daddy charged him for landing on his property. Ben reluctantly paid but went into a big huff. So Daddy gave him the money back to keep the peace, but then got in a huff, because Ben did not play in the spirit of the game and for him getting in a huff. Why do we play these games? We all ended of good terms. A busy weekend.

Rockets Are Go

title.value: Park, Jessica pickup, 30 mile Bike Ride, Gardening

info.content:
First up was a Family Parkrun at Frimley Lodge Park. There were 6 Gay's in total competing. Daddy was able to give it full beans, but still came in well short (23:51) of his PB. Ben shepherded Katie around, but gashed his knee open when he waved at Farmor and ran into Katie! They still came in around the 31 minute mark. Mummy and Jessica both completed one lap, as did Farfar who came in 30 seconds better than his previous week's time!

Katie went with an old school friend Leah Sumner and he Dad and sister to their Auntie's flat in Lee On The Solent, near Fareham for a few days. It was sad to see her leave, and Daddy played the Beatles track, She's Leaving Home. Katie was raring to go. It's good to get away for the parents sometimes. We know she'll be a good girl as well.

Making things worse, Jessica decided she was going to her first night away from any family and went to Rainbow camp near Tilford. The three of us took her there and made sure she settled in OK. Of course, she was of a similar disposition, and was raring for mummy and daddy to go and could not wait for her adventure. She was there with her good friend Jermima. They had a great time making lots of craft, running about and playing.

This just left Mummy, Daddy and Ben. As we were reasonably close and the weather was glorious, we decided to go for another walk out of the book. This time Thursley Bog. A place we've never been close to before. It was lovely with the first mile or so on board-walks around the bog. It was only a 2 miler, so we didn't feel too bad taking a hobbling Ben around.

From here, we headed via the scenic route down to Alton where we spent the evening watch the TV and having a nice spot of dinner. We enjoyed the new front room with it's fire and comfy chairs. Lovely.

Thursley Bog

Jess and Jemima

title.value: Walk 56: Thursley Bog, Family Parkrun, Katie to holiday to Lee On The Solent, Jessica Rainbow Camp, and Elders Dinner

info.content:
Jessica's turn for Come Dine With Me. We all had to dress in red of some sort. We had a Spag Bol for starter, Pizza for main and a Diabetics dream for pudding!

Come Dine With Me, Jessica Styley

In the morning the Fars came around to help Daddy do work in the garden. Currently the boys are making a shed base and Farmor was tidying the borders. There is a lot of work to do, but things are moving the right direction.

The rest of us went to church as usual. After a snacky lunch, we headed off to Compton and the Watts Gallery where we started another walk out of the Surrey Kiddiwalk guide. This was a 4 miler, which pleased us kiddies. The usual lethargy wore off after 20 minutes and we had some nice family time. It is really nice to just have time together, a chance to catch up on how everyone is. We passed many walkers along the way. I guess they were ticking off the well trodden North Downs way off their lists.

Family shot at the Loseley Lake

Katie and Ben enjoying a chat

Ben in front of Loseley House

Daddy and Ben went to Frimley Lodge today to run and celebrate James' 100th Parkrun. Well he says 100, officially it's 101st, unofficially it's 99. So take your pick. Anyway, good to see him reach the milestone. Hopefully he'll get his jacket.

It was Katie's turn to host Grace, Natasha and Nina for a sleepover. The 'fun' began at 4pm, when we all sat down to watch the Grand National together. We had a sweepstake which made us scream at the TV for our horses to win.

Daddy took us all to the park, where we played on the swings and flew a toy aeroplane which provided much entertainment, especially for Ben and Jessica. Daddy got it stuck up in the tree, 30 foot up which provided much amusement and members of the public to help get it down!

We headed off to the chip shop for dinner and us children had 4 film lined up: Frozen, The Smurfs 2, Monsters High 13 Wishes and some other Monsters Inc. related film. Ben became an honorary girls for the night. They stayed up till 2:30am!!

We are very proud of Katie. She is such a lovely girl.

Nina, Natasha, Grace, Katie, Ben and Jess

Ben won his school class reading challenge which entailed reading the most books in half a term out of his class. He read about 11 books. He won lots of Beast Quest stuff, like badges, pens and bookmarks. Well done Ben.

He also won Star Of Week on Mrs Good's final day of her career. He won it for being 'An independent thinker and a brilliant problem solver'. Excellent.

title.value: Ben Wins School Reading Challenge And Star Of The Week

info.content: As soon as we awoke we had early breakfast. I had Coco Pops and three pieces of toast. Next we met with the year group and went to see all the animals on site. There were goats, rams, lambs, pigs, ponies which looked like a goat. They had mini-horns on their head. After lunch, we packed our bags then got on the coach homeward bound. We stopped off a Maiden Castle, an iron age hill fort. We went to the very, very top of it. We kept thinking we were at the top, when we got there we found another step in the terrace. We then went back on the coach back to school where Mummy was excited to see me. We arrived 47 minutes late.

In the morning I did Living History. A person dressed up as a Roman solider and took us in a Roman-British house. I also made butter and bread flour. For lunch I had the same as yesterday. In the afternoon we did Den building which was my favourite activity over the whole trip. There were already some sticks there which me and my room mates used to build one big den. After we draped army netting over our den to make it blend into it's surroundings. We then had a bit of a play time before going to the Pirate Party. This was a disco where everyone turned up. We had a bit of a boogie and played a couple of games. One was flip the coin, the other a dance competition. We went to bed about 10pm.

Ben went off last Monday for two nights away with the school to New Barn, near Dorchester. We at home have missed him loads.

Account from Ben. When I got there, the first thing I did was go to my room which was opposite Katie's when she came here. The people in my room were Yuraj, Kai, Sandjog, Reece and Jimonez. We quickly dropped off our bags and went to have our lunch. My lunch consisted of: white bread with no butter on, chocolate spread, salt and vinegar crisps, Penguin biscuit and Apple Juice.

Next, I went orienteering. My partner was Yuraj. There were 10 points to find, each had two letters on to memorize and report back. We were the second to finish out of the whole year of boys. Next we worked on our diary. It said lots of things about our activities. After that, we went to do pottery. I made a clay dog. Last on Monday, the staff at New Barn read us a story. It was a Danish story which had a ghost, a King and poisoning and murder in it. It was a ghoulish story.

Yesterday we left Mummy at home to get on with her essay for play-school, whilst the rest of us headed off to Farnborough to get some bits for Mothers Day

Mummy was treated to croissants in bed (well croissants were on a plate), a couple of Lee Child's books, mint chocolates, liquorice comfits, nuts and some lovely cards.

Daddy went off to meet with his mummy, whilst we went to church and made some posses of flowers for the mothers in the church service.

In the afternoon we met with the Barnett's at Mytchett Canal centre.

A gaggle of mothers

Riding through the woods

Here is Ben's Poem entry

My library is the place to be

There are so many books to see

I've told all my mates

The books are great!

My library is the place to be

My library is the place to be

It is a world of fantasy

Superheroes fly

And villains spy

My library is the place to be

My library is the place to be

Nobody ever disturbs me

If I sit all day

As the hours tick away

My library is the place to be

By Ben Gay (Aged 8)

Ben entered his poem into the library poem competition. It had to be about his library.

Ben's Poem Displayed at Frimley Green Library

Daddy and Ben went off to do our home park run. The Elders came over, so Uncle Michael paced Ben around to his second best time ever. Funnily enough they were both slightly disappointed with the result, as they were hoping to get close to Ben's PB. After a play with Joey and Lily for a bit and bacon rolls all round, the Elders left and we went over to Chobham for another walk out of the book.

This time it was Chobham Common. Funny, as Daddy has lived here for a long time, he's not done that bit of the common before. We all had a good run around and blew away the cobwebs.

Chobham Common Memorial

Ben and Michael finishing Parkrun

In the morning the Fars came over to help Daddy continue with the shed base preparations.

In the afternoon we went over to the Elders and had a play.

We got up early for another Parkrun tourist trip, this time to Hampstead Heath. Max had invited another old school friend along, Nicholai, from Copenhagen. It was good to run again with Max as well and the last occasion wasn't just a one off.

Nicholai was pretty fit, being in the Danish Army. His best 5k time was in the 17 minute something region. Blooming quick. Anyway Daddy chatted lots with him even on the run. We got a good time in the 26 minutes this week, which considering the hills was a very pleasing time.

We stepped into Hampstead Heath village and went to a tea shop for ermm.. tea and toast, along with our two friends.

We said our goodbyes and caught a bus southbound and headed towards our start point, which was St Paul's cathedral. They're we had a spot of lunch and basked in the sunshine, before crossing the Millennium bridge over to Southwark. We passed the Globe and Golden Hinde and some small theatre which is older than the Globe. We toured around a busy Southwark Cathedral, then the highlight, Borough Market. Daddy treated us to a large cookie, and croissants. They were delicious. So much good food, hard to go wrong really. We stopped off at the George Inn close by which is the oldest Inn in London. Katie was checking the beer barrels.

We headed over London Bridge where we saw an interesting Pedi-Bus. About 10 people cycling on this platform to provide the energy to move the platform on. Genius idea. Looked like it was being used for hen/stag parties as most of the passengers were drinking! We ended the walk at Monument, then made the 19 stop journey along the District line back to Gunnersbury and home.

In the evening Mummy went out to Zizi's for a surprise dinner for Anna Strangle.

title.value: Walk 53: Shakespeare London. Hampstead Heath Park Run.

info.content:
Mummy's turn for Come Dine With Me. Started with tinned soup, spag boll, then the deal clincher, a sweetie pizza, where Mummy presented us with pizza dough which we had to flatten at the dinner table, then add the selection of chocolates, marshmallows and sweeties. Extra for marks for originality on the pudding. Marks off for tinned soup!

Sweetie Pizzas

We dropped Daddy off with James who along with other park runners were off to run in the inaugural Surrey half marathon. The course was basically a 'there and 'back' from the Spectrum to Woking town centre.

Surrey Half'ers

It was a hot day and Daddy had not done a lot of training, but still managed to do 2:13 hours, which was not too bad. It was pretty hilly as well. He got a lift home with Paula Fudge, an ex world record holder at 5k. It was interesting speaking to her about her career.

Meanwhile, the rest of us went to Fleet for Joshua Sanders, 3rd birthday party. It was nice to catch up.

title.value: Surrey Half Marathon, Joshua Sanders 3rd Birthday Party

info.content:
We decided to do the home parkrun today. Jasper Henderson was also doing it which meant only one thing. A race and a faster pace from Ben. We set off in the lead, Jasper caught up with 1km to go, thinking that'll be it for Ben. However, he upped the pace and shrugged Jasper off and finished in 25:39 minutes which smashed his old PB by 1 minute, 7 seconds. He was most proud and phoned Uncle Michael to tell him.

In the afternoon, mummy went to the Mall in Camberley to collect for Marie Curie cancer for an hour and a half. After which she went with us lot to Alice's birthday party at Cascades swimming pool near Gravesend. We had a good time, although inherited some bruises from the flumes!

Meanwhile daddy was preparing an epic meal of 3 courses. He knew the children were unlikely to go for the menu. However, he ploughed on. Starters was pineapple and strawberries. Main was a Jamie Oliver filo pie with spinach, cheese, nuts and various herbs, with a tomato salad and cucumber salad. The children barely touched this. Finally we ended with a very lemony, lemon drizzle cake.

During the meal we put forward our ideas for the summer holiday and voted two finalists. Ben's, Northern Ireland and Jessica's Scotland holidays were the winners. So they now have to cost it out and actually come up with an itinerary for the final vote.

title.value: Ben PB Parkrun, Marie Curie, Alice 7th Birthday, Daddy Come Dine With Me

info.content:
Daddy took Ben and Katie, along with the Fars and Richard to Wembley to watch a friendly international between England and Denmark. Of course Ben was supporting Denmark and Katie, who really couldn't care too much, was on the English side.

We took Richard and met with the Fars in Ruslip for a McDonalds dinner. The Fars were not too pleased with this. Farfar, boycotted the place and went elsewhere, whilst Farmor needed help order fast food!

We caught the tube and got off at Wembley Park and walked down Olympic way. There were thousands and thousands of people. We'd never seen so many. I guess that was the main reason for coming, was to experience such a large crowd. It was a very friendly and safe atmosphere.

We had seats right at the back of the stadium. No one sat behind us! Still we still had a reasonable view. There were 65,000 people there. The game was OK, enjoyed by the children especially when the Mexican wave started up.

The game ended with a late winner for England, making it a 1-0 scoreline. We had the long, busy walk back to the tube, and then a car journey ending at midnight back home. School in the morning.

Wembley

Daddy and Ben went to Wimbledon Common parkrun where Daddy met up with Max Dinning, a school friend from 26 years ago! Wow they had a lot to catch up on. Anyway, it was a very muddy run and was proceeded with a nice cup of tea and a catch up.

In the afternoon we all went out for a family walk starting at the air-force memorial in Englefield Green. It was very wet and the whole area had been flooded just two weeks before. We looked around the memorial and saw the surnames: Gay and Weston. I wonder if they are relatives of ours? We continued our walk which ended up over the Pleasure grounds. The return journey was quite eventful. We crossed some wet fields, that got more and more wet as we ventured. Soon the water got so high Daddy had to carry us one by one. Eventually the water got too high for Daddy, and he almost lost balance in the sinking mud when he had Katie on his shoulders. Not sure how they did not fall in. Anyway we had to leave Ben and Jessica around the corner whilst Daddy was ferrying KAtie across. All the girls were getting hysterical. They decided that Mummy and Katie should continue to the car, whilst the others could not continue and headed back to the pleasure grounds, via shinning a tree to overcome the barbed wire fence.

Airforce Memorial

Going down Coopers Hill

Puddles, lakes

After church we rushed over to Godstone Farm and joined Ma Ma, Pop Pop, Ellie, Lily, Joey, and Toby. We had a great time on the hill slide.

Train down the hill slide

Summer Teale came over for a sleepover with Katie. Surprisingly they didn't stay up too late. They played teenage mums! Daddy and Ben went and did the Alice Holt parkrun, whilst the rest of us played in the playground. We then went direct to Ikea in Southampton where mummy and daddy picked up a few supplies as well as ideas for when the extension gets put up.

We had a busy day. In the morning Daddy borrowed a high ladder and he went up and cleaned all the gutters and upstairs windows, whilst the rest of us went to church. Also all the fence panel that got blown over needed cleaning up.

Meanwhile Ben had an early meet at Farnborough Station as he went up with the cubs to the Outdoor Show at Excel, London. He had a great time. As well as handling a snake, he was raving about the stunt show and all the freebies he got. We love the Columbia Cub group. They're great.

Ben had a lucky escape as the rest of us continued on the Surrey Kids walk book, with an excursion from Pirbright to Fox Corner. Daddy's legs began to get pins and needles in the end so we had to rush home and feed him some sugar!!!

Ben handling a snake

Through Pirbright

title.value: Walk 51: Pirbright and Fox Corner. Cubs at Outdoor Show

info.content:
We went to the other side of Camberley and followed the Barossa Common walk from the walk. Ben was very happy and very grumpy all at the same time.

Happy Walkers!

Daddy and Ben went with the other Frimley Flyers over to Greenham Common for the Newbury Parkrun. It started sunny, then the heavens opened and the temperature dropped. The photographer saw Daddy's 50th badge and thought that he was 50 years old!!! Cheeky.

We rushed back and then went over to Alton for Joey's birthday party. He had invited 3 other mates and Ben over to Basingstoke Ten Pin bowling.

We rushed then to Poppy's party which was a swimming affair at Farnborough leisure centre.

title.value: 50th Parkrun, Joey's 9th Birthday Party, Poppy's 11th Birthday Party

info.content:
We had to call on Farfar to look after Jessica in the morning. Farfar read lots to Jess who has had her second time off school since Christmas. I hope she'll be OK.

In the evening was her Parent's Evening. Thankfully the teacher was pleased with her progress. Overall happy, attentive, lots of friends and either average or slightly above average in her subjects. Well done Jessa.
After church we went over to Windsor where we met with Uncle Steven and Eva for a swim and play on the flumes and wave machine.

Katie has now reached the age of what I'd call, adolescence. Physically changes can be noticed and emotionally. In the mornings she is not so good as she used to be. She is still as lovely as can be though

We went to Greenwich for a surprise trip around Greenwich as a 40th wedding anniversary celebration. We started by Wolfe's statue at the top of the hill, then made our way down into town where we had some lunch.

We had the usual race under the tunnel and caught a DLR and tube to North Greenwich where we tried out the cable cars.

Fly Emerites

Oaking about

Album Cover

title.value: Greenwich - Ma Ma and Pop Pop's 40th Wedding Anniversary

info.content:
Katie and Leah Rushforth have been selected to become house captains. As such Katie has had to make a speech to a quatre of the school. She, as well as the rest of us are most proud.

Katie sporting house captains badge

Ben spent the weekend away at cub camp, which is always very good for him, getting away from the parents! He absolutely loves playing games, building fires, tee pees and this time catapults. He was also invested.

Getting sworn in officially as a cub

After Daddy Parkrunned and lunch we went out to see where Daddy works in Eashing and played by the river. Jessica was not feeling too well. We stopped off on the way home at Elstead and played in the playground for half and hour or so.

In the evening Mummy and Daddy went to the Six Bells pub in Farnham to celebrate with the rest of the family Ma Ma and Pop Pop's 40th wedding anniversary.

title.value: Eashing, Ma Ma and Pop Pops 40th Anniversary Skittles Night

info.content:
Daddy and Ben took Uncle Michael and Joey to the London Motor Museum in Hayes. They had a great time looking at all the customized cars.

GT40

Del Boys

The purchase of 162 Frimley Green Road has not gone without incident. After a month in the house we receive a letter from the SRA to say that Ashworth Law, the firm who dealt with our house transaction, had been stopped from trading due to dishonesty claims. We thought we'd be OK because our sale went through a month previously and surely the contracts would have not been exchanged or completed. WRONG! It would appear that the money obtained from our house and the mortgage was used to buy the new house, no problem, however the solicitors failed to get around to paying off 42 Swordsmans Road. As a result, the new occupiers could not register with the Land Registry as our mortgage was still unpaid. Furthermore, the Stamp Duty of Â£8250 had not been paid off via the Inland Revenue. So not only did the money not get paid, but the contracts were never completed it would appear on the day! What a joke of a conveyancey system this country has. So we have been left with paying off two mortgages, been fined a Â£100 for late Stamp Duty payment and lobbing out Â£175 per hour for a new set of solicitors to complete the sale and purchase of the respective houses we own!

An intervening agent is assigned who acts similar to an administrator. They are the ones who freeze the accounts. Nothing comes in or out. They said it will be at least up till the late summer before any sort of resolution can be expected. Even then nothing is guaranteed. In the meanwhile we have filed for compensation via the SRA. In total we are currently Â£87,000 down.

Ashworth Law Article

title.value: Â£87,000 down after Solicitor is stopped by SRA for dishonesty

info.content:
Daddy was pleasantly surprised to hear that he'd done well at work and was given a Â£100 to spend on a meal for the family as a reward! Woo Hoo. Where to go? Well, we chose somewhere a little different, Buona Sera At The Jam, Kings Road, Chelsea for a spot of lunch, after parkrun of course.

It was a little different as it was the bunk bed equivalent of restauranting. We were led to our table via a small ladder, in this small, narrow eatery. We had three courses and drinks which and a good chat with the restaurant owner who we didn't think was the full ticket.

Happy Eaters

Climb to the table

We then caught a bus across London to St John Soames museum in Lincoln Inn Fields, Holborn. We left Mumma to queue whilst the rest of us played 40-40. The museum was different as it had a collection of John Soames artefacts when he travelled around the world. The house was certainly different. Not really for children, but a good experience.

title.value: Buona Sera At The Jam and Sir John Soames Museum

info.content:
Seeing we had no Christmas Party this year and everyone had entertained us, we had just the Elders over for New Years celebration. We had the usual fair of games and mayhem.

Game face

Mummy and Daddy made us wait until 6am until we were allowed for us all to start opening presents. I think Father Christmas had delivered 18 presents each!

Katie and Jessica got quite a bit of Barbie stuff, whilst Ben had a big Nerf gun and lots of Lego sets. It was all opened in good spirits and had a lovely time exploring what each other had received.

Then it was Mummy and Daddy's turn in their bedroom before moving downstairs to open presents we had got from friends.

We made our way over to the fars for 9:30-ish. Daddy had contemplated a Parkrun, but thought better of it as it was family time. Mummy had gone for an early half an hour church service at 8am. There were only 4 others there!

At the fars we had a lovely breakfast with Giffler, croissants and nice bread. We opened the present from Uncle Ron, which was a lovely big telescope which was extremely kind of him. We also had the annual game of Coppit which is fiercely contested, especially amongst the younger elements of the family.

Present time

Family Lineup

Daddy's new job meant that he did not have to go into work today which was a bit of luck as the weather was terrible. Work had a power cut for most of the day and the river had burst it's banks and flooded the road.

In the morning Daddy spent an hour and a half onto Talk Talk trying to get the internet connection sorted out. It was now 3 weeks in the new house and still no connectivity. He was fobbed off again with 3 different explanations as to the problem.

The rest of us were getting really excited about Christmas. Ben was more hyper than the other two.We played games for most of the day.

In the afternoon we went around to the Fars for the traditional fare of a Danish Christmas. First up a treasure hunt which Farfar thought would be a lot more challenging than it turned out to be. The children each won Â£10. I think this is one of their favourite gifts. Not sure why. I think it is the power of choice of what to purchase. They still need to respect money a little more and keep it safe. Katie has no concept of saving either. She wanted to go shopping to spend her money. When asked what she wanted to spend it on, she didn't really know. It was the fact that she could hand it over to the shop keeper I think thrilled her.

Auntie Susan and Graham arrived soon after and we sat down at about 5pm for the feast. This year the food was cooked as good as it can get. The pork was amazing. New secret weapon apparently is the 'cooking bag'. Need to try that out. Daddy again went for being fatty of the year, having double helpings for about everything..... and he found the nut in the riselamange!

Us children had chippolates, but steal a bit of crackling off the pork

After food and washing up we played the 'dice game'. A variant on the 'Chinese auction'. We had good fun at that.

Then came the main event. Us children had already been casing out the presents beforehand. Ben was the main organiser and distributor. He was turning more Weston-like in his methods. In the good old days there was only one present being opened at any one time. Ben's decided to give people their presents in batches, so there would be 3 or 4 people opening their queue of presents at any one time. Ben could not understand any other way when told to slow down.

We got through the present opening in about 45 minutes we would say. I think everyone was pleased with their haul. Katie received a magic box set which Uncle Graham and Katie went through and tried a few tricks on us. We ended the evening at about 9pm and returned home. Not too sure how much sleep we got that night. There must have been a period between 11pm and 2am when we actually slept solidly. Jessica said she couldn't get to sleep as Father Christmas had put too many presents on her bed!

Presents all opened

It was incredibly wet outside and when Daddy turned up straight from work we wondered if he had been dragged through a puddle he was so wet. Anyway we went to the new-ish Frankie And Benny's at Westgate, Aldershot. We had a lovely time.
Ben and Katie had starring roles in the Nativity Play performed in front of the whole church in Paddock Hill. They were great. Farmor and Farfar popped along to see it too.

Mummy went out with Paula to the Frimley Green Pre School works do at the Village Hotel.

The rest of us got dolled up as well. Auntie Charlotte was the make up stylist. Daddy didn't like his little girls having all that make-up on. It's just not right.
Mummy and Daddy had a Swordsmans Road party. It was nice to see everyone again.

After parkrun, we went off to the Frimley CofE Christmas Fair. Ben had volunteered to be an Elf for Santa's Grotto. He looked so sweet.

Farmor came along and stopped by to see our new house properly.

After what seems an eternity to put through the sausage machine we finally moved house today. Of course, Daddy took the cheaper option and decided that we should move all our stuff rather than get removal men in. Over the past 2 or 3 weeks we've been boxing up and trying to find somewhere appropriate to store the boxes. The garage has been filled for weeks. Katie's bedroom was used as a store room after the bed had been dismantled. All in all, the house was looking pretty uninhabitable for the past few days.

In today's crack squad we had Daddy, Mummy, Farfar, Uncle Peter, Pop Pop and Uncle Michael. A few of them were here the night before filling the Luton up with it's first load.

Mr and Mrs Reeve were still packing and clearing up when Daddy knocked on the door at the agreed 9:30 and basically was not allowed back again until 11-ish. The crack squad then decided to have brunch at the Deepcut Cafe. A first.

After a round of fry ups we were allowed to start dumping our gear around the back of the house in the garden. Luckily the weather was dry, but windy and threatening clouds above. At least it wasn't too cold.

After shifting the first load, we went back for a second, this time with some of the larger items. Time was pressing and surprisingly we needed a third load as well.

The troops did fantastically well, there were minimal breakages / damage. The funniest bit is when Farfar reversed the Luton into Pop Pop's car. Not much damage done thankfully.

The light was drawing in, the rain started, so there was a bit of a rush to get all the stuff into the house. Most of it was just dumped into the conservatory, awaiting Mummy and Daddy to sort it all out over the next few days and weeks.

One by one people departed. The Fars stayed around for the prize fish and chip dinner, although this time it was an Indian and Chinese takeaway.

Whilst all this fun was happening Ben was at Jaspers, Katie at Nina's and Jessica helping out. It was only later in the evening that we all got together and was taken on a tour of the house. We loved it. At first us girls are sharing a room. No more bunk beds, and Benny had a room all to himself. The first time since he had a cot!

Daddy managed to rig up the TV to Freeview so they relaxed at about 9pm watching Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here.
Ben had cub camp for the weekend. This time they played lots of games, made tye dye t-shirts and went to the Lightbox Theatre in Woking
Jessica was again in her own little world when it came to her Christmas Play that mummy and daddy came to see. We can not work her out as she is so expressive normally. Here she seems barely awake!

We went over to the Barnett's for a Sunday lunch which beats all Sunday lunches, prepared not by Joyce, but by Uncle Dawg! Fantastico. We had a trip to the local park and a game of Newmarket for sweets.

Roast Pork - Kiddy Style

Beautiful Mummy

Ben enjoying success at Newmarket

In the morning Ben proudly wore his great grandfather war medals, was the flag bearer, much to his delight, and played an acting role at the Remembrance service, St Andrews. Katie was representing the Guides and Jessica the Rainbow pack.

Ben the flag bearer

After the service Ben and his good friend Jasper had to 'jump the log' which is the official ceremony where they move from Beavers to being a Cub.

We then dashed over to the Sanders household, which we have not seen for a good long while and had a lovely Lasagne lunch and play.

title.value: Remembrance Day - Ben Jumping The Log - Sanders Lunch

info.content:
We went over from Istead Rise to watch the annual Firecracker event at Thurrock. We had a great time.

The Boys dreaming

Ben dreaming

For Pop Pops birthday we headed down to East Sussex to do the Kipling Walk, the last out of our outer London treks. It was a 3 mile, muddy affair through a lot of fields.

62 year old

Jessa

In the evening the Elders joined us, and some of us went to Broadwhitch Farm for a fright ride on the tractor.

Daddy started at employee number 17 at Net Evidence in Eashing, Godalming. It was a good day. The CEO sat with him for over 2 hours explaining the product in the morning, and had others help set-up his computer in the afternoon.

We went off with Ma Ma, Lily and Natasha around the usual suspects around town. First stop Great Grandma, followed by Uncle Howard, Farfar and Uncle Richard. We collected so many sweets.

Scaring Howard

Scaring Farfar

title.value: Haloween and Last Day at CNL Software

info.content:
The Fars very kindly took us on a surprise trip up to Clapham Common to watch a circus act. We had a spot of bother finding the place, but Katie saw a poster signposting the way to the big top.

It was a good circus. There was one act where there was a huge hamster wheel, as tall as our house and they had to keep running as fast as possible to make sure they didn't end up at the top of the wheel.

On the way home we were treated to a black cab trip back to the station. Katie went on about this more than the circus trip itself! Ben loved the sword that he was treated to.

We stayed overnight at the Fars, had chips and pizza and stayed up till 11pm!

Katie has stepped up to Guides which she is very excited about. They are so much more grown up. Katie said that they do stuff as opposed to Brownies where there was a lot of talking about doing stuff.

Katie being sworn in

Well we were supposed to do this tomorrow, but swapped our plans around as the weather forecast was even worse than today's. Despite the constant drizzle the day was not too badly effected by the weather. We left early in the morning and arrived at opening time at 10am. First roller-coaster that could be seen was the Sonic Pinball. Like a Waltzer car on a roller coaster. This was really good Katie and Ben were a little scared which was good. Jessica and Mummy went on some of the smaller rides, but Jessica is not satisfied with piddly, little roundabouts any more. No she has to take Daddy on the Enterprise. A super fast, upside down big wheel type ride. She absolutely loved it, where as Daddy was thinking it went too fast, too much upside down and what it was doing to his stomach!!! Again, again. Mummy had the dubious pleasure next turn. Ben went on Submission, his favourite ride as it also went upside down. It was like a flying carpet ride but set at all different angles for the rider. Katie got quite scared on some of the scary, ghost train type rides. She hated Hex, which the rest of us liked. It was certainly different. You are placed in a room. You sit down and you are made to feel that you are spinning around the room. Very good.

We tried to get on the ride called Thirteen, or Th13teen. However, it was shut which was disappointing. We did Blade, the teacup ride, the driving experience, the chair-o-plane, the traditional roundabout, Ice Age 4D, which was different again. A film which had live effects like snow and bubbles raining down, wind and even things smacking the backs of your legs! Towards the end of the day we went on the water rides much to Daddy's protests! First up the log flume which we got very wet on. Next the pirate boat ride which was awesome (especially if it was hot). Each of the pirate boats had about 10 cannons which you could fire water from. People on the side of the ride could fire at them with their own cannons. Anyway Ben got soaked, but he loved it! The final water ride was the tyre ride down the rapids which again we got wet! Daddy had one final go on Rita, which was rapid and made especially better as he sat at the front! A good day had by all, finishing up with Fish and Chips and a night's stay in a Travelodge in Stafford.

Spot the fearless and the scardi-cats

Rapid Ravine

Ooo Me Hearties

What a day. Daddy first found out that our offer on the house on Frimley Green Road has been accepted. Â£275k. We are all well pleased, even though the house is probably slightly smaller than what we have now. But it's in a great location, has a large garden and most importantly has potential to extend.

And finally Daddy found that Net Evidence has offered a job at their place in Eashing, Godalming. It equates to a 15% pay rise, and better career prospects.

We went up to London with Auntie Charlotte and met up with Barrie, Freya and Harrison in a lay-by off the M3. The professional driver, Barrie West, who has driven to London on many occasions got lost! After 30 mins of waiting around we walked from our parking spot in Notting Hill Gate to the wonderful playground in Hyde Park. I think we could have stayed there all day. We had places to go and Mummies to see. We caught a bus, the first time the West children had been in a double decker, and made our way across the length of Oxford Street to Tottenham Court Road where we stopped off for an expensive Pizza Express!!! Anyway, we made it into the British Museum. Both Ben and Freya were doing projects on the Egyptians this year so thought it a nice idea to see the mummies. It held the children's interest for a bit and they asked lots of questions which was nice. We liked the building of the British Museum. A contemporary roof to match the old internals.

Hyde Park exodus

Spot the Mummy

British Museum was jumpin'

We accompanied Daddy down to Littlehampton where he kayaked with Jon and Gerry up the River Arun. En-route they befriended a seal who must of kept them company for about a mile or so into Arundel. We met up with Ma ma and went on the beach then to the pub where we shared lunch with the boys.

Halfway pub lunch

Toby William Elder was Christened in Alton with lots of family and friends there. The vicar was a good one making the service interesting. There were lots of children. After we went into the church hall for some nice nosh!

Beautiful Jessica

Ben and Katie

The man of the day.

Jessica invited quite a few friends over for her 6th birthday party. Because of the ad weather we had to do all the games inside the house which made things a bit interesting!!! Still we all had good, manic fun.

Present Time

We met in Binfield for some picnicking fun. The afternoon turned in to a big water fight between Katie, Ben and Jessica against Howard, Gerry, Peter. It was good fun.

Just not cricket

For once we had a bit of a lie in then packed a picnic for our Palaces short walk in London. We parked up at Millbank and due to Mummy's dodgy directions we managed to do everything twice it seemed. We had lunch in Parliament Square where we watched people pose for photos. We circled parliament, the Jewel Tower and Westminster Abbey before crossing Birdcage Walk into St James's Park and a go in the swings and a close up of a pelican.

Finally we played in Green Park where we saw a fountain that we've not seen before. It was half a playground fountain. However, as we were to find out it was a dangerous one. Ben slipped over twice on it, the second time he smacked his head on the marble. Katie purposely slid from the top at a faster than expected rate and smashed her legs on the ledge at the bottom. There was a silence for 2 seconds before the screams of crying began. Bit of a dampener. Daddy walked all the way back to pick the car up and met us at the Ritz before returning home for another game of Monopoly.

Parliament Fun

Green Park Dangerous Water Feature

In the morning Daddy cycled over to Phoenix Green to start a disasterous bike ride with Nick 'Jonah' King and Mr Elder. Before they even set off together Nicks valve had sheared off in his pump. Michael had punctures in both his back and front tyres!!! Boc. Anyway Daddy had a nice ride.

The weather brightened up and we all went over to Box Hill for a walk down to the stepping stones. Something achieved during the week when we went with Fiona, Thomas and Natasha.

We carried on the river route this time and we paddled in the water. Daddy swore there were things nibbling his feet, but didn't let the rest of us know. A little further on there was the coolest rope swing. All three of us had a go and it was such great fun. We eventually had to stop and crossed the river again and started a very steep climb up the hill again. It was a nice afternoon for us to go out on.

Box Hill Stepping Stones

title.value: 40 mile bike ride, Box Hill Walk

info.content:
We all went for a parkrun today. Daddy beat his PB and now is 22:11. Jess managed half a lap.

Unfortunately 1 Milden Close have decided to pull out of the house sale as Mr Davey has got cancer. We are quite down by it as we would have loved that house. Still, we have to count our chickens as we are not in Mr Davey's position. Anyway we started looking at houses again. This morning we went to view a property on the Farm Road estate. Mummy really liked it, and Daddy really did not.

The weather was pretty grotty which stopped us from doing anything outside, so we started a 3 game bank holiday series of Monopoly. We also all watched James Bond, Tomorrow Never Dies.

Daddy ran with James on the Burnham Beeches Half Marathon. Preparations were not ideal. Daddy went out with the boys the night before, and although he didn't drink he did stay up later than hoped. Also there was a lot of muscle ache from the football match he played last week. Still he had James to pace him around the 13.2 mile hilly, circuit.

The Sub 2 Hour Taskforce

When Daddy ran half marathons in 2000 in preparation for the London Marathon he didn't do well and vowed to beat 2 hours. A time which had always eluded him. All looking good 10 miles in, 30 mins to do the last 3.2 miles. However, there were up hills still to come. A fellow parkrunner, Darren, had finished his run and came back for me and James and gave loads of encouragement. Daddy really struggled up the hills near the end. It was touch and go. However, Daddy finally came in at 1:58:42. A sense of relief and a big thank you to James and Darren. Daddy has learnt control and keeping an even pace is so important.

Later in the afternoon we went around to the Fars to celebrate, sort of his birthday. We had a nice Danish meal. Ben polished off the frikadeller no probs. It was nice to see Susan and Graham. We had a treasure hunt and sweets of course as well.

Farfar Dinner

title.value: Burnham Beeches Half Marathon - Farfar Birthday Meal

info.content: After Parkrun, Barrie, Freya and Harry came around for a BBQ. The children all played so well together. Freya will come over for a sleepover one day.

Our last day. The weather was changeable and therefore we decided not to go the beach, instead another playground which we saw from the train in Bispebjerg. It had a large rope climbing frame which went around like a track. Hard to explain. There was also a massive climbing wall which was brightly sprayed.

On the return journey we stopped off for a customary hot dog from the pÃ¸lsevogn in the Town Hall Square. There were some Chilean football supporters there who we had some photos taken with. They were mad. We checked out of our hotel in the afternoon and made our way to Lise and JÃ¸rgen's who had also prepared some food for us.

It was nice to see Lise again after all her health issues she had been having for the past 12 months plus. They had not lost any of their friendlyness. It was really good to catch up, and the food again they prepared was amazing. Just wished us children would be a little more adventurous and actually try some.

Whoever did the planning needs shooting as we ran out of time in the airport and again almost didn't make the plane. We were last on again. Even more late this time.

The Fars sat with us children on the ride home and we landed at Gatwick on time. Back in Blighty. Bus to Horley, M25, home at 8pm.

It certainly was a bit different this holiday to our normal. It was just as enjoyable and good to see Denmark. We packed a lot in.

Climbing the walls

Cuban Friends

Lise and JÃ¸rgens Summer House

title.value: Denmark Holiday: Bispebjerg Park - Lise of JÃ¸rgen

info.content:
We hopped on the train to Hellerup and walked to Experimentum. A bit like In-Tech in Winchester, but on steroids. It was really good for the kids as they could design a dinosaur and see it come up on a big screen, chisel for fossils, and take part in loads of interactive, science related things from water pressures, electricity, space, wind tunnel, weights and forces, reaction times and events and even attempting to lie on a bed of nails!!

Fredericksberg was the next stop for some nostalgia swimming. The swimming pool Daddy always went to on holidays. It was still a strict regime which was a little awkward. Anyway we had a great time on the diving boards and slides. The fars came and joined in the fun to.

After an hour and a half in the pool we exited and headed down Marinedalesvej which is where Farmor, Olemor and Olefar used to live. The door to flat entrance was open so we stepped in and had a look. It was in very good shape which was nice to see. After having a go on the local playground we headed towards the Little Garden restaurant.

Well Daddy certainly filled his guts here. He and Farmor shared shared fish, eel, port, beef, bacon and desert. Daddy absolutely loved the meal and felt sick afterwards just on the quantity eaten! The rest of us ate a little more conservatively.

Experimentum - Fossil exploration

Benny Bed Of Nails

Little Garden Evening Meal

title.value: Denmark Holiday: Experimentum - FrederickBerg Swimming, Little Garden Meal

info.content:
We had a bit of a lie in this morning but Daddy and Jessica made it out for the supermarket run ritual. Before getting over to Holmens Bridge to meet with the fars, Daddy went in the Christensborg Palace where the royal reception rooms are. Very regal.

The hour long canal tour was good. It was nice just to sit and relax for an hour and being carted around the canals and see the sights even if there was a heavy down pour near the end.

We made our way to Magasin for some pastries, watched a street performer juggle some fire lit torches and then on to the Round Tower which we raced down. Ben was captivated by the Lego store and absolutely loved it all. I think he could have stayed in there all day!

We caught the Metro and went out to Bisbjerg to see where Olemor and Olefar were scattered. We eventually found the small headstone and paid our respects. It was nice for the children to do that.

We returned back into town and ended up in the Fars accommodation where Ben opened his birthday present, which was another Lego set and we had hot dogs.

Daddy decided that when he got back to the hotel that he would go out for a late evening run which actually turned into a half marathon around the sights.

Ben and Farfar on the Canal Tour

Pilot Benjamin Gay

Round Tower Dash

Lego Store

title.value: Denmark Holiday: Canal Boat - Round Tower

info.content:
We walked along the west side of the station to catch the bus. It was a disappointing site of drug users congregating and the smell of wee. Just a contrast to the other side of HovedbanegÃ¥rd where all the tourists are. However, we did spot a bakers shop which pleased us. Anyway we caught the 1A and 3A bus past JÃ¸rgen's old hairdressers shop to Valby Park, another location that Daddy hadn't visited before. There was just another unique playground with hills and towers to climb as well as animals carved from wood it seemed. After a long play we walked down to the water's edge and paddled in the water before returning through some interesting gardens back onto the bus and train, home to our hotel.

Then comes the highlight of the holiday for us children; Tivoli. First up is the 100 year old rollercoaster called Rutschebane. Everyone liked this one, and it was Daddy's old favourite. Jessica especially liked it and wanted to go on it again and again. She must have had 10 rides on it in the end.

We went on so many rides, like the Aquila, Ben's first ever upside down ride as he puts it, the Star Flyer, a glorified chair-o-plane ride, which we all found extremely scary as the ride broke down the first time we were on it. It goes very high and there was a fair wind. Daddy doesn't mind admitting he was hanging on in there a bit. Got the heart pumping.

We won a Toblerone on the bike game, had 45 minutes of fun in the fun house. We met up with Fars later in the afternoon, they even had a go in the fun house! We got out of the park for some much needed food at Jensens BÃ¸fhus, before returning again for a belly-testing load of rides. The one unique aspect of Tivoli is the fact it opens to late at night and the appearance of the park changes, there are a lot of pretty lights.

Katie's favourite ride was the Drop Tower, Daddy's was the boating lake, Mummy's the Demon roller-coaster ride which was spectacular at night, Ben's the upside-down ride and Jessica the Rutschebane. We trundled out at half ten and took the 2 minute walk back to the hotel.

Rock sliding

Rutschebane with Jessica and Mummy

On top of the Ferris Wheel

Aquila

Rolling Barrel

Candy Floos Girls

Tivoli At Night

We started by searching for the Parkrun in Amagar Faelled. The park has to be 4 square miles so Daddy was stressing a bit in order to find it in time for the traditional 9am start. We were greeted with others who were also attending and met up with a couple of other English families who were running. We didn't set the world alight, but the course was very nice and we got the same warm, friendly atmosphere as we do in Frimley Lodge.

After the boiling hot run we bussed it over to Copenhagen Zoo. Mummy remembered from her previous trip how good it was and was not disappointed this time either. One of the first things up was the polar bear enclosure. We could go underground and see them playing under the water. It was quite a site to look up and see a polar bear swimming just above us. A huge, heavy thing like that able to not sink to the bottom. Amazing.

What we liked about the zoo, as Mummy says, there is no rubbish animals, and the fact they all seemed to be fairly active, no lying around, sleeping. We saw lions, elephants being feed, a group of 7 tigers playing, monkeys swinging around and being pickles, giraffes, Mummy's favourite, the Tasmainian Devil, snakes, crocs, brown bear, all sorts. We had a lovely day there.

On the way home we walked into Hamley's and had another go around the toys to play with, and sneaked another McDonalds. Honestly the kiddies have been treated!

Amagar Fallaed Parkrun

Polar Bear Swimming

The tiger in you

Zoooo

Nerf Attack

We have found a reasonably priced supermarket at last for our breakfast. The now legendary Rema 1000. Fantastic value compared to Irma. Top travel tip that. Anyway after our morning routine we headed into town again this time searching for Ãrstedsparken, another park. We finally arrived going the scenic route. We have been so impressed with the parks in Copenhagen. They are all completely different. This one is actually supervised and managed as it has a lot of play equipment such as trikes and scooters. There was even a table football game which was good, as all 5 of us joined in. A small thing like that is just a nice memory of our holiday. We spent almost a couple of hours there before returning to the hotel for a spot of lunch and to pick our swimming gear up. Next stop Islands Brygge.

We of course walked there which took us half an hour. The weather was good and the lido was busy. It had some diving platforms from a carved ship's hull. We loved it, especially Jessica, a real water baby. She lasted longer than any of us. Some of us had a go of the diving platforms. None of us where particularly brave on that front. It was a really good setup. The coldness set in a bit which put us off from staying in too long. After a spot of sunbathing, we got changed and walked south along the water's edge. We stopped off to watch a game of kayak polo. Looks like they were having a lot of fun playing that game, although some foul play was at hand. All in good humour and spirit though. We continued till one of the new bike bridges which we crossed to Fisketorvet.

We caught a train out to Flintholm, then the Metro back into town where we splashed out on a Jensens BÃ¸fhus meal. Ben loved this meal. Best ever he reckoned.

Parklife

Islands Brygge Lido

What a contrast in the weather. It was very gloomy with some showers coming in. We had a walking day today which really pleased the children! We did plonk in a few trips to the park on the way around. We started by walking around Tivoli, Christiansborg Palace, Kongens Nytorv where we decamped into Magasin, which is a huge posh department store and played in the toy department before committing a cardinal sin by visiting McDonalds for lunch. I know, its shocking. The rain had subsided and we continued onto the picturesque Nyhavn where we saw the royal band march through the streets, the Royal Palace (Amalienborg), the Gefion Fountain, the Kastellet Fort and of course the Little Mermaid. A lot of walking so far, and the weather was inclement. We had still plenty more walking to do. Across to two parks. The first was Ãstre AnlÃ¦g where we played loads in the playground. Next was FÃ¦lledparken Park which was very cool; from the tower playground, to the biggest skate park you'll ever likely to see and the traffic playground where a mock road system was been created with real traffic lights and road crossings. We had a great time playing all over this park. We were dead on our feet. We caught the bus back to NÃ¸rreport and stopped in an excellent Pizzaria that Katie especially loved. We packed in a lot of sights and good parks today. We slept well!

Zig Zag Walk

Laura loving Lego

Girls at Nyhavn

Fountains outside the Royal Palace

Gefion Fountain

Mermaids and Merman

TV Show

Go play with the traffic

We started the day very early. Dad's alarm went off at 3:15am. It took a bit of an effort to rally the troops at first, but everyone fell into order by half past. After gulping breakfast and of course stuffing the last few essentials into the suitcase we embarked in the 4am darkness, needing to quieten the kiddies down before they woke the whole street in their excitement. Tight wad Daddy wasn't prepared to spend $80 on parking at the airport, so devised a scheme which involved looking at street view and the local bus timetables for 5am in the morning! We cruised through Gatwick, changed some money, bought books, and then looked at the departure boards only to notice that our gate had closed! Oh no. The sprint was on. Was the gate a million miles away as it always tends to be? No, fortunately. They were still queueing to board.

This was Jessica's first ever plane journey. Mummy was still nervous, but the rest of us coped fine. Luckily the weather was good, not much cloud cover and the window seats could get a nice view of southern England.

Less than 2 hours later we landed and made our way to the central railway station where our hotel Astoria was situated. We dumped our bags and walked through the city centre stopping off at the newly opened Hamley's to scout around. There were many activities and a large range of Lego sets to look at which pleased Ben, who is well into it at the moment. We were finally prized away and made our way to the Kings Garden where we played in the sandpits. The weather was gorgeous and there were a lot of students socializing. We popped around Rosenborg Castle before catching a bus for a weary troops to the Opera House at the edge of Christainhavn. The estuary was looking lovely and blue in the sunshine.

We headed back to the hotel room, which was nice and spacious, via Hamley's to spend Ben's birthday money on a Â£80 Lego set which he desperately wanted. We had an early night in our hot, top floor room.

Waiting for the bus at 5am in Horley

Hans Christian Anderson meet the Gays

Opera House

title.value: Denmark Holiday: Jessica's First Flight - Rosenborg

info.content:
Ben started the day by opening lots of presents. From the family he got a new mountain bike, an Android tablet and copious amounts of Lego sets. In fact he got so many Lego sets from everyone. It was almost an exclusive deal!

In the afternoon he had a Lego party. About 10 friends were invited. It was pretty raucous and one of the boys spoilt it a little with his bad behaviour. Anyway Ben had a nice time. His friend Theo then stayed for a sleepover.
Daddy went on the Mega Meon 80 mile bike ride, but didn't fair too well. His legs seized up after about 65 miles. Still good to finish in the end.
The Elders came over for a BBQ. We swapped Joey for Jessica for the night.

We left in early in the morning to go up to the Olympic Park where we met other Park runners. Daddy had entered the National Lottery 5 mile run which wound its way around the Queen Elizabeth Olympic Park.

Daddy actually ran with James, Duncan and Lee. The end of the race finished with a three quatres of a lap around the stadium, where many were watching and supporting. Fortunately we managed to pick Daddy out and vice versa. The last 80 yards turned into a sprint. A great day.

Outside the Olympic park

Kit Kat waiting for Daddy in the stadium

About to run

200 yards to go

Uncle Michael joined us at the Frimley Lodge Parkrun this morning. It was blisteringly hot even at 9am. Anyway Daddy improved on his PB time and now down to 22:21 for 5km.

After freshening up we decided not to go to Bournemouth as we thought the roads and beach would be just so packed that it wasn't worth it. So instead we went to visit the Silent Pool which is just the other side of Guildford. We couldn't get over how clear the water was despite all the wildlife, algy and people swimming in the pond. We walked around and found a nice spot to have our picnic. Us kiddies went and played in the water.

We returned back to Frimley Green in the early afternoon so we could go and visit a house that Mummy was keen for us to do. There was an open day on the house in Milden Close, just around the corner from Great Grandma. The house was very spacious and quite a bargain we thought for the price. Anyway mummy and daddy put an offer in there and then. We'll have to see how that fairs.

We wanted to continue the water theme, even if we weren't going to Bournemouth. So decided on the Aldershot Lido. Well it was packed there. 1500 others had the same idea. We queue for about 45 minutes before we even got in. Still we had a great time all 5 of us playing together and going on the flumes. Good times.

In the evening Mummy, the dirty stop out, went out clubbing at Lakeside Country Club for Silvi's 40th birthday celebrations.

Katie rooted

The ever so Silent Pool

title.value: Parkrun, Silent Pool, House Viewing, Aldershot Lido

info.content:
Jessica had a day off school and so spent the morning at Paula's and the afternoon with Mummy having a real mother and daughter afternoon. Or should I say plus Mathilda. Mathilda is the school teddy mole which you are supposed to chronicle her movements. A different child each week takes her home and looks after her.

Mathilda
Daddy came along to watch Jessica 'compete' in her sports day. She did ever so well, winning her interclass running sprint race.

Daddy was awoken with croissants in bed. A treat in this household. He opened his presents which comprised of cycling tops, a bottle, book and magazine, a shirt, t-shirt, vouchers, cash and a beautifully crafted mug with all our hands prints on.

Ben and Katie had each made a loaf of bread as well which Daddy used in his sandwiches. It didn't matter that it was very soggy and undercooked, Daddy still proudly showed off his lunch to his work colleagues.

The fars popped over with their presents in the evening and stayed for a nice cup of tea.

Ben had been practising for the past 6 weeks on his 100 lines in the school play. He managed to land the role of Tex, the sheriff of the wild west town. It was in the two main parts of the whole show and we and he were nervous before the performance.

There was no need for the nerves as he played his part brilliantly. He was expressive, passionate and loud enough for us to hear him. The rest of the family had queue for an hour to ensure we had the best seats in the house. We were so, so proud of him. Well done Ben. Unfortunately we were not allowed to take any picture of videos of him during the performance. Such a shame as his Stetson hat was massive and almost looked like a sombrero.

title.value: Daddy's 38th Birthday, Ben starring in School Play

info.content:
We always wonder how Jessica fairs at school as it is so hard to get her to take anything seriously or concentrate for more than 2 minutes. However, her school report was a pleasant surprise to us all.

She exceeded in all aspects of Personal, Social and Emotional development. The teacher commenting: Jessica has an excellent attitude towards behaviour and fully understands the difference between right and wrong. She is a good role model to others with her eagerness to learn and achieve. Jessica has been a pleasure to teach.

Well I never. Pick me up from the floor. Well done Jessica.

The Dixons had a nightmare 3 hour journey to get to our house. It was a very hot day. The BBQ was sizzling away and it was nice to see all the children were playing so well together.

The Fars cycled across and joined us and went over the green to the RLC Army Show. There were loads of big trucks and guns which was right up Reuben's street. We also went on the inflatable assault course, a go in the parachute, played noughts and crosses with a deep sea diver, went on the fun house and some other fast fun fair ride. We also had a couple of go's on the grenade course and finally the older children tackled the rope across the water challenge. A favourite by far.

We returned back, had some cold drinks and ice lollies, before everyone had to return home.

The RLC Revellers

Jessica and Yasmin watching Katie traverse the rope

Dave and Reuben driving in the desert

In the middle of being swung about

After church we went to the Runnymeade Pleasure Grounds and met with the Sanders who we haven't seen for a long time. We had a splash about in the paddling pool and a nice ice lolly.

The lineup

title.value: Runnymeade Pleasure Grounds with the Sanders

info.content:
In the morning Daddy, Ben and Natasha went to the Parkrun. Daddy still managed a sub 23 minute time which he was well pleased about. Natasha also completed the circuit for the first time.

Eva and Steve Barnett came over for a chat, cup of tea and a game of ball in the back garden which was nice for them to pop by.

In the afternoon Ben went to a Beaver event at Frimley Lodge Park. He loved the hike and teddy bear picnic.

Later in the evening we went to Heathrow Terminal 4 to pick Charlotte up from her holiday to Thailand.

Eva Ball Games

Beaver Games

Charlotte Pick Up

title.value: Parkrun, Eva Barnett visit, Beaver Hike, Airport Pickup

info.content:
Katie played for the school in a cricket competition a few weeks back. She was given some free tickets and gave them to Daddy for fathers day present. They set off as soon as Daddy got home from work. They stopped off at Sainsbury's for a few snacks, then made the longish walk to the Ageas Bowl in Hedge End, Southampton where Hampshire play. In the queue we saw Leah Rushforth which was nice. The weather was good and we settled down to watch some cricket. Katie was taking it all in and enjoying the atmosphere. Overall we sat in 5 different places within the ground. Katie was taken by the hot tub bath which was weirdly placed by the boundary with a load of teenagers dipping in and out. Katie also took a lot of action shots of the cricket. We had a lovely time, although cannot help feeling the attraction was a lot to having a late night!

In the stands

Overlooking the Ageas Bowl

Not more than 12 hours having his new bike, Daddy met up with Uncle Michael and rode 75 miles to meet with us at Ma Ma and Pop Pop's house. Daddy was pleased he could now keep up with Michael on his new bike.

We went to Ma Ma's to celebrate her birthday with the Elders. After the boys turned up, and a cheeky quick BBQ we went down to ride Tiki in the woods.

Jessica riding Tiki

Katie riding Tiki

title.value: Bike to Ma Ma's, Tiki Ride

info.content:
As part of Mummy's birthday she wanted to do one of our walks from the book. We started off at Sloane Square and walked down across Albert Bridge to Battersea Park. There we played in the park, then came back.

Bench pressed

Daddy had bought a second hand road bike (racer for you old folk) off the internet which he was very happy with. Â£425 for a Giant Defy I 2011 model. Anyway he had to go all the way down to Taunton and back again to pick it up. He was well pleased with his purchase.

title.value: Walk 44: Battersea Park Walk. Katie Party, New Road Bike

info.content:
Daddy went with Barrie to Royal Ascot in an all expenses paid (courtesy of Bazza's dad) trip. Started at 10:30 at the West household with Champaigne and fish. A bus ride later and we were in the Fast Lane for the Fosters Bar. We didn't win any races, but had a good time and continued drinking in Fleet until midnight!

Royal Ascot

Daddy joined Michael and Nick and other fellow CNL'ers on the 54 mile trek from Clapham to Brighton. It took 4.5 hours and Daddy felt it went so much better and easier than last year.

The L2B'ers

We went to the annual Pribright village fair where they have the unique scarecrow competition.

The Twits

Katie represented the school at cricket. She was very good, prefering the bowling. As part of her participation she received two free tickets to a Hampshire Cricket match.

Katie School Cricket Team

After another big breakfast we decided to lay off the beers and go sightseeing. Again the weather was perfect. We literally done a lap of Paris. The roads were quiet. Sights included: Hotel De Ville, Notre Dame, Invalides, Eiffel Tower and again the Champs-Elysee.... Oh did I mention we stopped for a patisserie.

On our way back to the hotel we stopped to get gifts and even had a McDonalds before boarding the stress-free EuroStar back to Kings Cross. The journey took 2:15 hours. We played cards for most of the journey home.

Mum and Dad picked me up from the station and drove me home whilst the others had to cycle to Paddington, catch a train, then cycle home. Total mileage: 222 miles.

Route

Invalides

Tour Eiffel

Route

We started the day having bright blue skies for the first time for a long while. It was gorgeous. We tucked in customary style into a large 'eat as much as you like breakfast'. We began what we thought would be a gentle 30 mile ride into Paris. It was nice to get out of the fields scenery and more into towns where the life was.

Setting off from Hotel Campenile

We must have done 2 miles before we had a half an hour stop so Steve could pick up some sun cream and a hanger from a market place!

The ride was mainly off road, sometimes on a gravelly path through the woods, some tarmac path. There were a couple of hills to please us all. We made a point at saying 'bonjour' to oncoming riders, and only 2 out of about 15 begrudgingly returned a compliment. They're an unfriendly bunch.

We had some busy 70mph dual carriageways to negotiate where Nick's lights fell off his bike. Steve and I lost him for a bit but stopped at Versailles Gardens for him. However, Nick glided past without hearing the bellowing boys. Passers-by were laughing. Eventually we met up at a big statue in the middle of a roundabout.

Statue at Versailles

The ride was surprisingly a peaceful one through various parks. We had our first sight of Paris itself at Parc de Saint Cloud. We stopped off for a viewing and a drink before continuing over the River Seine.

Adonis

I wanted to detour to go to Roland Garros, especially as the French Open was on this week. They managed to see a Russian woman tennis player, but we do not know who it was.

Riding along park land again we were 5 miles from the hotel at this stage. We came across a car parked up on the side of the road. She looked like a hooker. Cleaning the inside of her car down. Something very dubious happened there. Still we got a photo just in case we needed to provide evidence!

We stopped off at another top notch patisserie for some lunch. Super high quality. We rolled up the hill to the iconic Arc De Triomphe. I set the challenge to cycle around the 10 lane roundabout. Steve didn't fancy it, he instead got accosted by beggars who had a curious scheme which we still cannot work out. They would drop a ring in front of you making it seem that it was yours. They would then try and give it to you. Then What? Dumbfounded.

After circling the Arc a few times, we headed down the very bumpy, cobble stoned Champs-Elysee. We were making slow progress in the traffic. Still this is what it was all about. Don't know how the Tour De France riders handle it on their road bikes at speed. They must need a chiropodist by the end. By now we just wanted to get to the hotel and freshen up and dump the bags.

Champs Elysee

Riding Down The Champs Elysee

We were in the Chopin Suite on the top floor. I had the choice of beds this time.... and took the double. The bathroom was the size of the kitchen diner at home, and it had jets squirting stuff from the sides.

The boys were out on the town. First stop was a beer at the end of the road, then a walk to the Sacre Cour, where Steve made friends again with beggars and was called 'strong man' as he tried to get away from the grabbing man. We went in the impressive, grand cathedral. The views were magnificent. Steve was gasping for a beer. After doing a few laps we ended up in a bar opposite the Moulin Rouges for a 20 euro round of alcohol much to my disgust.

Sitting in the sun watching the world go by on the street was very nice. After a frogs legs dinner we hit the metro and waited to see if Steve was going to deliver the promised 'good night out'. He researched by googling 'Where Single Girls Hang Out Paris'. Brilliant. Only the Dawg. We were worried at first as there wasn't too much around, and then we hit Rue Oberkampf. This was very busy. We hit a bar and convinced Steve to climb the stairs that led to the ceiling. Doh!

We then went to '114' which had dancing..... a dancing Steve and I. There was a dj spitting out euro music. Nick was not a dancer and so went off for an explore.... and not seen again by the other two for another3 hours! He got lost.

Out for the night. Me and Kingster

Steve and I decided to walk and partially run back to the Hotel. On the way we got a kebab and were approached by prostitutes! Paris at 3am was busier than it was at 3pm strangely enough. There were loads of bars which had massive queues outside. It was 3am.

Meanwhile Nick, who had lost his map, not remembered a phone charger or the name of the hotel was lost! He followed others to the 'centre' where ever that was, but soon lost them. Not sure on the order of these events, but he trod in dog poo, attempted to help a man who was worse for wear, then was sick over Nick's shoes (he had no socks on either). Yuk. He also needed the toilet! Still worse was to come after he eventually found the hotel and began to wash the sick out. After settling down and getting some much needed sleep, Steve decided to hop into Nicks bed and 'spoon' him. Nick, startled, told Steve politely to bugger off. The shock on Steve's face was a picture. This happened again!

Great day.

title.value: Day 4: Bike Villennes Sur Seine to Paris

info.content:
Today I consider as the main cycling day. It started slowly as we stocked up on food and cycle repairs. Nick had almost lost his arm in attempting to pump his tyre up.
